reviewText:
The barrel of the soldier's gun is IN the Sectoid's MOUTH.
65% chance to hit.

Your hit-chance is above 75%.
Guaranteed miss.

The Stun Lancer is 30 tiles away.
It sprints to your squad, incapacitates one soldier, nearly killing them in the process, and panics two others. Both panicked soldiers throw grenades at their own feet.

A Viper is 15 tiles away. Will it use its long-range grab or will it use its long-range poison AoE?
Trick question. There are two Vipers. They use both.

Is there a sectoid anywhere?
No?
Wrong. Your best soldier just got mind-controlled. The sectoid fled before you could kill it.

You actually made it back from an engagement. Nobody died and the worst damage anyone took was about 5 points of health.
Five of the six soldiers you brought are now shaken, reducing their willpower to 0.

This game isn't about strategizing a victory. It's about strategizing the most spectacular loss you can, because ♥♥♥♥ ain't gonna work out in your favor, even if the percentages seem to.
10/10 would hang myself again

reviewText:
XCOM 2 is a turn based tactical strategy game, releasing on PC in February 2016. The game is a direct sequel to XCOM Enemy Unknown which was released in 2012. XCOM 2 was developed by 2K Games and Firaxis Games.

Like the first game, game play is separated into two. A management style simulator of controlling your base, and technologies inside it, whether it be through engineering or scientific research – allowing you to advance certain aspects of your base how you choose. Along with the base management side of the game, there is also a map style function which is where you move your ship around the world to different locations, or hubs of activity. Whilst on the map you will see side missions, your main missions, scrap piles to explore for extra money, along with a plethora of other activities to take part in.

The main mechanic in XCOM is of course the tactical squad based game play.  This squad of soldiers can consist of five different classes, which again can be specialized even further by using the skills tree which you earn points in through promoting your squad members. To begin with the classes start out very much the same apart from the weapons that they use. After you have gained a few promotions with the characters you will start to differentiate the classes quite a bit with the abilities they will gain. The actual in game mechanics are very much the same as the previous version of XCOM, but just with general improvements. The game’s cover base system works really well, with some handy UI enhancements that make it easier to see how the cover affects you.  What I wasn’t too keen on was the aiming mechanic. On countless occasions I found myself face-to-face with a foe, and still my percentage chance to hit them with my gun would be around 30%. I know there is always going to be a chance anyone will miss a target, but c’mon, these are trained soldiers in point blank range, it shouldn’t be that low. This became increasingly annoying as you progress through the game onto harder enemies which make a habit of getting up close and personal with you.  Overall I found the game play in XCOM to be really intuitive and very addictive with that “oh one more turn” feel to it.

Graphically, XCOM 2 is a really stellar looking title. Absolutely crisp animations of anything that moves, right the way down to the rag doll effect of bodies when they get shot (or blown apart). It just looks so fluid that it feels real. The textures and character models are also really high quality too. Normally in tactical games like this the graphical element is more skinned down on to allow for more focus on the game play but not XCOM 2. It is one of the best looking games to come out in the past 12 months and one that will really challenge your rig if you want to push out max settings.  The voice acting is top notch too; I was a little disappointed that all of the enemies have the same kind of voice, but given that there is plenty of different enemies in the game to begin with, this can be forgiven a bit. I would have liked to have seen a little extra depth used with sound in the game mechanics; there is an element of stealth to the game play, at least at the start of missions. It would have been nice to have some sort of sound meter that would trigger alarms for the enemies if you made too much sound – again just a small improvement which would of made the immersion all that more deeper.
The game has varying levels of difficulty for the overall campaign – this of course is down to how hard you want the game to be.  After you have finished one play through of the game you will unlock “Ironman” mode which essentially saves your game after every action you take, meaning you cannot jump back a few saves if you messed something up. You have one chance to succeed and that is it. Given that the side missions in the campaign can make a real impact on how the rest of the game pans out, I see this as a really interesting game mode that has the potential to have endless amounts of replay ability. I have been playing for roughly 15 hours so far and I have just about finished my first play through. I will for sure be trying out the Ironman mode personally to see how hard it really can be. Where you start on the world map, and the in game maps are all randomly generated, so whilst the actual objectives of missions may stay the same, where you carry out those objectives will differ from play through to play through.

Technically, I had a couple of issues. The main one being I did get random crashes. A few of these caused my graphics drivers to crash. This stopped when I configured an SLI profile for my two 970s and helped with the overall performance of the game too thankfully.  I was happy enough playing on 1080p given the high quality of the graphics on show to begin with. My rig was not capable of playing at 4k, and to be honest I think you would struggle to find a rig to play any of today’s recent releases on 4k.  Whack you’re AA up to max and you won’t really notice a difference though.

XCOM 2 is by far the best game in the series so far; the graphical enhancement of the game, as well as the improvements made on the already core game play mechanics makes this a tactical turn based player’s wet dream. Apart from the technical issues I had, I have struggled to find anything major wrong with this release.  The game’s regular price tag of £34, 99 is the mark of this being a AAA release; the sceptics amongst us will want to wait for this to drop into the sales market but if you are keen to pick up where Enemy Unknown left off, XCOM 2 will definitely keep you entertained for plenty more hours with a greater gaming experience.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

You may also be interested in checking out a PC gaming podcast, be sure to head here.

reviewText:
There are a lot of things about this game that bug the crap out of me. The timed missions, the Avatar project which basically puts a timer on the campaign itself, the scarcity of elerium cores which makes outfitting your squad kind of hard, the same old six person squad size, the needless delays that make the game seem to grind to a halt at the worst possible times...the list goes on and on...

But there is a mod for every one of those complaints. Every. Single. One.

For everything about this game I din't like, someone else didn't like it either and made a mod to fix it. Then all of these truly amazing modders came along and created wonderful content that took an already impressively open game and expanded it even further. I have no idea how many mods I am currently subscribed to at this point, but every complaint I had about the game when I first bought it has been addressed by the community and my games are much more diverse due to all of the options unlocked through user created content. I'd also like to add that despite having an absurd number of mods active the game is VERY stable. This many mods on something like Fallout New Vegas? Forget about it.

So if you enjoyed XCOM and were on the fence about this one you should consider giving it a try. If there is something you heard about it that made you hesitant about picking it up, wait for it to go on sale. I am glad I bought it, though, and it is even better than the previous iteration.

reviewText:
(This review is available in both written and video formats below for your convenience.)
https://youtu.be/aD3Fuws6nJI

In 2012, Firaxis released Xcom Enemy Unknown which helped breathe new life into the genre and successfully rebooted the classic UFO defense franchise. Now, 4 years later, Xcom 2 hopes to improve on all of the elements of its predecessor.

Taking place roughly 20 years after where the first game left off, and in an unusual sense for a sequel, Xcom 2 assumes you failed Enemy Unknown as it now takes place in a dystopian future where the aliens have conquered earth. Rather than defending the planet from UFOs, you’re tasked with bolstering resistance cells across the globe with your mobile, flying fortress; the avenger. This functions in the same way as your underground base from the first title, as you can upgrade it, add new facilities, as well as recruit soldiers while managing research and production.

The core concepts are similar to Enemy Unknown and you’re faced with a constant race against the clock since the aliens are developing something called the Avatar project. Certain missions will act to delay the progress of the project, but it's game-over upon its completion. There’s also dark events which can provide random modifiers and buffs to the aliens you encounter. Occasionally you’ll be prompted to complete guerilla missions which allow you to prevent a dark event but you’re unable to stop them all, as you’ll typically have to pick and choose which event is most pressing.

The world map functions similarly to Enemy Unknown. You’ll set up a base and will be able to scan the map for certain points of interest. Building radio relays in countries will increase your monthly budget, and continental bonuses make a return, adding some elements of strategy and planning. Upon scanning the map, you’ll frequently be interrupted to go on missions, which are all randomly generated with varying objectives. These objectives range from escorting an NPC, saving civilians, eliminating a target or killing every alien in an area.

The turn-based combat is what you’d come to expect from an Xcom game, death is permanent and your soldiers can still possibly miss a point-blank shot which otherwise has a 97% success rate. Stealth has been added, which can allow you to strategically place your soldiers and set up ambushes with overwatch, but a lot of the time you’ll feel rushed as there isn’t much time to complete the objectives in most cases. Taking one extra step is sometimes enough to alert enemies to your presence, so you really have to balance between moving cautiously and completing a mission as fast as possible. That element of randomness can be a detriment, as sometimes a civilian could block a ladder and thus seal off the only way up to a rooftop extraction, or a ridiculous amount of enemies could spawn directly on top of a transmitter you’re otherwise supposed to protect. Which leads to one major issue with Xcom 2, it’s extremely luck based and these random factors can cause you to fail a mission with very little control. You can recover from failed missions, but it does feel a little unfair and can be a major downer for ironman playthroughs in which you only have one save file.

The soldier classes feel a lot more fleshed out and distinct from one another as they all kind of blurred together in the previous installment. For example the Ranger is equipped with a sword which can absolutely devastate enemies in melee combat while the specialist has a drone that can hack hostile robotic units or support squad mates from anywhere on the map. The scientists and engineers play more of a role now as well. They’re actually named and can be individually assigned to different projects.

Xcom 2 also completely expands on the level of customization, giving a lot more appearance options for your soldiers. You’re also able to modify your soldiers’ weapons with various attachments as well as give them performance enhancing implants. While all of these customization options were quite welcomed, this resulted in some completely broken and overpowered combinations. For example, I had given one of my soldiers a superior repeater which gave him a 15% chance to instantly execute whatever target he was shooting at and as a result I was able to one-shot the hardest enemy in the game. The difficulty in general is kind of spiky, while the game initially starts off as challenging; it quickly becomes too easy upon developing certain technologies. Some better pacing would have greatly alleviated this issue because as it stands, it can switch from being so easy that it’s tedious to frustrating with little warning.

At first, there seems to be a greater variety of enemies present in Xcom 2. The majority of enemies you face are Advent troopers, human-like soldiers that support the alien regime, while more familiar aliens such-as sectoids function as lieutenants and are actually a greater threat than the previous games. The other aliens have also evolved over the twenty year gap between Enemy Unknown. Unfortunately you hardly fight them in the latter half of the game as you pretty much always face the same enemies over and over again at that point.

I also had some issues with the world map. It gives you so many optional areas to scan for additional supplies and personnel but you’re interrupted every two seconds to take part in another randomly generated mission. There are very few actual story missions, and the random stages can really get tedious in the latter half of the game. There’s also very little rhyme or reason going into the appearance of a stage. You could accept a mission in Africa only for there to be pine trees and snow on the ground, making no sense whatsoever. There are a lot of bugs present in the game as well. From graphical glitches, laggy animations and the odd crash.

Xcom 2 promised re-playability with its use of random stages but I would’ve honestly preferred handcrafted levels with more of a narrative. There’s also extra mod support this time around but most of the mods available currently are cosmetic or the odd weapon, which doesn’t really add anything significant to the gameplay.

The multiplayer from Enemy Unknown makes an appearance again but it’s even more of a throw-away mode this time around. You’re given even less customization options than before as you’re no longer able to choose the rank and loadout of human soldiers. The turns don’t play out simultaneously and can take an extremely long time as there’s quite a bit of additional lag between them. That combined with crashes and random disconnects make this mode barely playable.

The soundtrack is well done and changes to match the mood of the battle as well as the enemies you encounter. Unfortunately, there isn't much variety between tracks and it isn't as memorable as Michael Mccann’s soundtrack from Enemy Unknown who was probably too busy working on Deus Ex Mankind Divided.

Ultimately, Xcom 2 makes a very strong first impression but it was all downhill from there though, and towards the end of the game, I couldn’t wait to be done with all the randomly generated filler content. That coupled with an overall lack of pacing made it a bit of a disappointment. It’s an improvement over Enemy Unknown in some areas but a step-back in others. Xcom 2 is by no means a bad game, and will most likely improve with time; I was just expecting a lot more.

Pros +	Strong Turn Based Tactical Combat
+	Increased Customization Options
+	Interesting Premise
+	Soldier classes and base management are more refined.

Cons -	Repetitive Gameplay and Filler Content
-	Numerous Bugs
-	Lackluster Multiplayer
-	Not enough of an improvement over Enemy Unknown

reviewText:
Listen: At its best, XCOM 2 is a great game and if you liked XCOM EU there is a lot you would like here. The good parts are covered in other positive reviews and I mostly agree with them.

However, I cannot recommend this game as a $60 release in the state it is in.

To be honest, I rarely buy games new at full price because I simply don't make that much money. However, I made an exception for this one because the buzz/preview coverage was very positive and I loved the formula established in EU. They couldn't mess it up THAT much, could they? In my opinion, they didn't and the gameplay experience is mostly great with a few minor quibbles here and there. But even considering that, the technical state this game is in makes me very wary about buying a game at launch ever again. I feel burned.

The most noticeable thing is is that the performance is terrible - I SHOULD be able to run it at ultra or high settings at 60fps but am sitting around medium with occasional slowdown. Honestly it's a minor thing because graphics aren't the biggest deal to me, but it is still something that annoys me given everything else. But if it was the only thing? Totally fine.
Unfortunately the bugs in this game are terrible. XCOM at it's best is a tight, no nonense strategy game where you make well thought out, in the moment decisions and live with the consequences. Unfortunately, bugs and crashes interrupt game flow and can make going through missions a slog. I currently have had three crashes in the middle of an action where a crash dialog box would pop up but I would be unable to force quit the game or access the task manager, forcing me to force restart my whole computer. Just my luck as every single time that I happened I was in a hectic situation that was going well for me. At that point I would have to go back to the game, load the last autosave and try and recreate the situation I was in before the game crashed. Completely breaks enjoyment of the game. I've gotten past them, but each time it happens make me less excited to return to the game.
I've also had instances where I've completely destroyed all of the walls of a lower floor in the hopes it would drop an enemy from above only to have it not happen? My only guess is that if a ladder connects the ground to an upper floor it makes it so I can't destroy that floor, which is not a  bug I guess, but still ridiculous. In that same instance I couldn't target a unit that was behind said ladder despite there being no walls around it and despite the unit not being in any sort of cover.
Right now I'm in a mission where I have to neutralize or knock out an advent VIP. There is a sectopod near the VIP, so I send a unit with chain shot up to try and shoot the sectopod. Presumably both the sectopod and the VIP are in my line of sight, but for whatever reason I can't change between targets - even when clicking the yellow (flanked) VIP icon or trying to tab between targets, it targets the sectopod. That would be fine except every times I confirm the shot on the sectopod, my soldier shoots the VIP. Excuse me? I was able to destroy the sectopod in another way, but only after reloading my autosave and trying to puzzle out how to get the game to do what I wanted (and should have) been able to do.
In this same mission, I finally kill the enemies, knock out the VIP, and carry him away. However, when I knocked him out he was next to a burning car. NO MATTER HOW FAR I AM AWAY FROM THE CAR, and NO MATTER HOW MANY MORE UNITS ARE CLOSER TO THE VEHICLE, when the car explodes the VIP takes damage and dies. Once again, even my soldiers who are closer to the car than my unit carrying the VIP don't take damage. Only the VIP.

There are other bugs and crashes, but none quite as egregious or memorable like the ones above. At this point I would have to reload the mission in a previous state to try and figure out a way to get past this particular bug. I don't want to do that and shouldn't have to, frankly. I'm not into Ironman difficulties but also don't like save scumming to get the outcome I want. In this case I'm savescumming because the game is messing up, which just sucks!

At this point I feel like I'm trying to beat the game because I feel obligated, considering how much time I put into it, not because I really want to. And it's a shame because because the gameplay is pretty good and I should WANT to beat it because of how fun it is! But I just never know which mission is going to be the breaking point, where I finally hit a point where my best soldiers die not because of my mishandling but because of the game's mistakes. THAT is problematic and it  makes me not excited to return to this game. And maybe I won't. Who knows.

It's been a month now and things aren't really ironed out still. I understand a lot of games ship in various states of disrepair but it shouldn't be like this. Maybe other people can get past these things, and maybe other people won't even come across these issues, but I personally wouldn't recommend buying this game at full retail price until it is patched extensively.

EDIT:
Since writing this review I have played for about three more hours, finishing the campaing. Despite the last mission being mostly great, my recommendation of this game remains the same. Aside from the regular shoddy performance, there were a few bad spots: once again selected one target only to somehow shoot at another, and two instances of not being able to throw a grenade/other item farther than a few squares away with two different soldiers in different locations. Was able to use other soldiers/skills to give me the result I more or less wanted, but still I am annoyed I wasn't able to do what I WANTED to do. Those things did not invalidate the mission as a whole but still muddied what should have been a great experience.

Overall, the game's technical failings are a shame. When firing on all cylinders, this game is fantastic. However, the game's tight flow is too often interrupted by perfomance issues. Given just how IMPORTANT that flow is to making the game enjoyable, it's a damn shame that there are too many instances of you, the player, not being allowed to experience it. You feel like you're hitting a stride, and then all of a sudden a crash or a bug pops up and you stumble through no fault of your own leaving you to deal with the consequences or get back up and try all over again. That just sucks.

Whether you just heard of this game in passing and were intrigued or loved Enemy Unknown, I would highly recommend you do NOT buy this game until there is a hefty sale going on or until it is reliably patched. Preferably the latter. This is a game that should be experienced with no technical caveats as the sytems underneath are enjoyable, addicting, and often rewarding. Unfortunately that time is not now. Or who knows? Maybe you won't experience the bugs I have, as some people didn't. Guess you could just roll the dice.

Though, it's true the game need some performance patch.

Other than that the performance issue and few random lag, its graphic is great.
Sound is great (it manages to catch the atmosphere).
Gameplay is very XCOM EU/EW,   though I haven't been playing for a long time, but it's looking good so far.

If you've played XCOM EU/EW, I'd reccomend it fully.
If you haven't, that depends on your preferable genre, as not everyone prefer a strategy game

A bit of advice for people who haven't played XCOM EU/EW, this game quite relies on RNG, don't expect your 99% hit precentage to hit. Always prepare a strategy in case it misses. Still, that doesn't mean it's 100% pure luck type of game, the strategy layer is deep enough to make up for the RNG.

UPDATE: Finished the game.
Well, it's kind of confusing now that I've seen all the game has to offer. It's not a bad game by all means, it just really push you to be proactive, which good for most people, not really good for other.

The following things is purely my opinion:

The good one
+The avatar project timer is well timed. Not leaving you too laid back, but not really killing your gameplay.

+The timers in missions is sometimes bad, sometimes good, though what really screw me up is the placement of the objective in most mission. (♥♥♥♥ capture mission though). But mostly, it's tight but not too tight.

+The enemies are varied, which is good. I don't think it will ever be a bad point.

+The costumization is good.

+Destructible enviroment. Like, super destructible. This is good.

+The mods are awesome already, and we're not even hitting the one week mark.

The bad one
-Some abilities are useless late game, or at least not as useful as the other one. This is a bad point, as every abilities should be useful until late game, to make a varied gameplay.

-The pacing is weird and done too quickly. There should be a few mission with the introduction of new enemies. Instead in early time, I met new enemy in every mission. This is bad for new players who haven't learned anything about the enemies.

-♥♥♥♥ codex

-The final mission isn't as good as EU/EW. Warning though, this is purely my opinion.

-The buying of new weapon and armor is weird. One mission you're underpowered, the next one you're super powered. I don't really like it as there's no transition from one point to another.  The use of experimental stuff is also weird.

-The lack of stuff. It's like they only focused on the enemies, instead of the thing we'll be using against it.

reviewText:
A very good game plagued by questionable design decisions. The most obvious culprit is the mission turn limits. Apparentely this was done because overwatch was too strong and they wanted more fast paced/tense gameplay.

Unfortunately it's not well implemented, I don't know if its better on other difficulties but on Ironman/commander you barely have enough time to get from point A to B. This makes lots of abilities and even the sharpshooter class quite useless. Why would I carefuly place my sniper on a roof top to flank the enemy if I know I won't have enough time to get her to the evac point in time? Combine this with some extremely powerful enemies like sectoids that appear early and often and you got yourself a major headache.

On the other end of the spectrum the Ranger and Specialist are much stronger for the pace of the game, the specialist being especially crucial in the hacking missions.

There are also lots of reports of bad performance, I've been lucky enough not to get any but I also turned down certain performance killing options. But from a game that is supposed to be a pc exclusive and was delayed to make sure it's flawless, it's very dissapointing.

On the bright side the graphics and sound are great. Executing a perfect ambush against a group of enemies is extremely satisfying (unfortunately you rarely get the chance to do this because you have to hurry so much.

I have no doubt that with a few patches/modding this game will shine and I will have no problem recommending it, but right now (especially with the price tag) I can't do so.


TLDR version :

+ Great sound and graphics
+ Ambushes are very satisfying
+ I love the new revamped classes, especially the specialist.
+ Still the same heartpumping X-com action.

-Mission timers for almost EVERY mission
-some very powerful enemies early on with little way to counter them
-Performance problems

P.S. I chose the not recommended" option but I would choose a "neutral" option if there were one. It is not a bad game by any stretch and I feel I might update this to positive if a performance patch comes out soon."

reviewText:
XCOM 2 is essentially XCOM 1 with everything dialed up a notch. The short of it is that if you liked and played XCOM 1 for any significant amount of time then you are almost guaranteed to enjoy XCOM 2.

Great new additions or significant improvements:
RNG: The huge role random chance played in the core mechanics of XCOM 1 was something that really bothered me and many other players. Thankfully, in this iteration, there are so many more ways of dealing guaranteeing damage that it is relatively simple to mitigate RNG almost completely with the appropriate style of play. A few things allow this: first off more abilities that are guaranteed to deal damage including combat protocol on the specialist and weapon upgrades that deal dmg on missed shots, cover is more destructible this time around which allows you to easily expose enemies for reliable shots and most importantly the way the game works now allows and even encourages aggressive flanking. It is not uncommon to get 90-100% shot success on most missions mid way through the campaign now as a result.

Aggression and overwatch spam: Due to the way the maps were configured and the constant threat of activating additional groups of enemies, a very defense oriented and overwatch centered tactical play style was considered optimal in XCOM 1. This is entirely not the case in XCOM 2. The way the maps are setup now, it feels like you have much more room to maneuver around the map without fatally exposing your squad. With the concealment mechanic which lets you sneak up on the aliens and with the presence of turn limits on many more missions this time around, the game actually encourages an aggressive playstyle where you take out enemy groups with 1-2 turns of activating them through aggressive flanking and, as is my preference, heavy use of explosives. Another important aspect of this is that using explosives no longer equates to losing the loot you desperately need to fund your operations. It’s a little bit more complicated than that but generally speaking you don’t have to stress so much about not blowing up the aliens this time around.

Additional customization options: I really wasn’t into tweaking the appearance of my soldiers in XCOM 1 that much but with the mind blowing amount of customization options available now, I’m really getting attached to some of my soldiers that I’ve decked out to look badass. The character pool system which lets saved soldiers randomly appear in your campaign as recruits or VIPs or scientists and engineers is also quite brilliant and unexpected allowing for favorite soldiers to effortlessly reappear in a new campaign. With the out of the box support for mods through steam workshop, the already staggering number of options will only grow.

Things which are problematic:
Unresponsiveness: I had this complaint with XCOM 1 as well. What I’m talking about is how the game loves to take control away from you in the middle of the action, locking the camera and disabling input while it makes you stare at a “new” enemy that you’ve already seen before accompanied by Central or the Doctor essentially telling you what you most likely already know. There is seemingly more of that this time around and some abilities, in particular gremlin abilities on the specialist have unnecessarily long animations for you to endure. Some of this also applies to the UI in the macro game (the avenger and geoscape). Transferring from the geoscape to the armory menu for instance, take entirely too long and clicking while the animation is in progress may end up sending you to another menu accidentally which only serves to frustrate the matter more.

UI streamlining: In the course of trying to make the UI less dense, a lot of useful information has been buried further down in menus. This leads to a lot of unnecessary clicking to find important bits of information and makes comparing some stats across soldiers unjustifiably painful. The biggest culprit of course, is not being able to see vital soldier stats side by side across soldiers, including their hp and what upgrades they have installed on themselves and their gear. There are several other places where the streamlined approach makes information difficult to discern or understand due to ambiguity, but all this one can get used to eventually, even though some frustration will be encountered along the way. I suspect this is once again a symptom of PC games being constrained by a UI designed for a controller. It’s not a major gripe, but it is something which should have been improved in this iteration and not the other way around as it stands now.

reviewText:
Target Audience:  Tactical Combat Fans that want a challenge, and don't have beefs with the RNG gods.

Review Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dsQH16fF9Dc

Summary:
The game that has everything going for it as a sequel to one of the best reborn franchises of the last 5 years.....with one huge exception. The tactical combat from the original returns with some additional units and mechanics that takes it to the next level. The small changes like additional focus on timed missions helped the game in the big picture a lot, and the improved balance/skill trees made every class a great boon in the right situation. The simulation portion of the game may have been streamlined....but it was for the better in my opinion, as it makes an impact on your combat performance directly. The visuals for the most part are nice, although it will take you out the experience as well with some bad glitches. The story makes a bit more sense this time around and while its filled with scifi tropes, it does the job. This would be a shoe-in purchase if the performance issues, load times, and glitches are taken care of, because they REALLY create a major problem in the end, as I would have stopped playing if I wasn't formal reviewing the game. If you've got a backlog: play through it first, and wait for some of the issues to be fixed.

Lists:
My Positives:
The well known combat is still as good as ever, with incremental improvements. Difficult but smartly put together.
Class balance seems to be there a bit more this time around..Psy operatives were useful and still strong, but a great grenadier or ranger could give them a run for their money.
Simulation elements wisely refined, and seemed to make the difference in the battle in the long run.
Like the addition of more timed missions: it forces  less conservative play, and put your units more in danger, but not to the point where it was unwinnable.
Great character customization added that makes the sting of losing a soldier that much harder, when you've put the effort in crafting them from the bottom up. Your soldiers also can have a nice in-game personality that actually shows up in the lines.
Great move on Firaxis part to put in mod support on day one. I expect a lot to be done, as there's a lot of potential in the various weapons/units/etc.
The secondary equipment makes a huge difference this time around, and there was actually huge reasons to take it along as opposed to another med pack.
Improved visuals, in particular with character designs. Like the simple yet effective designs of the Viper and the Gatekeeper.
For those who really want it, Firaxis put several autosaves in there at the start of a mission and last turn. If you're a cheater. Cause it's cheating.
My Negatives:
Hate, hate the new graze system. It adds an element to combat that you don't know what it directly does in terms of percent probability for it to happen, and is generally an unknown factor. It's the one thing you don't know, and it will REALLY get on your nerves.
Panic system seems to mean less then before.
Held together by glue and string, it seems. The game can run great at times, but when something goes wrong, bad things happen to not only the performance, but the in game mechanics get messed with as well. It's unstable.
The loading times. My god the loading times. At one point, it took 3 minutes,  27 seconds to load into the next portion of the game. Unoptimized, the game is not.
Glitch Fest 2000. Hits a wide spectrum of issues, from graphical, to camera, to in-game affecting. Takes you right of the experience. It's funny at times....but really annoying at others. Especially when the camera decides to show you a wall because it can't figure out jack ♥♥♥♥.
The music doesn't do the job like the original. It just doesn't have the punch, it's good....but compared to the original, it just doesn't work at ALL.

reviewText:
Twenty years have passed since the conclusion of XCOM: Enemy Unknown, and we lost. The alien menace has convinced the XCOM council to join them, now calling themselves Advent. Advent has completely taken over the world promising advanced tech, medicine and world peace. The biggest problem is they rule with an iron fist. The XCOM program lives on in the form of a resistance.

Welcome back to the world of XCOM. Enemy Unknown was released in 2012, and a lot has changed and a lot has stayed the same. XCOM, for those unfamiliar with the series, are military strategy games that have always been about decision making. Whether the decision is one about what equipment to build, what tech to research, or giving orders to soldiers in the field; your decisions make the game. This series was one of the first to use permanent death for squad mates.

If one dies, they do not come back. This made players very cautious on how to use their squad, or even which squad mates to send in. Do you send in your most experienced? Or do you take a chance and send in a couple veterans and a couple of rookies? Keeping in mind that, of course, the veterans are better and have more skills, unfortunately, if they die you lose access to all their training and skills. It was also one of the first series to introduce recovery time for injured characters. If a soldier got injured in the field, they need time to recover. Hope you have some reserves.

Where XCOM 2 really shines are with the improvements they made over the last game. In the previous game, players picked where they wanted their base to be. Different locations gave different bonuses. In this game your base is mobile, making you harder to detect and capture. In the command room is a holographic map of the world, and when looking at the it several choices are available at any given time. Should you make contact with a resistance cell in another part of the world? Go steal the supplies from Advent forces nearby? Or should you take out that black site in hopes of securing more soldiers, scientists or engineers? This is a massive switch from the previous game where players really couldn’t move around and all they could do is scan the world for trouble until trouble presented itself.

The alien invasion story has been one of the biggest areas of improvement since Enemy Within. Its characters talk more, fleshing out a story and creating a sense of companionship despite the fact they’re clearly just a cipher for each part of your mobile base’s inner workings. There’s more mystery here, and great cutscenes go a long way to layering on more and more intrigue as you discover bigger,more sinister revelations about the alien’s intentions. To say much more would be a disservice to the great surprises, but the game’s narrative setup - an oppressive occupying force vs a struggling resistance - doesn’t just allow for a greater storytelling: it makes for a much stronger marriage between story and gameplay.

XCOM 2 introduces plenty of new gameplay elements that fit this new style, like player-placed extraction zones, ambushes, and a complete restructuring of character classes to reflect the focus on guerrilla combat. Players will find themselves thinking hard about which classes to bring into a particular firefight, and finding the right combination of soldier types will be a hard-fought trial-and-error process. Likewise, when players start in concealment – a new stealth aspect that is brand new to the franchise – they’ll find themselves tediously organizing ambushes to maximize their overwatch impact.

XCOM 2 is a serious strategy game, even on normal difficulty. The AI rarely makes stupid moves, and will respond to your mistakes with absolutely brutal efficiency. My most common mistake in the first few hours was advancing too far forward with one trooper, spotting a group of enemies, and watching the pioneer get slaughtered with their companions too far away to help. This is a crucial part of how XCOM 2 works – allow your troops to get isolated from each other, or leave a flank exposed, and you’ll be punished.

You’ll need to use every trick at your disposal in XCOM 2, as the ADVENT aren't here to play around. The aliens from the Enemy Unknown have been settled on Earth for some time and are more powerful for it. Sectoids - once the lowest ranking enemy in the game - are now powerful mid-game units that can disorientate and debuff your units while ADVENT troops (humans modified by the aliens) flank and close the distance.

The ADVENT forces are varied and require a considerable amount of tactical thought. Even amongst its foot soldiers there are officers, grunts, sword-wielding assault troopers and heavily armoured damage-soakers. The aliens also bring mechs and robots to the party, as well as more grotesque creatures like the gooey ‘Faceless’ and reptilian ‘Venom’ units. XCOM 2 has gone a long way to make the ADVENT seem both human and alien. Facilities and surroundings will bear all the hallmarks of Earth’s near-future yet be defended by snake-men and dimension-hopping guardians.

As expected your trusty soldiers will gain promotions as they complete missions and kill aliens and like in the XCOM: EU you get to choose one of two skills to unlock. These skills are mostly a new type of attack, but can sometimes be a passive ability like returning fire when attacked or being unable to be hit after killing an enemy the turn before. If you do happen to change your mind, you are now able to retrain abilities using one of the new buildings, the Advanced War Centre, which can also increase the healing down time of injured soldiers,

Combat in XCOM 2 is very similar to the combat from the previous games, each soldier is permitted two actions per turn. These actions can be made up of movements, firing at the enemy, using a grenades, healing or reloading. When you do lay down some sweet guerrilla justice on the alien overlords, there is a chance for loot drops, these can be either weapon upgrades or materials for advanced research. Weapon upgrades are a great addition to XCOM 2, they can add things like increased critical chance, reloads that don’t cost an action or larger ammo clip size and many more.

XCOM 2 has given pretty much every graphical feature in the previous game a polish to update it to modern standards and it goes without saying that the game is flawless in its design and looks. Every battlefield oozes style and really set the scene for your operations against the ADVENT. Soldiers grimace, wince and shout as they fight, while hair, toolkits and weapons sway in convincing ways. Enemy and friendly animations are smooth and detailed - from leaping over barriers to climbing ladders - and I can’t recall any time where my immersion was jarred by clunky movement.

Similarly, composer Tim Wynn has done a fabulous job in creating an epic action-movie feel that accompanies the game. The game’s soundtrack is cinematic in its crescendos and swells and palpably tense when things are going awry. The sound effects are also spot-on: guns crack, rattle and boom while alien mag-weapons make suitably science-fiction pops, zaps and fizzes.

Despite being a fan of the XCOM series as a whole I never expected this new entry to be as polished, intricate, immersive, beautiful and exciting as it is. I’ve had to tear myself away from the screen multiple times because I’d got so invested I’d forgotten to eat. XCOM 2 is one of those titles that appear once in a blue moon and set the benchmark for gaming; from start to finish there wasn’t a moment I did not completely enjoy playing it. XCOM 2 is one of the greatest strategy games of all time.

reviewText:
I really do enjoy XCOM 2 but the bugs and technical glitches are just too much to overlook. I have a 980 Ti and I constantly see frame drops. Kill cams are constantly broken. Aliens are suspended in mid air or teleporting around. But the worst of it all is the game breaking bugs.

After playing Commander/Ironman for 15 hours and constantly getting my butt kicked because I just wasn't good enough I dropped down to Veteran/Ironman. 7 hours in and I'm doing great. No deaths, mag and gauss weapons, predator armor. I'm feeling pretty confident. And then I go on a dark VIP extraction mission and it all goes to hell. A bug treats the mission as failed after I destroyed the VIP's car even though I have him over my shoulder 30 squares away. Then the game calls in reinforcements right on the evac zone in back to back turns. Even though I could have killed them the game treats the zone as overrun and moves it to a place that I can't physically get to in the time left. So that's it. My squad is captured and there is nothing I can do. So my best run is now over and I'm questioning why do I even want to try again when next time something worse could happen 20 hours in.

I'm sure Firaxis is trying to fix these bugs but it is just really disappointing to see a game that was in development for so long and even delayed multiple times is still released in this state. Then again, I guess that is just the norm for video games nowadays.

** UPDATE on February 27th, 2016 **
So I have beaten XCOM 2 on Veteran/Ironman difficulty and it took about 28 hours. I went through the game being much more cautious then in my previous attempts. Sometimes I did not attempt a gorilla ops mission that would have given me the best reward because it had something to do with evac and I just didn't want to risk the game bugging out and me losing a squad again.

While there were a few bugs here and there (enemies suspended in mid air after I destroyed the floor beneath them, somehow triggering pods when I couldn't see the aliens but they could magically see me, kill zone not triggering on enemies that clearly moved, mutons seeing me through a door and throwing a grenade at me) the game was rather uneventful.

The problem I now have with the game is that its difficulty snowballed and didn't push me to experiment with my tactics. Once my soldiers levelled up it was hard not taking them on missions and levelling up replacements because the aliens simply did too much damage. Also my tactic of bring at least two grenadiers (and some soldiers in amor suits with rocket launchers) got boring pretty quick. The problem was whenever I tried to deviate from it by not using my grenadiers or holding them back to the end of the turn I found that I just didn't have the fire power. The game seems really balanced around AoE/shredding damage and killing the aliens before they get any shots on you especially because of the aggressive timers which force you into combat.

The missions also felt more repetitive than XCOM 1. The procedurally generated maps were great. I never really felt that I knew exactly was coming next but the missions were always the same. The guerrilla ops barely changed. The retaliation missions were always the same and you knew exactly when they were coming. The alien facilities were almost identical. The exact same tactics worked on every single one. I was bored my alien facilities by the third one and only did them to lower the avatar project to stall for more time to get supplies. In XCOM 1, looking back with my rose coloured glasses, the randomness of the alien attacks I feel like I enjoyed more. The different types of alien crafts, the landings versus shoot downs, the terror missions which you sometimes didn't see coming.

Also story missions felt better spaced out in XCOM 1. In XCOM 2 I probably went 12 hours between story missions because after the black site there was nothing pushing me on. I literally had taken out every single alien facility on the planet before I attempted a story mission. There was no tech or advancements behind those missions on then the next story mission to eventually get you the final mission.

All of this sounds really negative but I did enjoy a lot of the game.
- The geoscape was great. Tough choices all around. I felt it dragged the game on a little bit because it was hard to get the supplies needed to upgrade everything to tier 3 so I definitely killed time for a month just waiting for attacks because I didn't want to attempt any story missions.
- There definitely were some missions where even with what I feel are my OP tactics of never-ending explosives and mimic bacons I did feel like I was just walking over the aliens.
- The character customization really drew me in. There were so many storylines of all my soldiers and their amazing exploits that are all just inside my head. The ability to customize every character ahead of time and just have them randomly showed up really pulled me in.

On the whole as a die-hard XCOM fan I did enjoy it and I'll probably come back in 2-3 months when some DLC and patches have come out and make my Commander/Ironman attempt. But I am very afraid that I'm just going to have to resort to my same boring tactics again. I'll probably make a couple of attempts at different tactics, maybe rush psionics instead of mag weapons or something but I'm just a bit worried that the game at higher difficulties just isn't balanced for that.

reviewText:
If you planning to buy;
Don’t do it until it has 2-3 hot fix/patch (usually 1-2 month).

If you are an UFO (XCOM) fan i recommend you to buy it, but keep an eye in the 2 hour refund period.

It seems the game was not QA-d or programmers checked it and some bugs got lower priority than is should be and you will encounter them at beginning and in core places. Also feels like marketing pushed the game to hard and let many annoying bug in just to keep release date. Shame for AAA game exclusive for PC.

What need to be worked on:
- Game crashes in various places (example: when you switches area in your ship while someone is talking to you)
- Animation sometime freezes or laggy
- Frame rate drops for no reason multiple times
- Mostly the mission objective needs to be reached under a turn limit which eliminates safe" or "go around/behind enemy" tactic. You need to rush cover from cover in straight line.
- You get mind controlling enemy in first mission while you have just your beginner equipment.
- The grenade is your best friend in early game
- The melee unit is the only unit you need the rest is just nuisance (i hope it will be balanced soon)
- If enemy is in cover you have 32-38-42% hit chance even if you stand next to him behind the cover (like if enemy stand near a wall)
- You can search dead bodies but you wont have time to do it if its died outside of your main path due to turn limit
- At the end of each mission you need to "clear all remaining enemy""

reviewText:
An incredible game worthy of full price, something I have not been able to say about the overwhelming majority of AAA (and otherwise) titles these days.  If you are a fan of turn based strategy combat, and a minor basebuilding overworld that involves an early-mid game frantic pace where you juggle resources and make key decisions, Xcom 2 should be right up your alley.

It improves on almost every facet of the original, though the base building is a little bare bones in comparison, since the nature of this game is quite different and your mothership is your home base so naturally, there are a lot fewer choices to make.  If you played the first one, you will be right at home, nothing is so vastly different that you won't be able to infer what its role or function is.

The story is pretty well done, albeit a little sparse, and towards the end it does feel a little anti-climatic but really Xcom is about having a badass group of marines and the amazing combat.  A gripe many people will have (myself included) will be in regards to the some what questionable RNG that determines the success or failure of your tactics within the game.  When I think of 80-95% chance of success, I think of it as an almost sure thing.  When you miss 4 of those in a row, you begin to really question how accurate the numbers depicted upon the screen are.... but as everyone says Xcom is Xcom, and this is just part of the experience.  You can miss a 95% and you can hit a 20%.  The game isn't without its moments where you'd like to put an axe through your monitor.

Unfortunately, there are definitely some performance issues and bugs/glitches with the current game.  The game, as impressive as it looks, is certainly not what you'd expect to push your gaming rig to its limits, yet your frames will drop inexplicably, mini cutscenes will stutter, and overall you will notice some choppiness.  Where as it's not aggregious for me (GTX980 TI, 16 gb RAM, SSD, I74790k), it still is bothersome that this game isn't running flawlessly.

There is quite a bit of graphical clipping issues, it seems the engine has trouble dealing with structures, walls, doors, windows, and multi-level buildings.  Often your character will stick his gun through a seemingly solid object, or try to smash out a window that is already smashed, walk through a door, be pulled through a building, shot through solid cover, etc.   Where as it is annoying and takes away from immersion, the game is still so robust, deep, and rewarding that I found myself looking past it.  It's just too damn enjoyable to let those things drag down the experience.

One would hope Firaxis is aware and addressing these issues, because once they are fixed, this game is a VERY strong contender for GOTY.   Certainly, this is the best tactical strategy game I've played, and the extensive modding capabilities the game has only means great things when you get guys like the creators of the Long War  working on all manners of new content - for free.

All in all, despite the somewhat unforgivable performance issues of a PC-Exclusive, this game is definitely what I would consider a must-buy for anyone who is a fan of the genre.

9.5/10

reviewText:
Yes, I know, I know I haven't played the game for two centuries, so I'm not allowed to talk about it in public yet. Much less write a review.

I'm giving it a negative review, because all the issues that were raised in reviews haven't been addressed for the launch copy:

* The frame rates drops constantly (my pc is more than good enough to run it) almost constantly from the start of a mission to the end. So much so that it is sometimes impossible to keep up with.
* The camera angles are awful at times, grenades explode off screen before they are due to, walls block the sight entirely, sometimes the alien's move is just a black screen so you have no idea what is going on. You can literally lose a soldier and have no way of knowing how.
* There are excessive short pauses for no reason after actions and during some actions (seemingly at random).
* Sometimes a person's body will be facing the exact opposite direction to where they are shooting.

As well as that, a large number of missions have arbitrary turn limits, which are punishingly short. They only give you enough time to complete a mission comfortably if you rush most of the time. And rely on purely run and gun tactics. It removes any chance or opportunity to actually use strategy and tactics.


Most of these issues will hopefully be addressed with hotfix patchs, and working with the graphic card companies to get out some optimised drivers ASAP. But that doesn't excuse the game being released in this state. If this is the standard quality of a game at launch then this is the last game I'll ever pre-order.

We need to make sure companies know this isn't acceptable or tolerated, or it will just keep happening *Looks at Bethesda*.

I HIGHLY recommend waiting until the performance issues and bugs have been patched before purchasing. Once all the performance problems and bugs have been resolved, and there are plenty of mods to allow people to tweat the turn limit system, this will be an absolutely superb and very worthy sequel to X-Com.

Your squad can only carry so much firepower. Even if a 100 % of your shots hit, sometimes a squad simply does not have the firepower (leave alone the staying power) to move from point A to B to C and dispatch everything that happens to spawn along the way within the turn limit set by the game.

Further into the game, the glaring line of sight bugs also become very annoying. I don't know how often my sniper shot someoe through walls, floors or ceilings on overwatch. Or how often an alien did it on me. I've had entire firefights with all units on both teams exchanging gunfire right through (yet) intact walls.

At this point, the game comes down to save-scumming until you get lucky.

Recommendation: hands off for now, XCOM2 is simply broken in its current state.

reviewText:
Nice Game but Even Fraxis Missed His Shot with 90% Aim.

This is pretty much how I felt the last time I started playing XCOM, way back in 2012, but I’d liken the game more to XCOM’s “Enemy Within” expansion in 2013. A comprehensive update to the gameplay, customization, and flow of the original, “Enemy Within” made XCOM the game it should have been at launch.

XCOM 2 is better. Not only are customization options far more varied even than the expanded XCOM, the game is simply deeper, more challenging, and more fun in almost every way. Still, it’s not without its problems.
Lets take a look at the Good, The Bad, and The Insulting of Firaxis’ ambitious sequel.

The Good-

Customization- I have way too much fun customizing my soldiers. This was severely lacking in XCOM, massively expanded in “Enemy Within” and has reached critical mass in XCOM 2. If you like customization options, they are here in abundance, from language and voice options, to props like sunglasses and baseball caps, to facial hair and scars. When a soldier reaches a certain rank, even more options are opened up

Enemy Variety- Enemy variety is almost overwhelming at times. You learn to tread carefully and start making a kill-priority list very early on

More Tactical- Alongside the increased enemy variety is an increased sense of panic at the rest of the challenges. Whether that’s rescuing civilians, blowing up an enemy base, or getting to an enemy data bank before it self-destructs, there’s often some sort of primary or secondary objective that makes your life even harder

Features- Adding to the tactical flavor are some new game features. Often you start the map out in Concealment mode, and can move through the map unseen by the aliens. This allows you to set up masterful ambushes and take out multiple bogies in one fell swoop.

Swords - Using swords is awesome. Every game should have swords.

The Scenario Makes Way More Sense- Here we had a global effort to fight back against an alien horde, and we were barely able to fund it. And why were so few soldiers taking on these missions? This time around you lead an underground resistance to the aliens and their global domination organization ADVENT. Having limited resources and a small, elite squad makes way more sense.

More Strategic Depth- Alongside more tactical missions, your base of operations and world-map are now way more complex. There’s a consequence for every action, too, which means you’ll probably screw up a lot. Or at least, I screw up a lot, or I think I do.

The Bad-

It’s All A Bit Too Much - You can barely get one thing done without being interrupted a bazillion times by all the various projects you have going, by new missions popping up, or new resource collecting timers going off. Even when you get through a month and the powers-that-be send you your supplies, you have to go spend a few days picking them up. During that time any number of horrible things can happen, and all the while the ADVENT clock is ticking, leading toward some new calamity.

Frankly, it’s just too much going on at once to be enjoyable at times. There’s almost no breathing room, even in the very beginning, and it’s very easy to slid into chaos.

Mental Distress- Let me give example for you: I’ve got my four squad mates lined up just right to take out some bad guys. A dudes is in Overwatch, and the girl I have shooting has an 87% chance of success. Then she misses. My Overwatch dudes miss. Everyone misses and the enemies flank me. One of my squad mates gets hit by an alien with a sword, knocks them unconscious, so they’re out of the game. Then two of my squaddies panic and shoot wildly at nothing. Then a Sectoid takes over the mind of my fourth soldier and I’m out. I can’t do anything. There was nothing I could have done any better, either. I set it all up perfectly. I had a good chance of landing a shot and then taking out at least a couple of the aliens with Overwatch. But because half my squad panicked, one was knocked out, and the other got mind-controlled, I had no options left.
(After this incidence i took a 3 hours nap)

The Insulting-
Repetition- In missions where you have to save civilians, you’re going to lose a bunch of them no matter how good you are. Aliens start picking them off instantly, and it’s a race just to grab the bare minimum. But each time the aliens kill someone, your right-hand man “Central” pops up on the screen to chastise you. “We cant afford to loose too many civilians, Commander!” he intones, or something like that. Many times over. The game pauses while he says his bit, which is really irritating. Stuff like this happens throughout the game. It’s repetitive, slow, and annoying. You should at least be able to play while the NPC’s are dressing you down for being a pathetic loser.

(Whenever Central pops in, I AM LIKE, DUDE STOP IT, I AM YOUR ****ING COMMANDER)

Bugs And Glitches
My character fall of a building and KIA. One time the game just went black. Sometimes animation freezes for an agonizingly long time when Overwatch is triggered, ETCs.

Load Times-
Since this is a PC game, performance will vary by machine. On my POTATO the load times between missions are horrible.
Having i5 4590, gtx960, 8gb ram, game on samsung 850 ssd.

NERFING SUGGESTIONS -

Before your squad levels up, you’re pretty much screwed by anything Will-related. Panic, mind-control, etc.
Enemy can call more than 1 Reinforcement

SO, Should You Purchase This Game.

YES
Once Firaxis patches it up, it’s going to be even better.

I do think balance issues are going to be a turn-off for some gamers, and I definitely feel like the game is less “fair” at the moment than XCOM. That’s something to consider if you’re thinking about purchasing it. But I can forgive most of the flaws simply because there’s no other game quite like this on the market. It’s top of the class when it comes to turn-based tactical gameplay, and I honestly can’t get enough.

reviewText:
I don't know, something about the game feels wrong. Maybe it's the performance issues, maybe it's the 'slower paced' gameplay, or maybe it's the lack of Micheal McCann. I just don't get the same feeling like I do with EU/EW.

Even Long War feels more satisfying, and that ♥♥♥♥ is brutal.

I wanted to be excited for this sequel, and I was for sometime... It feels like it was partially for nothing.

--- Pros so far ---
- Customization is great. Customize guns/people to a higher extent versus EU/EW.
- Graphics are nice. I care more for gameplay though.
- Mod support right outta the box.
- New terrain/landscapes are nice.
- New enemies.

--- Cons so far ---
- No Micheal McCann. His music was the one thing that made me excited going on missions, made me care for Earth's survival, and made me care even more about the soldiers under my command. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=exWNztpgfIw
- Gameplay feels slower versus EU/EW. It feels like I'm forced to watch a soldier finish his/her 3 second animation before I can call my next move. Makes the game feel slower to me. Or maybe that's the performance issues? We'll see by next patch.
- Story is pretty lame. I won't go into it, do to spoilers.... Hopefully it gets better.
- Performance issues. Random stuttering, even on high-end rigs.
- Base building is overally simplified.
- Get to this ♥♥♥♥ing spot in x amount of turns. It's like you don't want me to plan things.
- Some enemies need balancing.

I will never thumbs this up, even if they fixed the performance issues. This is not the xcom I wanted, nor is it the xcom I was told it was.

--- Edit ---

I'm happy there were people who shared my concerns and have decided to 'fix' some of the problem areas of the game. Reminds me of the Skyrim/Fallout modders. At least with mods, I think this game is a bit more playable.

Firaxis strikes again, with a mostly excellent sequel that hits every note bar one.
XCOM 2 is one of those games that gets under your skin. You'll be playing it mentally long after you've finished your session for the evening, you'll be thinking about various strategies long after your first campaign completion too. The fact that this time Firaxis has built modding right into the game client is a real testament to the fact that this XCOM will almost certainly be the one to beat for some time to come, and with it they've made some major steps forward, and a few steps sideways, along with one step backwards. I'll come to that one at the end of the review.

Firstly, let's go over the synopsis. The game assumes that most people failed their first campaign in XCOM:EU (or EW), which is probably correct, and thusly, the governments of the world, having lost faith in XCOM decided to go the route of negotiating for peace with the aliens. On the face of it, this approach worked. The elders" as they're now called

reviewText:
I Can't reccommend this for anyone except die hard Xcom fans desperate for more xcom action. If you're interested in Xcom and havent played the originals, and the reboot, AND long war, don't buy. They bumbled this one.

The bad:
- Baffling gameplay design choices
- A huge system hog for seemingly simple graphics
- A crappy interface, especially for PC (worse than the last xcom!)

The good:
- Combat is still very satisfying. But way more bullet spongey

I don't understand the direction they are taking this series. It truely baffles and confuses me. The last game stripped xcom of all of its deepest (some may say complicated) elements, like soldier stats (which made them individually unique), action points, etc. This one continues to remove the things we love, like the (granted, dumbed down) UFO interception system, but on top of that ADDS a ridiculously convoluted geoscape and base system. What the hell were they THINKING?

There are 400 differnt resources. Its like an Iphone game where you get wood and ore and gold, but you gotta pay 5 dollars for the super special pink crystals! Unless of course you want to wait around with your thumb up your ♥♥♥ for 48 hours.

You run around the map playing a persistant game of wack a mole. But there is always an obvious choice. There is no STRATEGY in this strategy game.

You get to maticulesly place every scientist and engineer, assigning them to various tasks. Cuz why not add some needless, unfullfilling micromanagement to the game?!

You're never really sure what youre acomplishing and why! I need some intel for this, then gotta reseach that, then make contect with this guy then fly over here and pat my head and rub my belly and WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥! How could you make this such a convoluted MESS, yet still say, Players are too stupid for action points! Thats too complicated! No more interceptors

reviewText:
I loved the first one - played through on hard and enjoyed it. This, however, on easy on the first level, I am struggling. 5 attempts so far and no where close to winning.

The aliens seem to have a preternatural ability to hit my soldiers in cover despite when it's my turn they show as having a very low hit point percentage.

One of my soldiers has a mele attack, which, when you use unless you kill your foe in one hit, it leaves them standing next to the alien, which then obviously kills you.

The very first level has a 'grey' which can raise the dead. This would be fine but it takes at least two full barrages from your soldiers, which means you have to put them into harms to way to kill it before the zombie - which also require two kits to kill - can kill your soldiers. And by the way once you fire, that is that's soldiers turn over.

And all this is set against the clock, which means you have to take a lot of risks to get to your objective.

I would not recommend this.  I bloody loved the original, but this is terrible IMO. God knows how it got such good reviews.  Games are supposed to be fun and this just isn't.  Oh and the graphics are distinctly average when compared to the previous game.

My only hope is that I'm rusty at playing xcom, but on easy, 5 attempts in without getting close, come on!

reviewText:
Short Version - XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within are vastly superior to this game. Go buy them instead, or if you have them and want more Firaxis XCOM, install and play the Long War mod.

I wanted to like this game so bad. Hundreds of hours into Enemy Unknown and I was ready and raring to go for the next step. And there are certainly next steps in XCOM 2, the Starting concealment, the changes to Psionics, different enemy types, those were all really good ideas. On the other hand, there's simply too many things that can make your game go sideways through literally no fault of your own. In EU, I usually knew when I made a mistake. Sometimes things go poorly one turn, and that's the way it is, and it usually doesn't happen too often unless you're just committed to riding the bullet train of bad decisions. XCOM 2 just is the bullet train of failure, and there's no brakes on that train.

Barring the DLC, the art is slick and totally on point, a really good iteration of Enemy Unknown's style. Tygen is cool, but lacks the personality and interest of Vahlen. He's 24/7 cool as a cucumber, and is just constantly aloof, where Vahlen had a proper forward face, but there were plenty of hints through dialogue that at any given time she was basically 2 seconds away from dissecting the nearest thing to her, living or dead, while singing opera. Lily Shen's interest basically drops right after her introduction, she never develops even though she's got the most opportunity to do so. On top of that, she looks EXACTLY like Jackie Ma from Sleeping Dogs, right down to the hairdo and freckles, so that's wierd.

The soldier base models are all basically flat, they have zero silhouette and really wierd proportions. Even though there's more customization, somehow it feels more constrained, and I think it's due to there just being less interesting faces and hairdos available.

And, once again (see: Batman: Arkham Knight), XCOM 2 has massive performance issues by trying to ship a next-gen" game on a decade-old engine.

reviewText:
This game alone is enough to make the year 2016 an awesome PC gaming year. What an amazing turn-based strategy game, with a staggering amount of nice character customization (especially with Steam Workshop mods). If you liked XCOM: Enemy Unknown, you will like this even more. If you never played the first one, you will still like this one. With a full mod support from the moment of release, and with the SDK now available, the game will have an extremely high replay value. We already have tons of great mod content, and its only getting better. Highly recommended to any and all friends of turn-based strategy games! If I believed in numeric ranking, this would be a solid 9/10.

Why not 10/10? My personal complaints:
- The game has some serious performance problems: with i7-3770k, 16GB RAM, GTX 970 and played from a 250GB Samsung EVO 850 SSD, @1440p or @1080p and medium/high settings (won't matter much), the game will average to about 35-50fps, will constantly drop below 25fps, sometimes even below 15fps(!). Lowering quality and/or resolution won't help much, so the problem is deep in the game. Holding steady 60fps is very rare.  This must be fixed ASAP! In its current condition, I'd say many gamers will lose their freakin' minds over this.
- late game content seems a bit unstable. I had 3 crashes during the last 4-5 hours of the game.
- EDIT: Stop Wasting My Time mod helps on this. SHUT UP CENTRAL!" mod would be amazing! Im tired of that guy saying the same things over and over again

reviewText:
Performance can be an issue but everything else in the game is an improvement [imo] on the original it is easily recommended; blood, sweat and tears- and i'm only 9hrs into the game- aplenty as you attempt to nurture a fledgling guerrilla force into a truly global resistance network. XCOM2 perfectly captures that feel of 'hit-and-run' partisan style warfare you would expect after twenty years of alien occupation and it is a refreshing change of style and pace over the slow 'overwatch' creep of the first in the series.

Blood: your's or their's, the combat is a mix of satisfying ambushes (thanks to the excellent 'concealment' mechanic), frantic tactical movement and complete RNG failure [see Tears].

Sweat: as the turn counter ticks down, you'll attempt to navigate the quickest and most effective route to the primary objective engaging in tense and at times frustrating [see Blood] firefights against alien pods after an initial ambush seeking every tactical advantage you can.

Tears: your soldiers, veterans and rookies alike, lovingly crafted and kitted out in the excellent customisation/loudout screens, will die. Retirement isn't an option.

reviewText:
I'm done.

While I was looking forward to the sequal this game apparantly is designed to break you before you even get out of the tutorial stage. It was clearly designed for those who have played Enemy Unknown on Classic and have their game down to a science. It is VERY newcomer unfriendly.

I was happily enjoying the game until it started hitting me with missions while was in the VERY LONG process of trying to accomplish any of the supply pickups. I hadn't even made contact with my first new outpost when the game started hitting me with different alien types that started shredding me apart with myself unable to counter attack with nothing but a squad of nothing but rookies, and very low ranking specialists.

Almost ALL the missions are on timers requiring you to play VERY AGGRESSILY in order to feel as though you're accomplishing anything. Anyone who's played XCOM will tell you that playing with that level of aggression with low level specialists and rookies is pure suicide. Failing the objectives will cause a swift decline in your ability to fight back effectively ending your game before you even make it out of the tutorial stage.

Speaking of the Tutorial Stage. I feel as though Firaxes was trying to push too much too quickly. I was quickly beaten and destroyed on my very first mission when they brought in a Sectoid. My rookies were unprepared to combat such a high level enemy (on the very first mission no less) with their woefully underdeveloped weapons and armor. If anything the aliens represent a mid-game threat and their number rapidly increase to the point where you're facing down packs of mid-game enemies and you haven't even completed your first major objective when the game gets done hand holding you.

A lot of the missions I tried to ignore in favor of picking up more supplies but the game kept telling me No. This is a high priority mission. You shouldn't skip this." With each one throwing a new objective at me. I hadn't even had time to catch my breath and consider how to accomplish the last objective better before I had a new feature to contend with. Again I feel that Firaxes is rushing the progressing trying to show me all the cool new stuff they've done. "Oh look at this new alien! See what it can do! Look at this new objective! You've never done this before have you? Look a new way to play!" Dear god can I just catch my breath and consider how my last mission went first?

Enemy Unknown (and Enemy Within) were much better at letting you get comfortable before throwing something new at you. You were just uncomfortable enough until you got toward the endgame and you were a much more equal footting. XCOM 2 is dedicated to smashing you flat until a mountain of new feature after new feature until you finally lose or just give up out of sheer frustration.

I get they wanted to make it like a resistance game where you were hounded at every turn but this game dooms you from the start. And I was playing on Normal Mode. It felt like playing on Classic from Enemy Unknown.

It's fun for all of about 3 hours. Then the inability to pick up resources because of constantly running missions demanding your attention because they have some new feature to show you cause you to hit a brick wall very quickly.

"Oh but Adhock that the point of the game! You have to make the hard choices!"

What hard choices? The choice of ether losing the game because of the inability to stop alien progression while I'm trying to ensure I'm relatively stocked up enough to advance my gear or let myself get smashed flat trying to keep the aliens from advancing their endgame causing me to loose all my soldier with the inability to gear them or get more because I'm too poor?

It's a lose-lose situation ether way. It takes too long to get supplies and they hit with higher tier enemies that should be saved for further in the game. I was expecting to clash with Advent Basic soldiers much like EU Sectoid until I made myself enough of a pain the aliens would respond in force with their bigger and badder units.

Apparantly ADVENT doesn't have enough troops that the aliens feel the need to come out swinging harder then they should instead of letting ADVENT troops do their jobs before taking matters into their own hands when you prove too tough for them. Look at a lot of the gameplay videos. Most of the spawns are basic ADVENT soldiers and their counterparts with perhaps one to two aliens per map. I'm getting hammered with four or five aliens right out the starting gate.

And don't even get me started on concealment.
