reviewText:
Read Full in depth review and my tips on DVS Gaming[dvsgaming.org] that includes a lot more details.

Looking at the gameplay a lot of it will seem familiar to XCOM players, especially if you’ve played XCOM Enemy Within. The interface is nearly the same and so are the mission styles and there is so much new stuff added on top of the old. As always you have a squad of soldiers ranging from 4-6 people to clear every mission.

Every soldier will have one of 4 classes that then goes into another 2 types of subclasses, so even though that sounds very limited compared to The Long War mod it still provides for a lot of unique and great combos.

XCOM 2 brings a lot of uniqueness to the things it had already in the previous game and therefore keeps it fresh and new enough for it to be a sequel instead of a huge upgrade/expansion of Enemy Within.

XCOM 2 picks up the story 20 years after the events in Enemy Within. The guys from the former game have been busy trying to rebuild the XCOM project and rebuilding the base. So here you are in the middle of a world where aliens are the masters and humans are the slaves marked as renegades, fighting in the shadows to save the world from the aliens’ newest project codenamed Avatar.

You’ve recovered an alien ship that you are using as a mobile base of operations, unlike Enemy Within, and you are flying around the entire world map gathering supplies, building contacts, gathering intel and much more. As the game goes on you can expand the ship with more rooms in the same way you could in the old XCOM base from previous games. You can also build and discover unique things across the world map that can make fighting the aliens a lot easier.

You will need to build contacts with the resistance in every country to expand your operational area and to receive more supplies to rebuild your army. This creates a great way of dealing with research, upgrades, buildings and much more in a great flow that can be boosted by completing unique missions and picking up loot drops on missions that can now FINALLY be performed by your soldiers without them having to spend a year researching it.

To explain that statement a bit, when you kill an enemy you have a chance that they will drop a loot item that can be anything from a weapon upgrade to PSI implants that will be usable if you collect them during the mission and then complete the mission. Weapon and PSI implants aren’t the only upgrades to be found. There are also ammo upgrades, grenade upgrades, soldier upgrades, armor upgrades and more. The combination of the level of customization available for each character and the number of possible upgrades makes for a level of overall customizability that rivals that of the Sims Universe. (You can’t dress up as Batman yet though, but give it time. Somebody will make a mod for that.)

Recruitment in XCOM 2 is different from Enemy Within. In Enemy Within you just recived a group of random recruits and and were cut loose. In XCOM 2 you can pick your own recruits to start with from a long roster and then when you’re unlocked a certain room (trying hard to avoid spoilers) you can train them into certain classes to avoid the dreaded rookie stage. While this is a relatively minor change, it really makes your recruits and soldiers feel very much like your own people.

As if all this wasn’t enough, Firaxis has brought out some truly scary aliens to woop our asses this time around. Everything from small creepy things to insanely huge monstrosities that make you wanna run home and cry. You get a great feeling for the difference between every alien and you will be able to tell them apart easily to know which you can shoot at and which you should just blow up with the biggest weapon you have.

All in all a great experience that will make you scream, cry and laugh as you slaughter your way through aliens to save the planet.

reviewText:
Going to be my first review on Steam, and sadly I can't make it a good one.

I absolutely loved XCOM EU across PC and consoles and was really excited for this, but like other reviewers I encountered far too many bugs to fully enjoy the game.

Specifically:

- Terrible FPS no matter what settings
- Game breaking glitches with objectives not allowing me to 'activate' them numerous times (this ruined an iron man run mid-game)
- Animations not working (Seems to be triggered by soldiers falling through a ceiling after an explosion)
- Important effects not appearing (AOE attacks from enemies especially had no area markers so I had no idea where was safe on my next turn)
- Ocasionally had a totally unresponsive game (Not frozen, but not reacting to any commands)
- Soldier perk bugs including the game becoming unresponsive when I used combinations of abilities, but was 'fixable' by skipping my turn in that case... I lost a lot of soldiers that way!
- Broken/buggy action cam; The game would often zoom to a seemingly random part of the map while a soldier took an overwatch shot, for example
- Moves taking up to & around 20 seconds to register as complete

It goes on and on. Definitely avoid this game for some time. I took a chance pre-ordering after promising myself that Arkham knight would be my last, because I loved the previous XCOM.
To make matters worse I went away for a week just after the game came out, and was looking forward to a patch when I got back - I came home to a hotfix that made things noticably worse and at the time of writing there is still no patch three weeks after release.

Another one for the VERY long list of broken/lazy releases over the last year :(

(Playing with an OC'd i74770K and a GeForce 980ti)

EDIT: I've been playing the game more since the patch and am happy to say that it has resolved almost all of my issues - The game looks, plays and runs SO much better.
I'm not going to change this to a positive review, since clearly the game was not ready for release and I'm pretty tired of these non-stop sloppy releases. But, I'd be happy to recommend this to XCOM fans now - minus a few questionable design choices it's a solid game at last!

reviewText:
XCOM 2 improves on EU in almost every way. The core gameplay is of course very simmilar but all of the changes lead to a much fresher feeling game. The classes each feel uniquely powerful and, for better or for worse, almost all of the enemies from EU have been buffed. Things like the buffs from hacking (speed boosts, invulnerability, etc.) add an enjoyable amount of manuverability in basic combat.

However,

This game runs like utter trash. It's an absolute slideshow while navigating between the ship and the map. Load times are sluggish and painful. Bugs are very frequent and as a result anyone who wants to play iron man with the chance that their campaign could break at any moment is a crazy person.

When they finally whip out the carnuba wax and finish polishing their game I can reccomend it. Until then hands off.

EDIT
-Specs-
OS:       Win 10
CPU:     i5 4570 3.2 GHz
Ram:     8 GB DDR3
GPU:     GTX 770

The in game settings were a custom set somewhere below medium. Ambient Occlusion, AA and the extras were all disabled. From that alone transitions would occasionally slow to <1FPS while generally being <7FPS.

For anyone still interested I would highly reccomend following this guide. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=616682629
With an emphasis on adjusting poolsize (my VRAM cache was a useless default value of 10MB) and threadedshadercompilethreshold to values that actually reflect your system.

FPS is now generally 60 while dipping down to 25 for some transitions.

reviewText:
This game once again vindicates my resolution to never buy a game at release. I made the mistake of not holding to that with XCOM 2 because I loved the predecessor so much and I promptly got punished for it.

In short, XCOM  2 is a great game which improves on XCOM in multiple small ways so if you liked the first one, you will probably LOVE the second.

BUT it has so many bugs and technical problems atm that imo it should not had been released when it did. None of the bugs I encountered was game breaking, but there are so many small annoyances mounting up that I almost put it away on multiple occasions out of sheer exasperation.

The game is still great, don't you believe otherwise. But if you successfully avoided the preorder trap, wait a little longer until they have all (or at least most of) the bugs fixed. You'll get a much less tarnished experience and will enjoy the game a lot more without minutes long loading times, clipping errors, sound cutting out etc.

I am sorry to say, I cannot reccommend buying this game at this point in time.

Edit: Rejoice, for I have been shown the way. I has been made clear to me, that I wrote my review in blatant disregard of the intellectually challenged of our esteemed colleagues out there. But fear not! You just have the one braincell and nothing to rub it against to make it spark? I will take you through it step by step.

Since you read this review, I am assuming that you have not yet bought the game. If you did, what are you doing here? Go play it, it is a good game!

I spent a three digit number of hours in this game, yes. Did I enjoy that time? Yes.... mostly. But I spent almost double that amount on XCOM and far less moments where I wanted to punch through my screen and exactly zero minutes contemplating a critical review.

So assuming you did NOT buy the game yet. From the top of my mind, there are two reasons I can think of why.

A) You desperately want it, but are broke. And while scrounging the money together, you amuse yourself by reading about how good this game is, trampling its enemies into the dust, grinding their bones for your bread and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on their graves. Yay you! Good for you, everybody needs a hobby, I guess.

B) You wanted to see if the game is worth your money and your time. For you, I wrote this review. Is the game worth it?

That depends, do you want a really good game (yes it IS good as my hours can easily testify, even if you subtract the idling time) NOW? Or do you want a great game in about half a year (where realistically at least a few bugs will have been worked out and it will probably have already been on a first 10% sale)?

Chocolate bar now or tub of ice cream later? What I am saying here is that in retrospect, I should have waited for the ice cream. But hey, it's your decision in the end.

Still not getting my point? Go pester your mom, she (hopefully) can explain it to you.

Pros

reviewText:
If you enjoyed any of the previous XCOM games, don't read any further - just play this game!

Amazing turn based gameplay. Complex and deep customisation/progression of your squad and base.

Graphics are lush. I had it all the way up on ultra on my GTX970 and it played well until there were a lot of characters on screen at once and that's when the close up view of shots/reaction fire slowed down. I used the NVidia recommended settings which dropped a few things down slightly like the anti aliasing and to be honest I can't tell the difference and it runs smooth as f*** now.

Some people don't like that some maps have a timer (not always a turn countdown). I didn't like the sound of it before in played and now after 40+ hours I can say it actually makes the game better. It changes up your approach and the gameplay and keeps the game fresh after and makes you the better tactician as you have to fully understand your squad and the battlefield. There is an overarching 'countdown' but it hasn't been a problem, again just adds to the overall game.

I haven't completed this game yet but I still give it a 10/10 and name it as my PC game of 2016 so far!

Seriously sweet.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game.  It's no longer a strategy game, just a race against XCOM's legendary rage-inducing RNG.

There's so much here to build on, and that's part of that makes this so disappointing.  There's a great stealth mechanic...that you can't use because of the turn timer, so you blow it on the opening group of enemies you see.  It's neat, fun to play with for a few (failed) missions, then you leave it alone because the turn timer invalidates a piece of great design.

There's awesome classes with neat abilities...except sharpshooters are worthless since using them like the sniper they're supposed to be means that you lose them when the evac timer runs out.  Once again, the turn timer invalidates another piece of some really good class/game design.

You could always counter the whims of the RNG in XCOM: EU/EW by playing safe with overwatch and setting up a good sniper position, and you can see the design intent to stop that with the turn timer.  But that turn timer coupled with the whimsical RNG turns the game from a series of interesting decisions" into a series of bad ones and worse ones.

It's really close to being the GOTY candidate so many reviewers are making it out to be.  But without a balance pass

reviewText: There are a lot of improvements on this game that could make it more enjoyable than XCOM enemy unknown. Character custimization, weapon mods, melee combat, stealth mode and a cool story line for example.  However, the addition of so many timed missions completely ruin the game for me.  I really enjoyed xcom enemy unkown's turn based tactical shooting style and expected the same from this game. Every move of every turn required planning, for both that character and the squad as a whole.  Having a strategy to tackle the mission was essential along with the ability to adapt to unkown enemies that you didn't see.   Instead, the timed missions of XCOM 2, which seem to make up the overwhelming majority of missions, force you to play a blitz style game.  Your only option is to make the shortest route possible to the mission objective in which you are forced to make long range movement, puting your characters into positions of disadvantage, and efffectively removing any type of tactical strategy from the game.  Let me be clear, my complaint isn't that the game is too hard, it's that the developer's have completely and utterly changed the game from a tactical shooter to a run and gun style game that i think they hope will compete with the more fast paced first person shooters. All in an effort to attract a new generation of 12 year olds who don't have the attention span to enjoy anything but a call of duty style game.\nThe rushed gameplay style ruins any other good aspect of this game.  I strongly reccomend you spend your money on somehting else, I wish i had.

reviewText:
It is unacceptable to release a AAA game in such a buggy and unoptimized state. Is it playable? Sure. However, the constant slowdowns (even at reduced graphics settings), animation bugs, floating heads (armor doesnt load on background characters), and camera bugs definitly take away from the experience.

It is very clear to me that the publisher said screw the polish, just release it. It's been several days now and still no patch to fix any of these issues. $60-$75 for what? A bunch of reused assets on a three year old engine? AND it doesnt run perfectly? Thats what really bothers me.

Is XCOM2 better than the last one? Yeah, the game mechanics fit the setting a lot better. The world map is more interesting, even though it just feels like im playing a cheap board game. Is it worth the price they are asking? sadly, no. I should not have bought this, you'd be better served just waiting for the 'complete' version for 10 bucks. If you are lucky, by then it'll run properly.

Update:
Still no patch... finished the game regardless. Spoilers ahead, you've been warned: I have to say i'm all around a bit dissapointed with the story. It's so linear, nothing interesting happens, no betrayals even if the side commentary keeps hinting at certain characters not being trustworthy. No twists. The idea of the Avatar project feels ripped off from mass effect2. Then it all ends with an episode of dragon ball. I have to wonder, did they not hire any writers? Did they let the intern write the story? I'm thinkin so.

Update2:
So it's been about a month, and still no 'real' patch from the devs. Game is still a mess, and they've done a good job here making me regret supporting one of my favorite franchises. Pathetic.

Update3:
Finally a patch. While it does fix some issues and speed up the game play, it also lowers the gfx. Can't seem to re-enable them either, game is noticeably uglier. Pretty lazy, clearly they didn't want to spend time to optimize the game engine and just nerfed it instead. Still Pathetic.

reviewText:
Better than the previous 'new' XCOM but obviously there are plenty of issues in game mechanics. The enemies still know when you see them and the ridiculous reaction move is still in place. The cover system is pretty much as bad as it was in the previous game and even though many guns shoot bursts it can always count only as a single attack. Also you apparently can't hit wrong enemies by accident. Corpse reanimation via psi powers is an instant action and seemingly requires noi 'maintenance' by the the one doing the resurrection. Also all reinforcement actions are poorly 'translated' into turn based environments. At times when you look all the things that happen you can safely say your team is having a nap while the enemies do strange chains of actions.

So in essence this game pretty much has all the flaws I expected it to have and for now I haven't seen that many improvements over the last version. There are some small tweaks in functionality but for now I have completed only a couple of missions so there are still plenty of things to discover.

Is the game currently worth the full price? No, not really. I suppose some issues may get an official fix and mods will probably fix some others so this game has a fair potential. Even as it is the game seems to be reasonably enjoyable but the actual game mechanics seem to be on par with the most simple board games ever created.

Edit: Started out with a recommendation but now that I have played more the game just feels so unbelievably scripted. Ammo clips also don't last very long as these 'soldiers' spray and pray all the time. There are no single shots for most weapons, meaning that even your more senior officers will act like total rookies to the end of time. Also movement rate for everything is far too great compared with the other things you can do. Also firing a weapon ends the turn for that soldier. You can run before moving if you like but you can't do it the other way around. This game getting over 90 points is just ridiculous and 80 would be a far more accurate.

reviewText:
There's a lot of good here that's let down by the short turn timers and buggy gameplay. Hustling into poorly set up engagements because preparing properly takes too long isn't particularly satisfying, and the solution - especially in Retaliation missions where you need to get to 6 civilians that are often rather far away from you before they're killed - is primarily to have enough firepower to not get bogged down in combat for too many turns. Actually outmaneuvering the aliens to success is largely too slow to consistently beat the timer. I preferred the risk/reward decision-making of collecting Meld in Enemy Within over this ham-fisted way to always force aggression.

The deal breaker for me is however the bugs. Dealing with glitchy cutscenes, random black screens on enemy reveal, getting shot through solid floors, UI that completely locks up, and combat turns that just get stuck and never end was trying, but I've finally given up after the timers on the strategic map started counting past 0 into the negatives, preventing further progress.

I want to love this game, but it doesn't seem to want to love me back.

reviewText:
*Sigh* Alright, I'm not gonna lie; I really tried to like this game but in truth, given it's current state it's near impossible to get my head around it. I only had to play the first TWO missions to realise that the balancing in this game will make it a perpetual nightmare. However, with that said I do want to cover the good things about it as well; so let's take a look at that first.

The game's tactical combat is still very solid for the most part: it's very comprehensive and you understand in a near-instant, so if you haven't played Enemy Unknown, you needn't worry too much. The pace of the game has certainly been upped a bit; Enemy Unknown was a bit more slow-paced: it pretty much needed you to complete the mission incredibly carefully and it required you to take a step back and analyze everything before acting. While this game is very similar in that regard, it seems as though it's more likely for someone to act on impulse in some circumstances. (It was certainly the case with me anyway.) But now that I look back on it... that's kind of the only thing that I can commend it for thus far honestly.

One of the main problems with the game is it's balancing, or the complete lack thereof. Allow me to explain, when you start off with the tutorial you face of against ADVENT soldiers whom are essentially the Sectoids of XCOM 2: they're pretty much the grunts of the game through and through.

Now I can imagine (if you've played Enemy Unknown) you'd think the game would have paced itself properly so that you can deal with them for a few missions, get yourself some better equipment and the like and the game will steadily progress and gradually increase in difficulty. Well, Firaxis decided to give that oh-so mad notion the middle finger and instead gives you enemies to fight that you would expect to see mid-game: the new Sectoids; whom are much stronger and have highly advanced Psionic abilities: such as reanimating their fallen allies, disorienting soldiers and mind-controlling them! In the second mission, where you will have ONE squaddie and THREE rookies!

Not to mention, Firaxis decided to take a couple of steps back and even simplify the game in some respects. As the Second Wave options from Enemy Unknown are no longer present, which is a huge mystery to me.

The Second Wave options were a great way to add a little more unpredictability to what happened throughout the missions and on some occasions could be fantastic lifesavers if you implemented one of the options. (Such as that Aim Roulette one. I forget it's name.) Why it is Firaxis removed it is nonsensical, as it added a lot more tension depending on the circumstances, and would make the players have to think much more critically about whether a risk was worth taking or not.

Unfortunately, that's all I need to say; this severe lack of pacing BREAKS the game straight from the get-go: unless you are a seasoned veteran of XCOM you really aren't gonna have a good time with this one. Now, I can understand why Firaxis wanted to go through with this particular idea; XCOM isn't as powerful as it was in Enemy Unknown, they're now guerrilas against a near-indominable empire. And as such there will be a lot more tribulations for them to face than before, thus they make the game a bit more challenging by making the enemies more powerful than before and more tactical, I appreciate that idea. But at least give the players a chance to meld in with the game before you start raining meteors on them in order for them to be blasted to dust! And with the lack of Second Wave, no matter how many times you try and re-load your save and see if you can do better, everything will be down to the same formula no matter what, meaning that you would have to start the mission from scratch if you want to do if flawlessly.

Not to mention, as many people have mentioned, there is a turn-based time limit for some of the missions, and that begs the question: why?! Now, granted yes Enemy Unknown did a similar thing with it's bomb disposal mission, but 1. those missions were very uncommon so you didn't have to worry about them too much for them to be pressing. 2. They allowed you to at least extend the amount of time you have so you can approach it much more calmly.

XCOM 2's spin on it is that you're given a certain amount of turns and that's it; meaning you have to brazenly charge into the battle without thinking, and not being able to analyze what in the blue hell is going on. This is NOT what you put into a turn-based STRATEGY game! I cannot stress enough how important it is for a game like this to allow players to take to it with a logical and sensible approach to avoid casualities, and deal with enemies with utmost efficiency. This mechanic completely contradicts the idea of a turn-based strategy game: as you just have to charge in as quickly as possible, thus attracting more enemies to you and then winding up with more hassle than your team can cope with. At least there is a mod that allows you to disable that, but it's only for non-story missions. But regardless, I have to give that son of a gun a HUGE thumbs up for that one.

Now, while the premise of this game points to it being an understandable mechanic to implement, that doesn't mean they could have used it more reasonably. This is something that should be used in critical situations, if the enemy were able to call in reinforcements, then the timer would be a clever idea; for if they cleared the enemies in time, then the timer wouldn't be too much of an issue. Instead of being a mandatory implementation, it should have been a circumstantial happening when the enemy decides to try and pull a trump card. That way, it would be rewarding to the player if they could deal with it effectively, and the tension would rise dramatically since it could be an unpredictable happenstance; if you're gonna include a timer in a strategy game, do something like that and DON'T make it a key feature in the missions.

Now I know SOMEBODY out there is gonna say well if you've got such better ideas

Let me start off by saying that I loved XCOM: Enemy Unknown. So much that I played through the entire game twice. When XCOM 2 came out I was really excited about it. But after having played 8 hours of the game and have won maybe 3 out of 15 encounters I gotta say, I'm really disappointed.

It's not that I don't mind a challenge, in fact I was hoping this game would be slightly MORE challenging than Enemy Unknown, but this game is more than just challenging. This game is, for lack of a better term, ridiculously cheap. You've got enemies that can run for what seems like half the map and one shot your soldiers. You've got insanely overpowered enemies that swarm you from all sides early on in the game, before you have any time to research new technologies and have half a chance at winning. You've got multiple enemy types that can incapacitate your soldiers for multiple turns/the rest of the match. So you basically go into every battle with 2 guys you're just sacrificing to the enemy no matter what, and then left with 2 other grunts to try and fight 8 overpowered, cheap, enemies. And, you have a lot of missions with turn limits, which ruins any chance you have to set up any ambushes, and ruins any chance of you having any sort or tactical advantage at all.

Solid improvement over XCOM EU/EW. I really enjoyed the change of pace and base management. A lot of the systems they changed felt like an improvement too. Offers a lot of replayability and character creation is a time sink as always.

Yes performance is sluggish if you don't meet minimum requirements (and trust me, a GTX 560 is bare minimum at 1080p), but turning down the graphics settings will improve things (obviously).  Definitely use a 2GB graphics card which is faster than a GTX 560. Running full screen seems to improve CPU load balance, but then I already have a fast CPU (i5 4690K) so it doesn't make much difference to me.

It's an unqualified recommendation if you meet the system requirements.

reviewText:
EDIT: Comments and further research have shown that whether or not the game runs fluently has less to do with the power of your PC but hardware lottery. Some people with terrible machines have it run just fine, while others with beastly monstrosities have experienced all sorts of issues. There seem to be a lot more people with problems than without, so you may not even be able to have this game run fluently if you do have a supercomputer.

ATTENTION: If you work at NASA or have access to the computing power of IBM's WATSON, you will find this to be a fantastic game. Otherwise, you will have big problems with performance where there should be none, not to mention the fact that this game is buggier than a square kilometre of the Amazon rainforest.

XCOM 2 is, gamewise, a worthy successor to XCOM. It may not feature the full range of contents yet, and the story is a ♥♥♥♥ poor as you'd expect, but if you bought this expecting something on par with Mass Effect, you should not have. XCOM is about shooting aliens, machines, and alien-human hybrids (seeing as the players cannot be expected to simply be fighting human soldiers who have threwn their lot in with the alien overlords), and if good turn-based tactics and moments of euphoria followed by indomitable rage are what you're into, this game is for you.

Sadly, it seems Firaxis somehow managed to do many of the things it did right terribly wrong. Yes, there is full modding support (as in: the tools the devs had, we had available on day 1), but the documentation on it is spotty at best. The character pool was a great idea, but it turned out to be an unweildy and unecessarily complicated feature. Not saying you wont get the hang of it, but once the ranger guy you carefully worked out to be an insane brute becomes a specialist because the game refuses to use the class you specified you'll be quite mad, I assure you.

This is also one of the better sides of the game: the mods. The community is already hard at work, and some fantastic groundwork has been laid out, so you can be sure great things will follow. Firaxis loves the modders already, and maybe that is because they hope they can figure out a way to improve the horrendous performance, but the encouragement people are getting can only be rivalled by Bethesda. And seeing as EVERYTHING is moddable, workarounds for everything you don't like about the game will be available soon enough.

Still, I cannot recommend the game in its current state. Wait until they fixed the performance and the modding scene is a little bigger, and this will be well worth your money.

reviewText:
I just can't recommend this game. I'm a long term fan of the franchise with 100+ hours in EU. XCOM2 just fights me at every turn. It's more frustrating than fun. The difficulty seems moreso frontloaded than XCOM is known for, so I'm not entirely sure this game is for newcomers to the franchise either.

I sat back and asked myself, was I having fun playing this game? Not much fun to be had in getting punished for playing honestly without reloading in the form of post-combat debuffs (gravely wounded for 5/7 hp? sure, thanks for that). XCOM2 feels like it just devolves into reloading the last save (which takes a bit) until you get the desired result.

I usually enjoy difficulty and challenge (granted this example is cross-genre, but Bloodborne is one of my top 5 favorite titles of all time) but XCOM2 feels contrived and frustrating. I don't get any satisfaction after overcoming a level, instead I found myself breathing a sigh of relief that I was just done with the mission.

I'm sure there's fun to be had here; it's just not for me.

At the moment, I really can't recommend this game. Especially not when compared to XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Enemy Within which is one of my all time favorite games.

reviewText: I loved the last XCOM game to bits and XCOM 2 was supposed to be an improvement in every aspect. Instead, it's the most frustrating game I've played in recent years. Unless you play games for a living, playing XCOM 2 for maybe an hour every day will lead to nothing but frustration and resentment. Why? Because even on normal difficulty the odds are stacked against you at all times, to the point where it becomes grueling. Once you're a couple of hours into the game you will have to scum save every move in order to make it through the mission by reloading it 15 times. There is not a single mission where the balance is not one step away from being completely out of whack. Move one tile too far and you will aggro another - previously invisible - enemy squad that can tear your group apart in a single turn.  With the over-abundance of escalating missions and the timing constraints added as a new ‘feature', strategic depth is simply AWOL in this game. Only rarely are you given the time to set up your units or prepare an ambush. If you don’t like trial & error games where missions randomly go south, you should avoid this game.\n\nOn the plus side, the graphics are much better (albeit laggy most of the time) and the controls have been improved a lot.

reviewText:
Xcom 2 retains most of the same formula as its previous game except this time they added more, The enemies are stronger, tougher, and smarter and made missions much more faster paced. Humanity
has new ways to fight from new technology to even strategy on the field. Xcom is even more bad ♥♥♥ than before and adds so much more. It starts off a bit hard, gets harder and then pisses you off if you've made the wrong choices or just bad but still a good game.

Video Review https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SqACDr286F0

Graphics The graphics is improved in this version of the game while still using the same engine and a beefier pc is needed to run it although it isn't drop dead gorgeous it still looks very good. At the same time there are some performance issues for the game even for me running a Titan and higher end processor but it is minuscule and the situation seems like it can be fixed via patches.
The environment is more detailed and come in many different varieties all over the world towns, cities, snow, rain, sand etc.

Sounds and music New alien sounds and voice acting in the game along with some returning familiar voices. The guns sounds great and new alien devices just blows your eardrums with its creative sci fi fx along with thier speeches. Accompanying this are also some great voice acting which goes does a really great job for the story. The music pieces for this game is phenomenal and gets your adrenaline going.

StorylineThe story is much more action packed this time around and explosive along with time sensative missions. Most of the game is accompanied by cut-scenes but there are also in game chatter between characters to let players understand the lore and situation of what has has been happening to the world in the past years. There are also archives and logs players can go through
to discover and read to obtain more insights. The aliens are up to something but what exactly play it and fondle thier plans.

GameplayThe game pretty much follows the same formula from the previous Xcom game except the r.n.g the game (Random number generator) during shots seems alot more improved (Sorta LOL)_. You can still of course miss shots at 40% or even 50% but it doesn't happen ALL THE DAMN TIME! Although 80% chance to shoot in the face can still miss lol.
Along with the returning gameplay there is more strategy and the action is faster paced since there are many missions which are turn sensative (many of them). The new concealment system helps player plan ambushes on the battlefield and also strategize ambush attacks
on the aliens before they can react along with new devices to scout, technology to upgrade, guns, armors and even environment hacking  to buff your units or debuff enemies  for a better chance to fight back.
There are also plenty of new class promotions, skills and load out for characters. The enemies this time are tougher, harder and even more annoying. They will bind you, poison you, shoot lasers at you, mind control you,teleport around you, aoe you, blow you up and kick your teeth in, thankfully you can retaliate.
Everything is randomized as usual even your start location so you don't really know whats going to happen as you play the game because your planning on resources will have to be appropriate for the counter. Sometimes it can start out smooth or harsh but it all depends on what you invest in and your choice.

Pros + Graphics looks much better maxed out on the pc.
+ Much of the same formula and gameplay, improved rng
+ environmental destruction improvement adds so much to the strategy including grounds building floors blowing up which can create win conditions.
+ New Concealment system, More weapons, technology and loadout and class trees with stats to help in the battle against the aliens.
+ Emphasis on the base building of choices you can invest in to get stronger. The choice is yours but the wrong investment can spell your downfall. Go for Supplies? More scientists? Engineers? or keep attacking?
+ Your base is now a badass mothership, and even called avengers at times I thought it was the avenger ship
+ Randomized missions and more side missions, the aliens COUNTER ATTACKS this time too.
+ Many new types of alien enemies and they look damn good. They'll knock you around like pebbles.
+ Multiplayer with ranks, quickmatches and custom games.
+ Mods support
+ Close your windows, shut your doors, hundreds of hours galore

Cons - Some performance issue in certain areas and a bit of stutter/fps drops (miniscule such as loadout and lifting off) - hopefully they patch this up!
- Some graphic clippings, enemy clipping walls, you making wierd shots, invisible guns but miniscule things due to engine.
- even though the rng is better a bit with the new buff skills, you can still miss an enemy while standing in thier face with 80% chance of shot lol.
- Most missions have move times, its super rough if you aren't fast. This can ♥♥♥♥ off some slow people who can't react to the pace that wants to take thier time. Recommended for you is easy so don't play veteran
- Camera during the attacks can be a bit wonky aims at wierd places which can throw view off a bit.
- The chatting between characters can cut off quick if you press a button on the menu too soon on the ships before you can listen in on them or sometimes it overlaps other voices.

- Can't think of anything else
- Oh god they're taking over my mind
- I can't move
- must.... call... for... help... xcom.... mayday

reviewText: It really breaks my heart having to write this review to not recommend this game with flying colors. I am a big fan of the franchise and a big fan of the previous game, enemy unknown/within. XCOM 2 was probably the one game that I looked foward to playing in 2016. I was more excited about this game than any other AAA games or indie games that are coming out this year. It is sad to say that the game did not live up to my expecation at launch. I say this because the core premise of the gameplay is good, but the technical aspect of the game is horrible. The peformance and bugs that came with release of this game can rival that of Batman Arkham Knight and Assassin Creed Unity at launch. What really gets to me is that this is a PC exlusive game, so it should have beeen the game that comes out the most polished on the PC platform in this current generation and the graphics in this game are good but not mindblowing to a point where gtx 970 should not be getting 20fps in sideview of your avenger base. It is hard to defend this game base on optimization and bugs because the game have been delayed so the developers have ample amount of time to fix the performance and bugs reported from the review copies of the game. Aside from the technical problems, I really enjoy playing this game because it is XCOM at heart. If you are new to the franchise I recommend waiting until hotfix or performance patch have been rolled out. I would glady change my review when technical problems have been solve by patches but I feel like performance wise this is the best we are going to get. I am not hoping to see major performance upgrade from patches because the peformance problem may tied in to their heavy tinkering with the Unreal Engine 3. I hope they prove me wrong.

reviewText:
I honestly want to know what version of the game the highlighted reviewers above were playing. I would swear it's different from the one that got downloaded to my system.

Serious balance issues, buggy, performance is really below where it should be. With graphics turned all the way down, or all the way up, it still chugs and lags so bad on my system that I can hardly play. Delivers the same frustrations as the previous game with little of the novelty. Enemy reinforcements are frequent and punishing, even on lower difficulty levels. Overpowered enemy units show up early in campaign and make some required missions nearly impossible to complete. You will run out of soldiers frequently through attrition or when everybody is in sickbay for a month.

EVERYTHING has a time limit, or a timer, or a progress bar, or some hidden event that will push you to the brink of ruin. Tactics and choice are truly very limited, the concealment idea is nice but poorly executed- how can I put my units where I want them AND engage overwatch, etc when there are so many detection zones, and I have just a handful of turns to complete my objective? No time really given to let you learn things, I guess the idea is you will fail in your first game somewhere, give up, and play again with all your training" in place.

Apparently there is a "correct" tech path to take in order to go very far in the game- don't deviate or you will quickly be outmatched and outgunned to the point of abandoning the game. DONT USE MODS UNTIL EVERYTHING IS PATCHED- they seem to corrupt your savegames :). That was a fun discovery.

reviewText:
XCOM 2 is largely a refinement of and an advancement on XCOM: Enemy Unknown. It honestly doesn't feel like a full sequel. Feels like XCOM: Enemy Unknown 1.5. But that's not really a bad thing. As mentioned, many things have been refined and streamlined, and there have been a host of new additions that do mix things up to a certain degree. Though yes, at the same time, I must say I am a tad disappointed that things aren't more different.

So, long story short, if you like XCOM: EU you will most probably like XCOM 2 as well. The campaign length for a first run is around 40-50 hours.

Now, the game has some glaring issues. One is optimization. I honestly do not find the graphics to be anything stellar (they don't seem that different from in XCOM EU), but even on the lowest settings I am getting absolutely terrible performance.

Another is from time to time, the game can bug out. I hacked a Sectapod successfully, yet somehow it remains out of my control and kills my troops on the next turn. Then there was once a muton who was actually on the roof, but the graphics made it look like it was at the bottom of the roof. And once my scanning went to -3 days (it just bugged out).

Gameplay wise, too many enemies are just bullet sponges in the mid-to-late game.

Now that I am right at the end of the final mission, I can say that this game suffers the same two issues from XCOM EU.

1) The mid-to-late game is relatively much, much easier than the fiendishly difficult early game.

2) There is no middle ground" difficulty setting between Veteran (a tad too easy) and Commander (a tad too difficult)

This game is a net recommendation actually but I leave a thumbs down until Firaxis can fix the optimization issues at least."

reviewText: Fun, brutal, and oh so unforgiving. This is truly what a sequel should be, improving on the bad, making the good better, adding some new features, and taking away anything unecessary. This game feels exactly like the original (the one in 2011) and former Xcom players will have no problems jumping in. Likewise, newcomers will find this game to be a bit harsh at first if they don't know what they're doing or if they don't know what the best strategy is, though there are lots of guides to help with that. To me though, the hardest part definitely comes in management. The Avatar Project, or the main thing you're fighting, can only be slown down by certain operations, it's no longer the take your time that we're used to in EW, but it still can feel a lot like it the further in the game you go. On a similar note, combat has been revamped and with all the other people talking about concealment and timed missions, I won't go into it, though I will say I like both. Another good thing is the multitude of ways to finish missions. In EW it was straight up kill all enemies or rescue certain amount of civs then kill all enemies. Now, there are missions such as hostage rescue, comm defense, comm destruction, vip capturing, and even detonating bases. The way they all function is great as well, they have multiple ways of finishing them, you can either go in guns blazing with a full squad, or use a lone soldier to capture an objective and then high tale it out without killing anyone. In general, it's a fun game and a great way to feel mad after seeing your rookies constantly mess up. 9/10

reviewText: This is a poor excuse for a tactical game.  Strategic elements are entertaining and interesting.  I find it challenging that attempting to gather resources may cost you in the long run because it forces you to choose between gathering or accomplishing missions rather than being able to achieve both.  In terms of tactical combat, this is a terrible game.  The cover system is horribly flawed.  Elevation plays no impact in the game whatsoever.  Having a good angle on an opponent means nothing if their plane of cover is between you and your target.  Fog of war prevents you from being able to make rational ambushes more than once per mission.  It's as though the game is designed around quick saving because they can't come up with a more creative engine, just nerf certain aspects such as overwatch.  Honestly had way more fun with the Front Mission series.  It's not that I expected this game to be that series, it's that it doesn't offer anything more than it.  A good tactical game should allow you to recover from an initial mistake if you play your cards right, not heavily punish you for scouting fog of war.  If you're going to make it so enemies can instantly discover me behind cover, you may as well make them all aware of my presence after the first ambush.

reviewText:
After playing through this game in it's entirety on Commander+Ironman difficulty with initially high hopes following my time with XCOM: EU, i've come to the conclusion that XCOM 2 is honestly, a complete mess, and really not worth anyones time.

Between the horrendous performance issues that seem innate to the game rather than anyones hardware setup being at fault, completely warped balancing, and a helping of tedious, almost insultingly easy story missions (coming from someone who could never even beat alien base assault on EU's classic difficulty, I might add.), XCOM 2 brings nothing new to the table besides a few rather nice graphical effects, some ridiculous new (and completely dumbed down!) mechanics, absolutely nonsensically imbalanced classes for you to steamroll the game with, and a story that's not worth mentioning.

The AI, too, is completely ♥♥♥♥-poor, it often relying almost solely on taking potshots at the nearest or lowest covered threat, regardless of their defensive status (hunkered down, buffed by a Specialist, etc) and trying to let the RNG carry it, which, if you learn the games mechanics well enough, can literally let you survive almost every single mission without having your team be hit. It's such a huge, HUGE downgrade from it's predecessor in this regard, it's impossible not to notice.

Take my advice: Before buying this game, either pick up and try Enemy Unknown or reinstall and play through it again, then ask yourself if you really want to see that game call of duty-ified to no end, because that's honestly all XCOM 2 will seem like in comparison to it's predecessor.

reviewText:
I can't recommend it. All the right ingredients are there, and it should be the best XCOM game ever made according to the sum of its features.

Yet the restrictive turn counters that appear in most missions utterly ruin the game, and indeed go against what has always been XCOMs central concept. No longer do you carefully plan your way to victory, but instead find yourself scrambling to rush to an objective completely arbitrarily. Apart from anything else, it simply restricts the way you can play a mission. In the past, if people wanted to rush an objective, that was one of many possible strategies. Now, in most missions, it is the only possible strategy.

The problem is only exarcebated because most of the maps are randomised, meaning there is no guarantee an objective is even completeable in the time allowed. When your entire squad can be wiped out on failure of certain mission types, this becomes a simply inexcusable and frankly game ruining design feature.

In all other aspects this is a truly fantastic game, and those 1 out of 10 missions where there are no timers can be incredibly gripping. But knowing that a potentially game ending mission (through no fault of my own) could be just around the corner makes it increasingly difficult for me to play this.

reviewText:
Awesome addition to the XCOM games! Quick rundown:

+ Graphics look good & unit customization is great
+ Solder pool allows you to save favorite looking solders, or import other people's solders. One from the pool may show up in game as a solder, engineer that has to be rescused, or even an enemy informant you need to kidnap or kill!
+ Maps look great, and are all of a good size, as well as variety
+ Enemies are varied, with more types than before. Aliens are actually a threat!
+ Tons of different items for solders to use (various granades, ammo types, gun mods)
+ Turn based missions make overwatch turtling an impossible strategy, which was pretty much the I-Win-Button for XCOM EU/EW. Also adds a sense of urgency.
+ Ranged heals
+ New classes are well designed and have some neat perks

- Some performance issues. Sometimes there's a 5 - 10 second pause at the start of the enemy turn. Sometimes on the enemy turn the screen will go black. Sometimes FPS tanks for no discernible reason.
- Navigating multi-floored buildings just as much of a pain as XCOM:EU/EW
- While I find the time limit missions (which seem to be about 50% of them) fine, I think extending the timer by two turns on a mission would help out the casual XCOM players.
- Russian & Polish languages missing. These were added in Enemy Within (along with localization), and should have remained. Even if Firaxis didn't localise there for XCOM 2, I'm sure a copy/paste of sound files from EW would have pleased those overseas. Though I am of neither nationality, I did like my Russian & Polish solders speaking their language, and hope this is implemented in the future.

reviewText:
XCOM 2 is the second BIG triple A title to come out this year and so far the year looks good for PC gamers
XCOM 2 is a TBS (turn-based strategy) game and the improved sequel to 2012's reboot of the series, XCOM: Enemy Unknown.
The story picks up 20 years after the events of the previous game. Aliens have taken over the Earth and it is your duty to reclaim our planet.

All your favourate character classes are back: Snipers, Assault, Heavies and support.
Heavie is now called the Grenadier and, as the name suggests, now carries a powerful and upgradable grenade launcher as well as the good 'ol minigun you already know from the previous game.
Snipers now have a powerful pistol they can use as well as their usual long range sniper rifle.
Support is now known as the Specialist and they have a military drone that can hack into the enemy's network, heal teammates or electrocute enemies.
Assault is now called Ranger and they wield swords. You read that right. Swords, baby, swords! Hack 'n' slash through the alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who shot down your ride!
You can now customise all of your soldiers tho. You can change their sex, name, nationality, voice, hairstyle and colour, armor style, colour, camo and same for weapons. You can even download mods from the Steam Workshop to take customisation to the next level.
I had a tough military looking guy in my squad. His name was Arny GetToDaChoppa" Commando and he used the Arnold Schwarzenegger Voice Pack. Amazing!
R.I.P Arny Commando. You'll be missed.

Your base is now an alien spaceship. You can fly it around the Earth to collect supplies

C) I love how you can customize your characters and even import/export your friends characters to the game, making every soldier in this game someone you care about, and not just another worthless grunt. You CARE about your teammembers.
D) I love how destructible the maps are.

-=CONS:=-
A) Unfair Enemy advantages, leading to poor balance where 'save-scumming' is the only way to win (repeatedly saving again and again until there is actually a possible way to win or proceed. See below:
a1) Enemies have a free movement action DURING YOUR TURN when discovered rather than at the end of your turn, meaning your overwatch ambush from stealth, (which hasnt yet been finished being setup), isnt allowed to be finished during your turn because the free movement action allows your enemies to run away or take cover before you have applied Overwatch to your teammembers. This is highly unfair when NOT discovered. This almost removes the fact that it is a turn-based game, when your enemies are breaking the most basic rule of a turn-based game. If they can move during your turn, as they are now, it makes completing missions almost impossible in a high number of missions because YOU dont have the advantage of moving however the f### you please when its not your turn.
a2) Enemies are given an unfair amount of action points which seems to change repeatedly. For example, (and you'll know what i mean if you have played) Players are limited to 2 action points, enemies however seem to breach this. I had a Viper who MOVED, TONGUE-PULLED, COILED, and ACID SPIT the rest of the team all in the same turn, turning my winning game, into a lost one, in a single turn that was not possible to defend against. Another example are Stun Baton soldiers, who are given 2 Running actions, and are still allowed to attack, which leads to another gamebreaking problem:
a3) Most Enemies are all given very unfair 'INSTANT KILL' and 'INSTANT INCAPACITATE' abilities, which are able to be carried out from absurd distances. 1: Viper Tonguepull into coils from 8 spaces away, through 5 'Full Cover' walls (another bug/exploit). 2: Mindcontrol from 12 spaces away (meaning your team has to make a suicide run up to the controller to stop it, meaning, you're screwed 3: Stun Baton from over 10 spaces away -.-, the list of Instant-Kill abilities just goes on, which are super unfair considering my next point:
a4) Your team size is limited to between 4-6, you can end up in fights against 20 aliens at the same time...meaning they get far more turns to kill you, and most aliens (see a3) can choose, whenever they feel like, to instantly kill your whole team in a way you cannot defend against, with no counter especially early-to-mid game, way before their turn is even over. Xcom original let you take way more soldiers and even tanks into the battlefield, why are we limited to such a small team size? And dont give me that 'Graphical limitation' bullcrap, Xcom ran tonnes of soldiers and aliens at the same time on the Commador Amiga, back in 1994.
a5) Cover and Aim, is bugged and broken. Cover doesnt do anything right now, everyone just shoots you or instant-kills you THROUGH it. You can be in an aliens face with a shotgun, whilst flanking, from behind with a 95% chance to hit (why the hell isnt it 100%) and that 95% shot will ACTUALLY miss 50% of the time. Now i know Xcom is about RNG, im a very experience player of these types of game, but the Aim RNG is actually BROKEN. The % shown to you is not actually the correct %. Many many more players are confirming the same bug. You can actually shoot enemies, and they can shoot you, through Solid Rock, and multiple thick layers of alien metal and still hit you for full damage....wtf is going on here, FIX THIS FIRAXIS.
a6) Some missions are so hard, that you can die on your very first turn, wth NO way to survive it, and given no control whatsoever to prevent it. I started a mission to protect a village from attack, (early game too) and had 2 heavy armor units, 3 special health-regen enemies, 2 mind control units, and 5 Advent soldiers who had all started, spawned right in front of my face at the beginning of the mission....they of course Instantly got a Free Movement Action during MY TURN DAMMIT, and then once i told them to take cover it didnt matter..the mission was impossible, and was Instant-death from the moment i came out of the Mission Start screen -.- this is BROKEN.

Holy crap i think im done with point A.

B) There's no time to do anything in the world. The moment you want to collect a resource, 10 major disasters will happen the moment you want to attempt to get some basic income going, even at the beginning of the game, collecting basic Starter resources gets you screwed over. These disasters and events seriously need reducing in frequency. If you dont do them, the penalties are so harshe theyre too easy to ruin the rest of your game right from the beginning! It's too much of a rush.

C) When you do the final misison (no spoilers of course) the game is just OVER. No more freeroaming no more 'confront alien invaders' its just THE END. You cannot continue playing......WTF Firaxis. This needs to change, once the story mode is over, random alien attacks, missions and enemy ships should still be happening, like the good old days of Xcom where the game mode is Infinitely long and you can continue playing to your hearts content.

D) No Skyranger VS UFO Ship  battles and downed-ship invasions to recover parts like the good days of Xcom (how Xcom was supposed to be played), if you run into a UFO, the game just goes You have instantly lost

reviewText:
First off I will point out that I am enjoying the game to an extent and I will put more hours into it, but I am giving it a thumbs down because of the aggressive mission timers.  They ruin the pace and strategy of the game for me and force you down one path - rushing the objective.  In a single player turn based strategy game I like to take my time and try different ways of achieving the objective.

One suggestion would be to make it so the timer doesn't even start ticking until you are out of stealth at the start of the mission, but overall I just don't like the timers.  I certainly don't think that they should be in 75% of the missions.  If timed missions came up around 10% of the time I would be OK with it, so maybe it is a question of not enough diversity in the mission types?

Hopefully the modding community can sort this problem out.

The other problem is the performance of the game, which I have found to be all over the place, and I have a pretty good PC (i7 4790k, GTX970, 16GB RAM, SSD).

reviewText:
Jeez, I really like XCOM, however, at the moment it is difficult to recommend.

In a lot of ways this sequel is a move in the right direction. The game makes you feel pressured and you often have to decide on the best of two bad options. The field game is a lot more in depth and plays a lot more like old school X-Com. that said there are a lot of problems. Some of this stuff can be fixed with patches, however, on some level the game is just fundamentally flawed.

It's hard, and I'm fine with that, XCOM should be hard, though I feel a lot of the time it's hard in the wrong ways.

The missions often have time limits, and that's okay in itself but combine that with the way aliens enter the fight (they become active in packs of 2-3 as soon as one of your soldiers spots one of the pack, at which point they get a free move to cover) means that it is never smart to push out more than a few spaces a turn. If you discover a pack with your penultimate or last move of a round, 2-3 strong aliens get a free move to cover (or, even worse flank you) and then have a whole round to take down a couple of guys.

The game pushes you forward with time limits and then punishes you for moving forward at even a moderate rate.

Also, a lot of people seem to feel melee is OP, I'm not sure I'd agree with that, but I don't think it feels very good. If you run up and take a sword swipe at something and miss, that soldier is probably dead.

The geoscape gameplay is not very well explained either, I'd advise treating your first game as a throwaway until you get the hang of how that works.

Lastly, this game is really badly optimised, lots and lots of slowdowns, the game hanging for 5-10 seconds. Lots of gaps in the action, you'll throw a grenade, and there is significant gaps between the grenade being thrown, exploding, damage being dealt and the next action taking place.

This game does have a lot of potential, but I don't think they can change the gameplay enough with patches to really make the gameplay coherent, the mechanics complementary and the difficulty.tough but fair.

reviewText:
I am overall disappointed with the game, being an XCOM enthusiast. I've played XCOM1 for 255 hours, but I do not feel like giving XCOM2 more than the 55ish hours I gave it so far

XCOM2 follows the same pattern the previous games did: start with rookies, study alien tech, build some armors and weapons, learn psionics, find a way to the aliens' base and destroy it, and have your base attacked at least once in the process. There's even pretty much the same tech development - assault rifles into magnetic guns (laser guns) and then plasma. Only 3 armor tech levels too. Sure, there are modifications and some fancy variations of weapons and armors, but that's still underwhelming. This is hardly an improvement on XCOM1:EW. I expected XCOM2 to be much more developed than EW, but it's merely on par. It's not even longer than XCOM1.

The final mission is also an insult to the player. I don't want to spoil the surprise here, but it was not just difficult, the designers made it simply unfair. I was about to prevail against the odds, when the crucial enemy I needed to kill teleported away to the other end of the gigantic map leaving me sorrounded by a dozen enemies.

The game is a bit glitchy and unstable - hopefully there will be patches in the future to fix that. Fortunately, not everything is gamebreaking, but I had to restart the game and steam several times in my playthrough. Frozen cutscenes, cutscenes displayed more than once, disappearing/stuttering/looped audio. Currently, it is not worth its full price - I recommend waiting for discounts.

What is perhaps the most puzzling is the poor design of gameplay. Sometimes I would roar in frustration because I had to listen to the same dialogues over and over again after restarting a mission and there was no way to skip it - the apogeum of frustration are the terror missions. The game still hijacks the camera away from you (I think I know better what I want to look at, thanks). Also, does the cam really have to center on the soldier I switch to every time? Lots of your time will be wasted for no reason at all (I recommend getting some mods to fix that - they don't change any balance, such as Quiet Bradford) because apparently you need full 10-15 seconds to be told that there has been progress on the Avatar project.

There are several improvements though: waypoint soldier movement, reloading does not end the turn anymore, more class balance, diversified enemies, diversified terrain, soldier customization, simplified base build-up, melee attacks (finally!!!). I might have forgotten some things, but they certainly do not change my opinion of the game.

reviewText:
Finally fully finished a run of this game so I am now able to give a complete rundown of the game.

This game takes the normal formula of an XCOM game and twists it to fit the guerilla warfare style of the story. While this is refreshing and forces to player to play far more offensively and aggressively there are some issues in doing so that I feel were not ironed out before launch as was left up to the modding community to fix.

Story:
The story opens with the Commander being rescued by his old advisor and reveals that Enemy Unknown/Within never happened at all and that it was a series of simulations done by the aliens immediately following the instant surrender of Earth after they captured the Commander. The story continues to unfold with the game and the decisions of the player but every so often key parts of the story open up and show that the aliens are actually doing bad things to humanity rather than actually helping them and culminates on a final assualt.
A lot of people had a problem with how the first game was relegated to simulations but I find that outcome not only logical but hilarious considering that only 10% of people even beat Enemy Unknown at all with how easy that game is. My problem is that the stance of the aliens is barely explored at all throughout the game and only does get explored on the final mission.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is still the same at its core as it was in Enemy Unknown but with added features and elements. The main feature added is the Concealment mode. This allows your team to move around without enemies heatseeking them until you open fire or enter their field of view, which in turn allows you to set up an ambush.
Along with concealment, some new features were added along with some new goodies, too. A lot of classes have been reworked from EU and gun attachments that augment how a specific soldier operates and new explosives and armor have been added as well. The main problem with the gameplay is how Concealment works logically with some of the timer missions. Why would they rig their own supplies to explode when they don't even know that XCOM is in the area?

Graphics and Performance:
This is where the game really falls apart. While the game as a whole looks pretty good, it performs like absolute ♥♥♥♥. With a 970 memecard, I was getting huge frame issues on max settings even after the patch. Turning off ambient occlusion and reducing AA to FXAA helped a lot but there were still issues that caused it to dip into the 40s after turning off some partical effects as well.

Audio and Music:
The music is still roughly the same as it was in EU but sounds a lot more triumphant upon a victory than before, mainly due to being a tiny rebel force fighting a huge alien force that has the planet in its grasp. The audio is about as standard as it gets but voiceovers can NOT be skipped and during retaliation missions, Bradford never shuts up and continues to repeat the same unskippable dialogue over and over each turn.

Other:
There isn't much else to talk about aside from the modding community. While Firaxis left a lot of issues in the vanilla game, they made modding tools very open and acceisble to the community and they have done wonders for this game. From adding small aesthetic mods to full blown mods changing how Concealment and timers work, the modders have done good work and have effectively fixed all the issues of the game. This does not excuse Firaxis for releasing the game in the state it was, but it allows players to easily change the game to either their liking or just enough to fix some issues they have with some game mechanics. Keep it up, mod community. You guys do good work.

Epilogue/tl;dr:
Even with all the graphical and gameplay issues, the game is still solid and adds a great deal more content to play with and against and any issue a player might have with the game can be fixed with the click of a button in the workshop.
WARNING: Adding a mod to a campaign and then removing it and attempting to continue playing will result in an error and bypassing that error may result the campaign corrupting or becoming unplayable.

I give this game a solid 8/10 and recommend it to anyone who is a fan of XCOM, new or old, or strategy games in the vein of XCOM in general and would recommend those that aren't to at least give it a good shot.

reviewText: Harsh design, poor optimisation and a baffling lack of truly random outcomes spoils an otherwise interesting sequel.  The strategy layer is much improved, the concealment mechanic interesting (if not actually all that useful) and the new aliens and soldier abilities expand into new territory.  It's such a shame therefore that it seems hellbent on preventing players having any fun at all.  Tweaks can be applied by mods to smooth out some of the worst, but presently there is no way to ensure the game properly delivers random outcomes to possible actions, meaning all the decision making by the player is ultimately irrelevant.

reviewText:
XCOM: Enemy Unknown - the complete version is one of my most favorite games of the recent past. I played it on my PS3, PC/MAC, and my iPad. Hell, I still play it on my iPad. I then got into the Long War mod, and I couldn't play the base game anymore (except my iPad). XCOM 2 had some large shoes to fill. Did it?

I think it did. Let me first put a disclaimer up. I didn't experience any crashes or game ending bugs. I somehow missed all of those. Sure, I had some slowdowns and long loads, but no crashes. Very few bugs at all. I don't even have that great of a system, but that's besides the point.

I love XCOM 2. It took me a while to accept the timers, but when I did, I got over one of the few qualms I had with the game.

I love the new story. We lost to the Aliens. How refreshing. We are having to fight back and try to re-conquer our world. AWESOME. We have new mission types, and we use the hellicarrier from the Aveng....  er... floating alien transport ship instead.

We are a guerilla force out to exact revenge as we uncover the plot of the story. The unit rebalance and customization is great. The new gameplay is great. The timers... um, not so much. But then we have mods.

Oh the mods, the glorious mods. After downloading a dozen, I can't play the base game anymore. The modders are making this game even better.

How would I score this game? Hmm, I would certainly recommend it, but players need to accept that the RNG is brutal. Really brutal, and the game is harder than XCOM:EU was. Is it as hard as the LW mod? No, but it can be on the highest difficulty.

I have many more thoughts about it and if you are interested in reading them, here's a link: http://explorminate.net/2016/03/04/friday-excursion-xcom-2/

Have fun commander, and if you want to know what mods are a must, just comment here and I will let you know what I use.

reviewText:
While I'm still playing through the campaign, I can say that XCOM 2 is overall a well-made game, but there are some downsides with it. For me, mainly two: the game isn't as optimised as it should be, I'm running a 650 Ti 2GB currently but I feel like it should be able to run the game at higher frames (although the game has never outright crashed). I also feel like the difficulty of the game needs some tweaking - I've been playing on the second difficulty and it feels too punishing in certain areas.

If you make one mistake in your research, mission choices or facility choices, you can find yourself in completely frustrating situations, like not having enough squad member slots, or wasting all your money on new soldiers because you didn't buy the facility needed to use the speed boost that heals your current soldiers faster and in time for the next mission. Once you realise your weaknesses and start trying to correct them down the road, the Avatar counter will keep ticking up as expected, not giving you enough time unless you want the red bar almost completely filled by the time you're prepared for the mission.

Making these types of oversights can make the game extremely tedious unless you constantly revert saves, which isn't how you want to play it. You can find yourself saving after every mission so you can revert to any point of the game and change your choices so that you can avoid the problem that made you revert in the first place.

Overall, good game for strategy players and one that improves on Enemy Unknown. Don't buy if your graphics card is old or if you don't want to constantly revert saves or constantly lose all time and effort you invested into your playthrough.

(Yes, I understand XCOM is meant to punish bad decisions, but personally I feel it went too far in that direction and could have been more forgiving at least a few times, especially on the first two difficulties).

P.S. I wrote this review for the Pillar of Community badge.

reviewText:
It has been stated before, but i just have to say it again.
The game is basically a nice improvement over the first part, but two very annoying issues drive the fun out very quickly.
The first one is the mission timers. Timed missions were the curse of the first part, because all the nice setups you can plan in this kind of game just need to be hurried and you cannot explore with a timer. This happens almost every single mission now. The entire laid-back feeling that made the XCOM series great for all that time is gone with this single change. It wouldnt be so bad if this happened to b the occasional odd-one-out timed mission. But it is almost every single one.
The same principle applies to the whole campaign by the way. Your only have the illusion of choosing your goals in the campaign, because the very narrow time limit has you chasing after primary objectives and the means necessary to acces them (contacts/intel) all the time. This always hectic feeling really squelches the fun out of what could be a prime gaming experience.

The second issue is the ridicoulous low performance and memory leaks.
The in-combat performance is really low on default settings, but can actually be tweaked via lowering graphic options to manageable levels. The bigger problem here is a kind of stuttering that is introduced after you run the game for some time. Usually starts with slightly longer breaks between turns, missions or changing a screen on the campaign map. The longer you play, the longer the pauses, until you feel like the game freezes every couple of seconds.
Now this feels like something that could be patched in time, so the question remains: why on gods green earth does every premium developer nowadays resort to releasing half baked products?

reviewText:
XCOM 2 is a turn-based strategy developed by Firaxis and published by 2K Games. It is a direct sequel to the previous XCOM: Enemy Unknown and the expansion XCOM: Enemy Within.

In XCOM 2, follows the story where the XCOM lose the war to the alien. The aliens rule Earth, building shining cities that promise a brilliant future for humanity on the surface, while concealing a sinister agenda and eliminating all who dissent from their new order. So they said it, we are now on the offensive on XCOM 2. With only limited resources, XCOM must retake back Earth from the ADVENT.

XCOM 2 gameplay are quite similiar with XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but plays differently. In fact, you feel like you already knew how it plays out until you see the timer. Yes, each mission has a time limit to reach certain objectives. But most people describe it wrong as a turn timer or whatever it is they said. The truth is, it's a turn limit to reach certain objectives such as hacking a device, rescuing VIP or destroying key objectives. Most of them if completed, then the timer is gone and you can have all the time you want to kill the enemy. NOT all missions has this turn limit objectives however. Overwatch in XCOM 2 is even more powerful I think, even if some people didn't like the turn limit, overwatch now doesn't trigger all at once, they trigger one by one that you can be sure every overwatch is count. Base building retains the same element but building adjacent bonuses are gone, instead you get to upgrades with resources. The global map have been changed too. Since you have a mobile headquarters, in the global map, you need to move from place to place to scan for resources, intel or even contacting resistance on other location.

There is this thing called Avatar Project or simply AP by the community, I think, it renders your campaign has time limit which you have to act fast to delay or setback the project progress. You can do this by assaulting alien bases or hacking then kill the alien codex. There's also Dark Event, which some kind of random even that if left unchecked will, I say again WILL give you disadvantage and give the alien an advantage. Like XCOM: Enemy Unknown abduction mission, not all Dark Event mission can't be completed, you have to choose which you think is the best... or the worse. All of this makes your campaign has faster pace then the previous.

Tactical combat also has become more difficult, at least for me. I can see more challenge here. Remember Sectoid? They're not what you remember now, they posses more power and can mess you up if you don't kill them real quick. What about Thin Man? Now you will see the true form of the alien infiltration unit. Soldiers now also has even more useful abilities, some are in fact powerful if you know how to use them. Soldiers can even be upgraded further to gain more advantage, whether it's a weapon or the soldier themselves. Turn limit may be frustrating, but in my opinion they're not as frustrating as some people said.

Customization in XCOM 2 are great, I will say huge if they actually add more content or option into it, nevertheless we have modding support. There is a dedicated place where you can create you characters before you even play the campaign. Characters you created can be set to appear as XCOM soldiers, or VIP which is scientist or engineer, or even Dark VIP which will appear on some mission and you must capture them. With mods, customization will be unlimited.

Firaxis did improve the graphics and effects on XCOM 2. They look prettier than XCOM: Enemy Unknown. The downside XCOM 2 has is the performance. It is unoptimized that I can barely have FPS above 35. Most of the time I get stutters and lags. Mission loading time is quite long. They need to fix this.

Overall, XCOM 2 is a great sequel. Some people don't like the turn limit, but for me, knowing that we are on the offensive with guerilla style warfare, that's just about fair and challenging. With mods support is even better. If only the performance were better on release, I would give XCOM 2 way better score. I recommend XCOM 2.

Rating 7/10
