reviewText:
XCOM 2 is the sequel to XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  I played over 1000 hours of the first game, including on my Android device, and it was my favourite game of all time... until now.  If you're looking for negatives, scroll to the bottom.  Otherwise, I'm going to discuss all the things about this game that make it better than its predecessor.  (Other than the procedurally generated maps; the feature I was most excited about before the game launched.  The maps feel handcrafted and still provide near endless variation.)

XCOM 2 is a genuine sequel, not a polished re-skin with a few new buttons.  This game is a sequel in terms of story, your opponents, and even the difficulty level.  (For that reason, if you haven't played XCOM: EU, I recommend you begin there.)  Despite my experience with the previous game, XCOM 2 destroyed me on my first attempt, at the difficulty level I played most on EU.  I'm thrilled about that because fans like myself can experience the challenge, the rush, the highs and lows of the war, and those moments when everything's so intense that your heart pounds but you keep on playing!

The story and the characters in the campaign have been improved immensely.  The tutorial introduces you to them, and the setting, through a series of story missions that'll make you feel connected to them in a way you never did in XCOM: EU.  As the story goes on, the connection you feel to each character continues to develop, and the story might stay with you for a long time.  In addition, the ending is much more thrilling and rewarding than the end of XCOM: EU--however, this game makes that somewhat disappointing ending into a spectacular one, and then goes on to give you an even better ending in XCOM 2!

The strategy layer of the game has been significantly enhanced in XCOM 2 as well.  In the past you could do research and construction however you wanted, but that isn't the case in XCOM 2.  No more watching the hologlobe spin while you pass time at the base either--now the Geoscape is like a board game.  Your decisions on the strategic layer have a major impact on the way the game plays out, and the aliens are also playing their own game against you.  You'll need to adjust your strategy on the fly to counter the aliens' projects and prevent their victory.

Additionally, the tactical gameplay is better than ever--and that's where XCOM has always been strongest.  Many games try to copy the tactical combat of XCOM, and you might hear games described as like XCOM."  I assure you that having two actions per soldier per turn

reviewText:
In Xcom 2 Firaxis have done what many thought impossible and improved on almost every aspect of Xcom EU. And if you are a fan of turn based stratagy games then this is a must-have purchase. That being said however, It does have it's drawbacks.

Pros:

1. Far, far deeper customisation for your soldiers, now being able to choose things such as face paint, camouflage and individual options for the torso, legs and arms of their armour.

2. Randomly generated levels meaning that you won't play the exact same level multiple times like in EU.

3. Consealment. Now when you start most missions you are in consealment meaning the enemies don't know that you're there, Allowing you to move without being attacked and set up abushes.

4. Strong class system requireing you to think tactically about who you bring on each mission and what equptment to give them.

5. Much improved Visuals.

6. Mod support.

7. More varied enemys with unique abilities to each other.

8. More methods of going about the task than just shooting. You can now use a specialist to hack robotic units, or use a ranger to deal massive amount of damage with their sword.

9. More mission types. The missions are no longer just kill everything or escort someone across a map. There are new objectives such as destorying a communications relay. Breaking VIPs out of prison or having to carry an unconcious VIP across the map to the extraction zone.

10. Almost fully destructable environments. Is there an enemy flanking one of your soldiers while on a rooftop, and there is no way that you can shoot it to death in that turn? Get a grenade and blow up the floor beneith it! making it take the grenade damage, fall damage, and if you're lucky, fire damage from the building begining to burn down.

Cons:

1. Clipping issues. Soldiers will often fire through solid walls, break windows that have already been broken, or standing on absolutly nothing in order to shoot an enemy while positioned on a ledge.

2. Performance issues. For some unexplained reason this game is far more demanding than it deserves to be, or that the reccommended settings say it is. Unless you turn off MSAA then it WILL lag. Even without MSAA it will still lag, jusst not as much.

3. long load times. Even on an SSD, expect load times to be 30 seconds+. While it is understandable on the way to the missions due to generating teh map, on the way back the load times are even longer. An issue that can inexplicably be fixed by pressing the 'Caps Lock' button which makes it load almost instantly.

4. Mod support. While I said that it is a good thing that it has it, it has been implimented in a way that means that any mod you turn on creates a dependancy for that mod in that save. This means if you install a mod, play a mission with it an descover you don't like it then you either need to keep playing with it, revert back to a save before you had it, or with Ironman player, restart the game.

5. Steep dificulty curve. While in Xcom EU the first 3 missions would be fighting sectiods, then they intoduce thin men who can spit poison, on Xcom 2 the first 2 missions are fighting nice, weak enemies, then suddenly the introduce sectiods in the 3rd which can panic and mind control your soldiers. In the 5th mission the introduce vipers that can grab your soldiers from 7 tiles away and pull them out of cover. The game gets very hard, very quickly.

6. Mission timers. Most missions now have a timer for you to finish them in before you fail and are either force evacuated or captured by the aliens. The problem is that they give you usually less than 10 turns to kill about 12 aliens, finish the objective then get to a set evac zone on the other side of the map. Another problem is that most of the reasons for the counters are 'drop ships are coming to attack you' or 'the aliens have rigged this thing to explode' but when you enter the missions you're consealed so there is no reason for the countdown timer to start in that case.

Although I listed almost as many cons as pros, the good things that the pros bring by far outweigh the badness of the cons, and none of the cons are things that can't be fixed in updates or by mods. And yes, this is a difficult game and I have rage quit it many times, but i'm not going to be pathetic and post a negative review, just because I wasn't thinking tactially enough to get myself out of those situations.

reviewText:
In short this game is more or less XCOM 1.5. Though that is not necessarily a bad thing as the great gameplay from the previous one is still in there, the bad thing is that it feels as if many of the assets such as animations have been re-used from the previous game so it does not feel entirely fresh. And the graphics look sleek without being too good.

Many of the new additions are great and since you are now on the offensive most of the time it means that many missions have timers, so you have to get your objectives done and then get out as soon as possible which creates tension and forces you to adopt new tactics compared to what you were used to previously. Though some of the missions have timers that either are too short or does not make much sense in relation to the objective. Such as the missions where you have to secure a supply stash, and even though you start the mission in stealth the enemy will still destroy the supplies if you take too long even if you were never detected.
The endgame also feel a bit too easy, as there are no elite versions of many of the enemies, ADVENT soldiers of all kinds seem to level up and develop as time goes on, but many of the units such as the Vipers don't. Meaning that a once feared enemy no longer is a threat at all. So the pacing feels a bit off later on.

Customization is really great, with many new ways to customize your soldiers, from a wide selection of hats and armours, even weapons and character personality animations can be changed to make your own squad more unique. Many of the classes also have been a bit more streamlined as well, and many skills feel a bit more useful and distinct. The specialist for example can now go down the skill path to become a medic or combat hacker. Both are useful so it is up to you how you mix and match character skills and builds.

All in all I enjoyed XCOM 2, but I feel that they could have done more, it feels like a large expansion rather than a full new game. But if you liked XCOM: Enemy unknown, then you will probably enjoy this one, just be prepared that they are fairly similar while at the same time have enough differences. If nothing else there is always a steam sale later on.

One thing is the same still though, RNG is still a ♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Truly a great successor to the first XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within.

XCOM 2 has a story that is a lot more engaging compared to the first XCOM, and I managed to finish the entire campaign on Ubuntu within 51 hours on Veteran. That's a drastic improvement in content over the first XCOM, which could be completed in 20 hours on one playthrough.

Gameplay mechanics have been improved quite drastically to keep things fresh each time you play a mission, and difficulty rises as you progress but does not feel insurmountable once you know what you are doing.

Customizations for your soldiers really let's you get attached to your soldiers, and I even found myself scolding my ranger often for failing his Bladestorm attacks but never wanting him to be in harms way.

The Linux port is very well made, with one caveat. Performance is not as good as I would have hoped, but I do trust that performance improvements will come in the near future. It is playable, but not as enjoyable in that aspect as it could be on a GTX680 at 1080p.

The only last real caveat I feel the game suffers from is timer-based missions (gameplay mechanic). Some of them force you to abandon tactics, and sacrifice soldier's lives for the sake of completing the mission in-time. This is a turn-based game, but it feels like I'm being forced to play it like an RTS which is off-putting for those missions. Thankfully most main missions don't have these turn timers or have well-balanced timers.

Overall, a worthy successor to XCOM EU & EW. Highly recommended for those that love strategy games, but even more so for those who do not define their libraries by genre but rather by engaging and well-made games!

reviewText:
This brief review comes from an old time veteran of UFO games going all the way back to the 90s. Being a great fan of the relaunched Xcom the second installment was an autobuy. And I am very confident they will eventually patch it to where it should be, but...

Even on easiest setting some of the missions are extremely hard - mainly due to the RNG gameplay mechanics built into the core mechanics: I've had to reload for literally 2 evenings to finish one of the missions because of flaws in my team that I simply could not have prevented as a player. And that comes from a ironman player of Xcom 1. I have no qualms with being punished for stupid gameplay - in Xcom2 I am constantly reloading simply because stuff happens that I have absolutely no control over.

The alien opponents seemingly use their maximum movement range and still melee attack - or they have insane range. And why Aliens get an out of turn movement phase when they are surprised by my team beats me. Result as so often is that they can essentially flank the hell out of me without my team even being able to reposition.

The timers are extremely tight and often enough I had to restart missions all the way from the beginning simply because I had that one turn missing to finish the extraction. I even had to leave folks behind due to the constantly reapearing aliens - without my guys having a fair chance to fight their way out. No one left behind? Not in Xcom2.

And don't get me even started on the hit/cover percentages... Let's say it this way: they really need some love.

Story and core combat of the game are great and absolutely addicting. It's just not really polished for the player yet. But I am sure it will happen over time and then my hesitant NO" will become an overwhelming "YES"... until then: you either have to be a lucky star OR masochistic. Or both..."

reviewText:
Xcom 2012 was a great game.  Xcom 2 aggressively changes everything that made its predecessor great.  Let me count the ways.

- This game is a turn based strategy, only when it wants to be

There are enemies that can both move and attack you on your turn.  YOUR turn!  All your troops are positioned perfectly.  You inch your way forward as safely as possible.  One soldier takes one step too far.  Suddenly (still, during your turn) an alien shows up, runs towards this soldier, attacks AND poisons them.  Your soldier will be dead in 4 turns.  That's what you get for walking.  This game hates you.  It wants all your troops to die.  It will take their lives in the most unfair ways.

- Geoscape is overly complex and confusing

Base management in Xcom 2012 was fairly straight forward.  You needed to research stuff and build stuff and grow your staff.  This was all to gain more satellites, thus increasing your income.  Apparently Firaxis didn't like how cut and dry this was, so they completely changed the base management aspect and hid every bit of information behind a wall of obfuscation.  Let's say you want to fly your base to gather supplies.  The game tells you there are supplies waiting, and that it will take 4 day to collect them.  So you fly to the supplies and start waiting.  Within seconds, a red dot is added to the alien advancement gauge.  You are one step closer to losing the game.  In reality, this gauge isn't all that important, but its inclusion stresses out players for the first 5 - 10 hours.  Whatever, you shrug it off and keep waiting for the supplies.  Seconds later, you are presented with 3 bad Dark Events".  These happen monthly.  You get the ability to prevent one of them.  The others will happen.  Sometimes just one of them
date: other times both of them.  It seems random and just adds more confusion and stress.  And just to make things even more stressful
recommended: they don't tell you what the third dark event is.  You have to pay to unlock that information.  Sometimes you won't have the money to do so.\n\nYou start off with one scientist and one engineer.  You are not really told how to get more.  You can't use your knowledge of Xcom 2012 for this

reviewText:
I have just finished playing XCOM 2 and here are my thoughts about the entire experience.

XCOM2 did some great things but executed the overall game poorly.

TLDR:
Until FRAXIS can deliver a polished product onto the market, they will not deserve money or respect.

Good things about XCOM2
- Music was great and I enjoyed the atmosphere it created
- Graphics were pretty good even though I had to run the game with minimum options for the sake of performance
- Great enemy diversity compared to XCOM EU/EW, each had their own unique look and actions
- Hacking mechanic did not seem like a gimmick but a solid tactic
- New classes are fun to play with, Psi ops are particularly awesome
- Diverse grenade/ammo types in the research tree

- Lack of overall polish for the following reasons
- HUD is pretty much the same in EU/EW
- HUD mods vastly improves gameplay

reviewText:
Xcom2 is a difficult and challenging game. If anyone new is thinking about getting it I suggest lots of research and learning on how to apply the game's available mechanics successfully. My perspective is purely from some one who's new to the series and haven't played much turn based strategy in the past.

Much of your success will be based on probability rolls. What this means is, even if your shot has an 85% chance of success, you could still very well fail. It can be infuriating, but careful planning and smart use of the tools available can very much help mitigate some of that frustration.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aiLjQMk2opg
I've mentioned that this is a difficult game, and indeed the learning curve is very high but strangely enough, understanding the core mechanics was easy and well paced. Learning how to apply them is the challenging part.

Overally XCOM2 is a very satisfying game when things go according to plan, but can be infuriating when it doesn't. I like it!

reviewText:
If we purely look at the content, the game is absolutely great. Possibly the best thing that developers have introduced are procedurally generated maps. Maps are not random, instead they are a combination of huge number of ‘modules’ (sets of these modules are exclusive to locations) that are picked and shuffled in a new way every time you start a game. If that was not enough, there is a number of weather conditions that take place – rain, night, flying burning ashes, etc.

Classes have been revised, now you have five of them (sword person; hacker; sniper; heavy; and psi-soldier) and sixth will be added as part of the pre-purchase DLCs later this year. I really like the new psi mechanic, you now train your psi soldiers within the base, but you can take them to mission when needed and they will jump in back to complete their current education upon return to the base. If you train the psi-soldier long enough, they become a bit too powerful.

Gameplay wise, the game is slightly tougher than ‘XCOM: Enemy Unknown’ and at the same time, I found it mostly more enjoyable to play.

Downsides? Visual glitches and a few bugs here and there. Until they are fixed, there is no point to even try completing the game on Iron Man difficulty. Quality Assurance is not exactly the strong part of Feraxis. I hope that they will fix them soon, as they did with the first XCOM and Civ 5.

6/10
XCOM 2 reminds me why I didn't quite like XCOM EU when I played it on console.

If you've read around at all, the usual suspects criticizing this game aren't exactly wrong in their gripes about XCOM's core gameplay mechanics:

This Game Is a Roulette Table

No pun intended on this game's apparent seeded RNG mechanic (That's a Random Number Generator for you non-nerds).

Seeded RNG would be more like a loaded digital slot machine, which is exaclty how is games core mechanics funtion, but anyways...

I love strategy games, so I know quite a bit about the niche, from classic cardboard table tops like Chess, Risk, Catan to old school computer titles like Starcraft, Warfrcat, Z etc. to modern day games like Front Mission, Homeworld, and so forth. But, XCOM feels more like being in a sketchy casino rather than a strategy game; It's like betting a big stack of money on an post-apocalyptic alien invasion coin flip.

The never ending dice rolls is what takes so much away from this game. No matter what amount of skill a player has in this game, randomness is what sends you spinning out of control, epecially in missions on the harder difficulties.

There is so much work lost through random-chance character deaths and mission losses, that any enjoyment and reward are overshadowed from the amount of frustration and hours of grinding and reattemps.

And I can attest. I completed the last game on its hardest difficulty and played this one on its Legendary Ironman" mode just to say that I did. So

reviewText:
The RNG in this game is horrible. Some turns you will do everything horribly wrong but still win due to luck, the next turn get everything right and still die to luck.

I have had a high ranking soldier be killed in one shot from full health due to a crit (by a lowly ADVENT trooper) whilst in high cover with a smoke grenade on him. Why should it be possible to crit anyone in high cover? Also I have, on many occasions, set my whole squad to overwatch whilst concealed to lay the perfect ambush to have only 2 out of the 6 troops fire and the other 4 sit there watching, despite the enemy running right past them. Also I have had crazy things like an enemy move, be killed by overwatch, respawn, move again, then kill one of my soldiers all in one turn. Not to mention a few times Chryssalid's have spawned from beyond the fog of war, moved, and attacked (sometimes 3 of them at once) in one turn before I have even revealed them or had any chance to defend myself.

I'm not sure if any of the above is intended but it sure as hell makes any kind of tactical planning near impossible.

Also it runs horribly. The FPS is way lower than games which look much better than this, the camera constantly bugs out, the load times are ridiculous even on an SSD and it constantly hitches and stutters for no apparent reason.

There are some positives to this game, such as the character customisation however it is hard to enjoy this because for some reason the game lags like hell during the character customisation screen, dropping to 15fps whilst using only 30% of my GPU and CPU.

I was a massive fan of XCOM:EU and EW (with 137 hours in them). So it is with a heavy heart I have to say I cannot recommend this game. The RNG frustrations were definitely present in EU and EW however with this game they seem to be off the charts. It is for that reason and the performance issues that I cannot recommend this game in its current state.

As a side note I have no idea where all these 9+/10 reviews from the professional critics are coming from, were they playing a different version of the game to us? The steam user reviews should speak for themselves.

reviewText:
I don't want to write a giant wall of text, so i will keep it short (or atleast try to) and summarize the pros and cons of this game. Please keep in mind that these are based on my own experience with this game. Some people have little to no issues with this game. That is why the reviews are not all negative nor are they all positive. Anyhow, back to the pros and cons:

Pros:
- it has the potential to be a great game, if playable (some recurring new mechanics that i did enjoy: timed missions,
blacksites and class mechanics (all classes are good and none of the builds are inherently weaker than the other builds.
It really depends on the mission, to determine which build is more efficient. Also, don't be afraid to experiment with
your builds. You have the option to retrain your soldiers at some point in the game.)
- most issues people have with this game are fixable
- a great and friendly community (a lot of people, who have small performance issues, can find help in the steamforums
of XCom 2)

Cons:
- crashes and freezes that leads to crashes (black, grey, red, blue screens, i have experienced them all atleast once in the
last 4 days)
- poor optimization (low to mediocre fps even on high end rigs)
- a lot of bugs and/or glitches ranging from aliens detecting/shooting you through walls to allies sinking in the floor
- poor technical support on the side of the developers (a friend of mine was advised to use the same strategy as with
XCom EU/EW. That is to play untill you crash/freeze with XCom EU/EW, then start up XCom 2 and play untill you reset
your pc. Repeat this process, if you want to play XCom 2 without black screen (or whatever colour you're
experiencing))
- no patch announcements, so you can forget about short term improvements and/or resolutions.

Conclusion (Well, i did promise to keep it short, so here are my final thoughts regarding XCom 2):
I loved XCom EU/EW and XCom LW, but sadly i am unable to enjoy and play XCom 2 due to technical difficulties. So even if i wanted to, i just can't recommend this game to anyone, untill the game is properly patched. Which is a shame, because the game has a lot of potential. I just have to wait a few weeks (or more likely months) for the game to be patched, so i can enjoy the game thoroughly and on my own terms, instead of making compromises due to poor optimization and or technical issues.

I sincerely hope, that i have dissuaded atleast some of you from buying this game in its current state, because i really want you gents and/or ladies out there, to have a great and memorable (first) experience with this fantastic franchise.

Cheers!

XCOM 2 promises to be a great game at some point, so I feel a bit bad about writing a negative review, but the state of the game right now is that of a beta version and definitely not that of a full price title.

Apart from the frequent camera glitches which we know and love from the first part, I've encountered a ton of new and sometimes game-breaking bugs (e.g. assaults warping through walls when doing their slash-attack, soldiers getting stuck, issues with the new concealment system) which make me seriously question Firaxis's quality control.

If you intend to play this game, do not repeat my mistake of playing in Ironman mode. Having just lost half of my squad by getting stuck in mid-air, I decided to do what Firaxis should have done: give the developers a few more months to finish the game.

reviewText:
XCOM 2 is a game that tries too hard to be XCOM: Enemy unknown, by slightly changing the names of the classes and by introducing a timer and new aliens.
XCOM2 Hasn’t learned the difference between “hard” and “punishing”. In XCOM: Enemy unknown both sides try to get the upper hand, the aliens through number and brute strength while the player can achieve the goals through destruction of terrain and positioning to flank, while in XCOM 2 if you don’t kill everything that you see in the turn that your unfortunate eyes sees them, which you won’t with the few hundred of them, which is understandable with the story, but with massive amount of health and damage that your B-B guns will merely tickle the Muton that will evaporate on your cavalry impersonator by looking at it funny. In addition, even XCOM: UFO defence which is known for being difficult is just difficult, not punishing. The aliens have a larger range and are usually hidden, so you have to be careful as you move, unlike in XCOM 2 where the Cortex will disable all of your weapons, teleport behind you and kill the only useful team member you have all in the same turn which will cause the animalistic “super soldiers” to go into a panic, run out of cover and then get immediately shot by whatever waits for them.
XCOM: Enemy Unknown glitches are fun. You grapple onto a ledge and you get teleported under where you started, or by doing a Chryssalid dance with the dumb AI, while in XCOM 2: If you log out of the game while something is building, which you probably will as doing more than one mission at a time is about as desirable as grinding teeth against a cats ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, the building suddenly doesn’t exist, all the days that you waited for it have gone to waste, and the materials you invested into it are now gone. I mean, it’s not like you really need those Psi operatives to make the game playable.
We’ve come this far without talking about the timer. XCOM 2 has introduced a timer for practically every mission, which isn’t fun, it’s just artificial difficulty that will make you panic. If you don’t do the mission in the time limit, the world becomes that much worse, everyone blames you while you were standing on a roof trying to not get absolutely everyone killed with the mass amount of aliens the game throws at you. Take Jet Set Radio into account: Would be an amazing game but gave everything a time limit, but there it made sense as it’s supposed to be a fast paced hip hop game.
If you wanted to buy XCOM 2, my advice is: Don’t. I’m going to play some more XCOM: Enemy unknown.

reviewText: I just want to start off by saying that at its core, this game is phenominal. Enemy variety is plentiful and is for the most part really well balanced. The game is a decent looking game too. Sadly, the enemy variety sort of goes out the window late game and the longer you play, the worse performance gets due to a nasty memory leak. The Avenger base isn't anything special. It's just slightly better than it was in EU and not really worth mentioning. Oh, and the sound design, both with the in game voices and sound effects to the phenominal score is nothing short of amazing. I absolutely LOVE this game. XCOM has always been a series that I've LOVED since I was a child. And because of the love that I have for the series, I HATE writing a negative review on this game. You see, aside from the core aspect being amazing, that's really the only positive thing I can say about this game. It's quite clear that this game seriously lacks polish. There's even evidence that the developers actually panic patched the game at the last minute to make it harder. And there lies the problem with XCOM 2. The XCOM games have never been hard, challenging yes, but never hard. This game however is hard for all the wrong reasons. From spawning 2 Archons and 2 Advent elite troopers at the LZ of a timed mission (and then landing another 3 troopers ON the LZ making it 7 foes to face) to having your troopers caught during the concealment" phase without so much as a warning to let the players know that said troopers can actually see behind the 2 buildings you're at. The game honestly feels completely botched. I NEVER felt screwed over when I played the older XCOM games or Enemy Unknown/ WIthin. I've always played on the harder difficulties to make it more challenging. The AI has ALWAYS cheated in the older games (it's a fact)

reviewText: I loved the game from the start. Even though in any graphical configuration but for minimal the game was full of lag - a problem I hadn´t have with any game in my current pc before, I didn´t mind as the gameplay was fantastic. The innovations and changes refreshed the serie and everything feels different from the previous XCOM even though a lot of concepts are unchanged. In some reviews people complained about the turns limits, but in all the missions that I played that had those, I didn´t need to rush too much and managed to complete the objectives just in time with few turns remaining in a way that it seemed that the number of turns was well balanced - neither making the mission too rushed nor letting you move slowly abusing overwatchs. However, soon the crashes started. Firstly, I tried hard to make excuses such as that the problem was with my computer or that it was just something occasional so I could just let it pass and keep playing. But they persisted and striked everywhere: in the middle of a mission, in a loading screen, in the geoscape, etc. And they have the peculiarity of even if I reloaded a save happening again if I tried to do the same thing that resulted in the first crash, which worsened substantially the problem. In the end I couldn´t evade from the obvious and unfortunate conclusion that the game was UNPLAYABLE - at least in my PC, but I didn´t have such problems with any other game before. Certainly this will be fixed in the first patches for the game but it is rather frustrating to have bought this game in presale and to have waited so anxiously for its launch to receive a product unplayable and to have to wait more for the patches to be able to properly play it. Anyway, it may be that the problems I am having do not extend to all players, but if you are thinking on buying XCOM 2, the safest route would be to wait for the game to be fixed. A part from those problems, the game is great and I will totally recommend it once it hopefully becomes completelly functional and playable.

reviewText:
Now that the patches are out this game became a lot better. The infamous stuttering of the loading videos and the Avenger management screen has not plagued my machine that much, but it was looking a tad ridiculous. (I repeat, it appears to be fixed.)

Disclaimer: I am a savescummer. There is no way in this Universe that I will ever try it on Ironman.

XCOM, our beloved super secret organisation is back with a vengeance, this time as a terro... a resistance movement who engage in kidnapping, property damage (extensively so), murder, mayhem, research and development. It's faithful to the classic three-layer design (global strategy and expansion; base management, R&D, recruitment and training; actually shooting aliens in the face on a turn based tactical screen (where face is applicable)). It continues what XCOM:Enemy Unknown started and improved it.

The good:
- it's everything I love about XCOM
- a lot more diverse set of terrains in the tactical layer
- creatively redesigned classes (they are still good but different enough to think a bit
- cool new weapons
- finally you do not have to take the damn things alive
- finally, faces
- soldier customisation options through the roof
- loot system
- time limits that add a sense of urgency to the gameplay
- concealment for all your ambushing needs

The mediocre:
- acceptable storyline that somehow manages to wriggle out of the confines of XCOM:EU's ending
- solid characters
- decent ending
- some soldier development options were useless for me (think twice before choosing extra armor for the Grenadier instead of armour shredding capability)
- plenty of bottlenecks in the game, got to think three steps ahead (I like it but it can be frustrating at first)

The bad:
- ridiculous misses in the tactical gameplay (five missed shots in Overwatch, hell yeah!)
- line and splash effect placements are wonky (double-check the affected area before launching a grenade)
- the Hellish Stutter may still be present on some rigs, I dunno
- solid surfaces can be seen through at times, ending in megatriggers (you will see what I mean).

reviewText:
Previous review was about the spike in difficulty (enemies gets a free move on you, they have OP abilities from start, there are timers for every thing, and so on) but those are not really problems any more with all the mods that came out in the weeks after this games release.

What is still in the game thou, and something that maybe will never get fixed is the sheer stupidity in the combat system. I'm not far in to the game (as I waited for mods to even be able to play it) and the amount of bullcrap this game has done is staggering.

Enemies will see your sneaking, fully in cover soldiers when they are sneaking on top of a roof two floors up. They have some sixth sense (or wallhacks) and will spot you (and shoot you) from positions that defy all logic or fairness. The game will give you some really neat action shots of your guy shooting an enemy thru a floor, a wall and a busstop. Boy, those are some strong bullets you have in your rifle there soldier!

and as every one knows by now, the game runs like crap. It will make your video card work a staggering 116% (as reported by MSI afterburner, GPU meter and HWmonitor) so you better have it water cooled!

TL;DR unplayable in it's vanilla state for everyone but the already initiated, the game will constantly cheat" and it will take your system to the breaking point no matter the hardware."

reviewText:
In its current state I wouldn't recommend it. Not only are there balance issues but the campaign mechanics are poorly explained, meaning you'll most likely lose the game and have to start over. The second time will go better since you now know what the game should've told you in the first place (black sites only remove a few pips from the avatar project, they don't reset it, your main goal should be taking out those as fast as possible).

So to sum up the issues point by point:
- Poorly explaind Avatar Project/campaign
- Balance issues on missions, even on normal
- While people say base building has been simplified it still has an optimal build order. If you don't know it you're screwed.
- Turn limits on almost every mission exacerbate balance issues
- Bugs galaore. Most are just visual and can be ignored but others affect gameplay.
- Major performance issues even with a 980

Wait for balance and performance patches.

reviewText:
Still the same card-game mechanics, except this time the game itself isn't even sure if it wants to be Mass Effect 2-like, C&C4-like, XCOM-like or something else-like.

More timers, more pressure that isn't quite justified, less balance, most things that were bad about XCOM are still unchanged. The one thing that was fixed was how overwatch targets are handled - units do not waste their overwatch shots on downed enemies anymore if they have a different target on that same turn.

Of course, wierd pauses pretty much everywhere are still here; poor intel (actually, criminally poor intel, lore-wise) is still here; atmospheric immersion is worse, ironically because there is more of it - more points of failure have emerged.

XCOM you could play while drinking a beer and watching what was on your screen like a nineties action flick - brave americans kicked some alien ♥♥♥ and looked cool doing it.
This game doesn't play like this. It doesn't even play like a 'rebel tactics'.

So all in all, while being graphically an upgrade over XCOM, logically and atmospherically it may well be quite the opposite.


Disappointment reigns.

reviewText:
XCOM is a tough kind of game to sell, because when it's good it's bad and when it's bad it's bad. The best time you can have in XCOM is when you're scraping on the skin of your teeth with one soldier dead and another one bleeding out and a sectoid waving his finger ominously in the distance, and so it's hard to sell to someone who just wants an easy time. Thankfully this is the sequel, so presumably everyone here is a masochist who enjoys feeling like they've lost even when they've won.

The first thing that surprised me in XCOM 2 is how much they've expanded the unit customization. Unlike in the previous game, which was somewhat dull in soldier clothes and left me just giving everyone the classic Guile hair, 2 features a pretty wide variety of glasses, hats, hair, beards, and other ways to form a personal relationship with your soldiers before they're eviscerated before your eyes because of your own orders, blood which will never wash from your hands. You can even choose from different arms, legs, and torsos for each type of armor, though the later armors usually have less variety than the early one.

The game also has a stronger emphasis on story, with more cutscenes and development to the characters. I thought it was a welcome addition, though it does leave things slightly less resolved at the end than I would've liked. Most of the enemies are reworked versions of the old ones, but there are a few new ones here and there, and they all perform a bit differently enough to give veterans a surprise every now and then. There are still the usual customization options for your soldiers' abilities, but the more interesting ones from Enemy Within like genetic modification and augmentation are missing, leaving the game feeling like there's something more interesting hiding in that expansion pass. Other things like UFO landings also return, but they don't seem to have any real significance like they did in EU aside from just being minor resource grabs. My only actual problem with the gameplay is that in some ways it feels like more of the same in a bad way - they introduce a Concealment feature where your soldiers start some missions hidden and can ambush the enemies, reversing the typical xcom formula where you're the one being ambushed and fitting in with the game's guerilla warfare theme, but after you break concealment the first time it's gone for good except for special skill-based circumstances, and after that the game just starts with the same traditional gameplay. I'm not wanting to change the game into Invisible Inc. or anything, but I think it would be interesting for some of the more low-key missions like hacking a relay to be able to done with a small squad in stealth (or maybe it can - in my game whenever I tried there would be humans blocking the doors to every building, but maybe I just had bad luck). Another thing in this vein that bothered me is that almost every mission in the game requires you to kill all the aliens, rather than just do your work and get out. This is something that made sense in the old games, since you were defending earth from invaders, but in XCOM 2 they've already taken over, and killing this tiny group of aliens is completely inconsequential to their overall effort.

But while I overall enjoyed the game outside of those minor flaws, the big problem with this game is the actual build quality. On my GTX 970 and overclocked i5, I managed about 15 fps on the main menu scene, with maybe 20 to 30 in-game. This isn't necessarily a problem since it's a turn-based strategy game, but the problems got worse as the game went on. Reaction shots would sometimes cause the game to hang in front of the character shooting for several moments, enemies would stand still for upwards of 30 seconds before moving, just flying to the single-screen or loading a small map with one building might take 30 seconds or more on an SSD, etc - and that's not even going into all the times characters would go flying around the map or robots would get stuck in trees. During the final fight my game crashed 5 times, and on 2 of those crashes it corrupted my autosaves and made me start back 10 minutes or so. It even caused my computer to bluescreen at one point. The build quality is so terrible that it makes me think that the only reason the game is PC-exclusive is because they couldn't get it to even boot up on a console without it immediately melting.

Overall, XCOM 2 is a game that's still good enough for me to recommend, but just know that you're going to have to take some bad in order to get the good. Maybe in the future Firaxis will patch the game, but in the mean time you might want to double-check your specs before jumping on.

reviewText:
What a let down.   Game is only a short 20-30 hours tops.   Very linear, extra simplified over the other Xcom remake, has some annoying game save corruption and other odd perf bugs.   The game has really strayed far from what X-com is about.  Hopefully someone will mod in a real xcom game here.

Instead of tactical game play, there are tons of missions where you have to do something in a small fixed number of turns (ie, defend/destory X object in 6 turns.)  this means you just have to rush to the objective and end up losing tons of units less you save scum or don't care and just go and lose the mission.

Instead of a really good AI, they got lazy and just added in teleporting monsters (teleport next to your guy, free shot, rinse repeat),  ones that have very high move rates so they can close in on you in one turn even if you setup a shop tacticaly a few screens away.

Due to the forced events that control game time, the game has limited replayability (compared to say X-Com:UD or X-com:TFTD.)

Save your money, buy it for a one time $5-10 expiernce when it goes on sale.

reviewText: This game probably has a lot of potential, but it's too broken to know for sure.  Many times I would have a soldier aim at one enemy, but then shoot at another one that I didn't intend because of some glitch.  The camera has an odd tendency to slowly drift on its own when you're planning a movement or aiming a grenade which results in leaving your soldier in the open or missing a toss.  Whenever an NCP in the game talks to you on the radio, you're not able to take any action, and there is ALOT of radio chatter, which is usually reminding you of mission objectives that you already know or telling you about the mission timer of which you're already well aware.  There is an option that makes it seem like you can reduce this needless dialogue, but it has no noticeable effect, making missions last much longer than they need to and adding frustration to the already broken system.  It's disappointing to have the experience ruined by game glitches, bugs, and wasted time, and until they fix these problems, I cannot recommend playing this game.  Was very excited for XCOM 2, but ultimately very disappointed and frustrated.

reviewText:
The moment you see first intriguing cutscenes and get introduced to new core gameplay features (concealement, hacking, looting etc), the realization strikes you - they did it again and sleepless nights are imminent. Good old things are left intact, some things are changed to feel fresh (promotions/abilities) and 20% are all new things that keep you wondering and discovering. Feels like coming back home after 3 years of shuffling through subpar TBS games. All that with stunning visuals like we've never seen in any other turn-based strategy.

TL;DR It's a new benchmark for AAA TBS.

End game UPDATE: campaign-wise this game feels longer than XCOM 1. All tactical missions feel fresh and less tedious, except 'terror missions' which are way too much blood and time pressure, and overall I feel there were not enough missions without timer. Metagame made in a way of more restricting manner, it may be not so, but it feels like that, with more pressure, 'doomsday counter'  etc. Skill progression is interesting and enjoyable, feels fresh, especially for psi soldiers. Base building feels a bit dumbed down but still different when taking in account staff management part. Item building is new but feels very confusing, it may harm campaign progress for many players. With all that I confirm my first impression that developers took the right ratio for new vs familiar things. And for all the right places. The only regret is developers haven't left much space for big story DLCs so that I could shower them with money and march on with my base and soldiers.

reviewText:
(05/02/2016)

I dunno, feeling bit iffy.

97% flanking shots missing
every mission is a race against time.
I dunno

Played x-com 1 on impossible, and it's got less bu****it shots than this one does on 'classic'

Left me with a strange feeling.
Doesn't feel like x-com in any way.
Gonna give it some more time.
But it's allready drained all my energy today.

Left with a sort of sad, empty feeling.
My expectations where too high I guess

Edit: (06/02/2016)

Not only that, but it is very clear the game got rushed.
Too many bugs ruin the entire experience.

One time you can't see what you're hacking, as the camera thinks holding a wall in front of your screen is more interesting. Another time, you see an enemy soldier slow-walking out of his position, rubberband back to where he was. Then he performs the same move, and suddenly one of your own soldiers drops dead without anything attacking him.

When trying to move your squad somewhere in cover, checking out good locations, the camera also loves to jerk back to the character every 2 seconds.
Picking a good spot can thus result in the wrong tile being targetted instead, ruining everything.
On other times, targetting the correct spot refuses to respond to the move command untill you wiggle the mouse around a bit.

Too much 'lagging' and extremely long loading screens ruin the experience even more.
A high-end computer turns into a vacuum cleaner and has trouble switching smoothly from one screen to another.
This is especially the case in between missions.
Even returning back to base gives you enough time to do some groceries.
By the time you get back, it may have finally loaded.

There's also too much aggravation during missions.
A 99% hit shot at point blank range against a berserker decides to result in a miss.
And more too often, do enemies with 20% chance to hit your people, get a perfect shot at them.

Launching/throwing grenades now 'locks' to a tile.
No more free-aiming, when you know you could hit 3 targets if it didn't force you in this position.
Resulting in more too often, having to choose between hitting 1 big enemy, or 2 smaller ones.
While free-aiming could perfectly get all of them.

X-COM 1 had me hooked from day 1, and still makes me play it with a lot of pleasure on impossible difficulty.

X-COM 2 is depressing me to a point, where my energy is drained. And I must even push myself to turn the game on.

It definately needs a decent fix at the point of this writing.
Looked forward to this one so hard.
Never have I been disappointed so horrendously before.
Guess I expected too much.

Edit: (07/02/2016)

Now even more bugs pop up, as 2 mutons and a berserker show up.
Having hit a regular muton with fire ammo, he is going to burn to death on his next turn.
So the heavy can focus on the berserker.
No matter how many times I reload this particular save, the heavy keeps firing at the near-death muton, no matter how many times I try to force him to shoot the berserker.
There is even the third one in his sight, and that one isn't even an option when klicking it's icon.
The grenadier guy wants to finish off the dead muton, no matter what.
(spoiler): If even troops start taking random orders (not even disoriented or anything), then central could have saved the trouble of freeing the commander. Since these freedom fighters take orders of their own anyway.

Watch the bug here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lasbv6-ihrk&feature=youtu.be

And after trying to move a ranger in close from a different angle (since the suggested path makes him open), the game suffers a critical crash.

The game definately needs a stabilize protocol at it's current state.

Edit: (08/02/2016)

Bugs keep popping up left and right.
Game crashes, wrong actions being taken, etc...
Launch grenade! ..... evac point gets marked instead... -.-
Wait... wut?
For 3 days, I've been sighing and staring depressed at the screen how one horrid bug after another unfolds.
When you're reloading the same file 10 times in a row, hoping the bug will not trigger this time, you know you got some real quality on your hands.

Also, why do extract data missions require you to kill all aliens as well?
Package is secured, there's 135464645 billion more aliens around on the entire planet.
But killing 3 more is a must to have the objective completed (or it's marked as failed).
Sir, we got the data allready? -.-

Just sitting, feeling your life drain away from all the stupidity that occurs, and sighing the day away.
I thought games where meant to be interesting and entertaining?
Even the people living with me are affected by the way this just brings me into a dark depression.

I understand there some masochists out there, who love seeing their entire squad get bludgeoned.
I just want to see my people make it through the day and actually advance (without stumbling into another 50 bugs).

Left with an empty feeling.
Forcefully pushing myself to advance.
Why am I not playing boshy or another anger-inducing game then?
Because X-COM did things right.
Yes... did.
This one... it's something... but it's not X-COM...

Final report (10/02/2016):

After 5 days, beating the game on commander (classic) difficulty, I can finally make my final report.

And sadly enough, it still remains a non-recommended from my point of view.
Replayability is extremely low compared to it's predecessor.
The Avatar project counter ensures that you have to, sooner or later, make a move towards the end objective.
This excludes having time enough to explore more, train more troops, and all around have a lengthy ammount of good fun.
The player is constantly being rushed and pushed. The game tells you how much time you have, untill you're forced to end it, taking away the player's freedom entirely.
Thankfully, the modding community is very active. Most likely, there'll be a mod where this avatar project no longer limits your play time.
I loved spending hours in X-COM 1, finding new recruits and exploring their potential. Literally playing for months on one playthrough, in search of assembling those particularly unique good people.

Which also brings me to another minus point: There is no second wave option, once you beat the game.
'None are equal' and 'hidden potential' are nonexistant, 2 of the options which where my favourites.
Once you beat the game, you get the choice to make another playthrough, and that's it.
Only ironman remains, but what's the fun if you can't add in random generators of your choice?

Again, it'll be completely up to the fanbase to make mods for these.

There was also a dissappointing lack of customization options in terms of character creation.
What was promised as an endless ammount of possibilities, ended up in only 6 faces to pick from.
Also props and such, fall pretty short if you look at them.

There's too much 'cheating' going on in the game as well.
Have a patrol passing by, and waiting for them to leave to sneak past?
The moment you do so, the computer decides to send this patrol right to your hiding spot, instead of completing it's patrol route.
Dumbass enemies like the sectopod, andromedon and gatekeeper, destroy their own facilities with their patrols. Showing little to no care given to the facilities in which their own avatar project is being processed. Some patrols even refuse to move, when your team is hidden away, waiting for them to pass. Resulting in an endless loop of ending your turn, waiting for these stubborn guys to move on.
This ruins the stealth aspect of geurilla attacks, negating them pretty much entirely.
Operating in shadows is only good for getting that first scout off. It pretty much ends in guns ablazing. An attempt at being groundbreaking, but failing to do it's part.

If you plan to play the game vanilla only;
Wait untill it's on sale.
With the game now completed, it fails to keep me in a grip like X-COM 1 did.

reviewText:
Firaxis is kinda infamous for buggy releases but this time prelease reviews were claiming it's relatively free of game-stopping bugs, only chock-full of visual animation/camera bugs. While it seems like there aren't a ton of of game-stopping bugs there's still one pretty major one: During any mission the game can crash and corrupt every single save made during the mission, including autosaves. On ironman this means game-over - you have no chance of salvaging the run. Without ironman you can go back to the latest save made on the world map - though considering that the intended/prefered way to play xcom as stated by the devs is ironman a bug like this is unacceptable. Personally I ran into this bug around 3 times even before the final mission but what takes the cake is that this bug seems to be most common during the final mission - several prominent streamers had their ironman-run killed right during the final mission due to this bug and one streamer I occasionally watch is now waiting until there are any fixes for this bug before attempting the final mission.

Other noteworthy bugs include the enemy AI completely borking out which in turn has the effect that the AI's turn takes an abnormal and aggravatingly long time while actually remaining completely stationary and inactive.

Another common bug is the alien viper enemy being able to use their tongue-pull to pull your soldiers without any line of sight and through entire buildings.

Combine these technical issues and game-stopping bugs and the extremely poor optimization that a lof of people already have drawn attention to and I don't see how Xcom 2 deserves to be supported/bought at full prize in its current state. If you put aside the technical issues Xcom 2 is a fairly fun and decent squad-based TBS/RNG-BS game and would be worth the full prize for fans of the genre like myself - in its current state it's a lot less clear cut.

My advice would be to hold off and wait until patches are out and while you're at you might just as well wait for a sale. Personally I won't buy any Firaxis game at launch anymore and instead hold out for patches and sales. At this point I just don't trust Firaxis to not release a game with game-stopping bugs and I don't think they should be rewarded with full-prize sales for a MO like that.

reviewText:
First: Love the game, Love the gameplay and Xcom series is my favorite series of all time, by a very large margin.

Having said that: This game is unplayable.  I'm playing with a Nvidia 4gig 460 GTX, and a 4.7ghz 8 core AMD cpu which should run this at a reasable rate.

Min settings: caps at 27 FPS.  Max settings (excep AA is turned way down) 25 FPS.  Something is just wrong there.  This, I could actually tolerate.

However: The crashes are so prolific it's unplayable.  It crashed 3 times at different points in the tutorial, two of them during cutscenes.  Disabled tutorial, and I get 20-30 crashes per mission.  I can usually get 1-4 turns off before it hardlocks my PC.  I've went through about 40 hours of troubleshooting, and without a doubt it is the the game software.  It's not my hardware, it's not over heating, it's not drivers, it's not corrupted software.  The software itself repeatedly crashes on a significant number of people.

Judging by the overwhelming number of compliants of poor performance and random crashes, it's clear they did not beta test this properly.

reviewText:
XCOM 2 is to XCOM what Beyond Earth is to Civ V. The same game, made slightly different and released with a lot less features than you might come to expect after playing the previous game. If you're unfamiliar, Firaxis seems to be making a habit of releasing the bare minimum required to catch people's interest and to then release $50 expansions that slowly bring the game in line with what you were actually expecting.


The game plays out much the same way, including all the graphical bugs we know and love from the previous game. There's no real graphical change, just a slight alteration in overall aesthetic. The Avenger is a simplified xcom base with an ideal layout that is obvious once you work out just what things do. Put the power on the big power things, put the workshop in the middle and then build everything. The interface is completely unchanged feeling exceptionally clunky with mouse and keyboard, especially when trying to use area of effect abilities such as grenades. You don't have any mechs of any sort this time, just soldiers which are divided in to five classes now, mostly the same as the previous game just psionic is now its own class that is easier to secure a soldier for and brings back memories of an avenger full of Psi Amps considering how strong it is.


There's a lot more I could say about this game. It's not a bad game, don't get me wrong... but there's no way I could recommend it to anybody. This has sealed the deal for me on this developer. Wait until they're making xcom 3 and then buy a bundle with the full game when it's on special. Spend the $90 you'll end up saving somewhere else, perhaps on a developer who's willing to give you your money's worth on release.

reviewText:
All in all, a fun continuation of the Xcom series. If you enjoyed the first game, you will probably enjoy this.

That said, if you are looking for big improvements on the first game, you may be disapointed. Much of the variety from the original (including the expansion) is not in the game. There is a really streamlined version of troop enhancements and MEC style troops, but it is not near as diverse or satisfying as the previous expansion allowed.

Everything else is repeated pretty much right from the base game in a lot of ways except ship combat was completely removed. Considering that, it is disapointing Xcom 2 didn't do a bit more, but Firaxis as a developer is pretty well known for phoning in sequels these days. I don't mind that they didn't even attempt to improve on the interceptor game, but if it is going to be removed, players should see new content added. One could argue that the mobile base is that new content, but really it is the exact same base design mechanic as before with a different UI for interacting with the global map. That is about all it does.

Also, the economy is actually pretty bad. Everything special in the game costs elerium cores, which is random drop only from enemies. In effect, you end up with tons of alloy and elerium, but nothing to do with it if you didn't save those elerium cores. It is nice that core upgrades, like switching to laser weapons (well, I think its called magnetic, but whatever) just upgrades all your guns and don't require individual construction.

Difficulty wise, at least on normal/veteran, it felt a bit easier due to increased access to AoE, high damage ordinance. It really isn't that hard to get everyone sporting a rocket launcher in a reasonable amount of time and that is one of the weakest options available. A few other balance bits felt off as well, though the special weapons are satisfying to use.

It could have been more, but it is what it is. If you want a fresh Xcom fix, go for it. If you can wait, then I would highly recommend waiting for a sale. As it stands, it is hard to justify this game as being worth full price.

reviewText:
TL,DR Version:

If you are looking for a challenge and got the system to run it, this game is for you.


Long Version:

Good game overall, suffers from some technical issues here and there. Seems to be fixed as of now.
However it is HUGE in terms of datavolume (~25GB) so you better plan some extra time for the download.
The graphics are fancy yet require quite the system to run with decent fps-rates. The storyline is interesting aswell as the tides have turned and you are kind of in the role the Aliens had before. The new classes are interesting too but sadly the melee aspect which firaxis tried to implement seems kind of weak and therefore (in most but not all cases) useless. A lot of missions have a time restraint early (I got the feeling this changed later on) and so does the genereal mission. So this is unlike XCOM: Enemy Unknown. I know a lot of people bragged about that, but I don't think it's that big of an issue. The limits in missions can hurt but also force you to take smarter and more effective decisions. While challenging, I think this would have worked better as a feature for the IronManmode. The general limit makes you feel an urge to go on and maybe also a bit of unrest or even panic which I like a lot. On the other hand this limit can be kept in check by regulary doing special missions which wasn't so hard in the end. It also feels like the difficulty went up a notch which is not a bad thing.

I enjoyed it a lot but somehow liked Enemy Unknown/Within a little bit better.

reviewText:
I like this game, believe me. But in the current state the game is in, i dont think its worth buying.

Pros
1. Incredibly challenging, as the game forces you to make decisions you may or may not like, which gives you a feeling that i cant describe to you
2. Gameplay is solid, using turn based strategy and combat.
3. Unique enemies to fight again, no longer copy and paste swarms of zerg, or crafty eldar
4. An immersive story, which makes you feel like your actually playing and fighting for a cause
5. Tons of customization options, make your soldiers look like friends and family
6. The game is very moddable, and still lets you get achievements with mods

Cons
1. The game runs like crap, even with people who have monsters of a computer. The game is very poorly optimized. Live through minimal graphics with twenty to thirty FPS to single frames per second with high graphic options
2. The AI can sometimes be really unfair, or at other times a complete idiot, walking right into your overwatches
3. The game has too much RNG, watch as a single ADVENT runt dodges almost every shot, and crits your soldier, gravely wounding them
4. The game will sometimes stop after encountering a certain thing, and after a short pause it will tell you something you will mostly ignore
5. Bugs and glitches galore
6. It would be nice to have a 'Versus Mode' where one person plays as the ADVENT Coalation, and one as XCOM. XCOM would research new technologies, while ADVENT would be able to have aliens in their strike force.

In Conclusion, i like the game, but i strongly suggest that you buy the game later in the year, when it will be more optimized, the bugs ironed out, and possibly rebalances in multiplayer.

reviewText:
May contain minor Spoilers


TL;DR: Not as good as expected. Maybe an Addon will bring more fresh wind but the Story is very thin and Missions get dull really fast. Would give 5/10 with Sideway-Thumb.



The improvements over the first part are good:

- Classes fit their role perfectly and different styles are encouraged (from very mobile agressive to very static lurking). Also the new character customization options are great. However there are some minor balancing problems (Melee of Ranger too weak for the amount of risk, most of the time you can just Run'n'Gun with Shotgun for more damage)

- The rework of the worldmap need you to be more active and gives you the feeling of having more control over the given situation: You can decide to a certain factor, what you're doing and how you're doing it. (more about that later). Also different kinds of Ressources (Info, Ressource, Scientist and Ingenieurs) leave room for your approach to save the world.

- New mechanics like Armor,Melee and weapon upgrades bring some fresh air to the battlefield. Especially armored opponents require more tactical work in fights and changes your Setup and Loadout a lot.

- The new Enemies are fun to play against. Especially the Snake and ADVENT Melee need you to adapt to the situation fast

- Starting in Concealment is an interesting way to let the players feel like hidden agressors and allows for better preparation of the whole sector. Works great!

- The Basemanagment seems very well thought through. There's new buildings which fit perfectly to the game and the old buildings got a great rework. The building part feels less grindy and more impactful on your gameplan.



What didn't went as good as expected for me:

- The Story is dull. A modern version of Nazi-Germany suppressing the population and experimenting with certain civilians." Haven't seen that in a while! reviewText:
Its times like these that I wish Steam had a sideways thumb as this is not a bad game by any means, however it does suffer with a couple of issues.

Let me start by saying that I believe Xcom 2 has the potential to be a great game, it has all that I would like in a Turn Based RPG and I’ve only just scratched the surface, however there are a few balance issues that need to be remedied that make certain things in the game impossible.
I have played just under 10 hours on veteran mode on the opening weekend, and have had some really good moments, however there are certain issues which I know will eventually nullify my enthusiasm.

1) Cover

Cover seems to be a bit pointless. More often than not I lose full health squad members who are either in full cover or in half cover (I understand half cover isn’t always guaranteed). On one occasion I was flanking around the side of a garage with two troops at full health. Soldier 1 was behind a road block and soldier 2 behind the garage wall, this gave me both Half-Cover and Full cover respectively. However this didn’t seem to matter because soldier 1 was hit at distance and died instantly loosing 5 health. Soldier 2 was shot through 2 solid non damaged walls and again was killed (How the enemy would have seen her I don’t know). That doesn’t leave a lot of room for setting up your team and formulating a tactical plan if the enemy can just shoot through cover as if it wasn’t there, this for me is a major issue. I feel that either the enemies are too overpowered or the cover isn’t working as it should do. Surely a concrete roadblock would assure a smidgen of protection.
In another instance, I had a full health rookie behind a barrier; the enemy melee unit ran all the way up so he was positioned on the other side of the barrier (half-cover) and killed me with one thwack to the head.

2) Timed Goals

I have no problem with the idea of a timed goal; however there are 2 issues I feel need to be addressed:
a) Harsh countdown times - The timed goals given are on the whole too short, running and gunning doesn’t work as combined with the above issue of cover being like jelly, it makes getting to the goal impossible and in most cases I lose the majority of my team getting there, just to have to spend all of my supplies on new recruits and thus getting stuck in a vicious cycle. (and this was in the Early game).
b) Random reinforcements are too penalising, as you just have barely enough time to get to the goal. But add in the fact that 75% of the time, reinforcements form behind your team, and just mop up with 1 shot kills.
From what I’ve played of the game, there’s a lot that I’ve enjoyed, there's a lot of potential and I’m genuinely excited about it, but I personally feel there needs to be a re-think when it comes to the cover situation and the harsh countdown timers.

There are also a few performance issues that I believe are being looked into, however, I’m not as badly affected as some.

May contain minor Spoilers


TL;DR: Not as good as expected. Maybe an Addon will bring more fresh wind but the Story is very thin and Missions get dull really fast. Would give 5/10 with Sideway-Thumb.



The improvements over the first part are good:

- Classes fit their role perfectly and different styles are encouraged (from very mobile agressive to very static lurking). Also the new character customization options are great. However there are some minor balancing problems (Melee of Ranger too weak for the amount of risk, most of the time you can just Run'n'Gun with Shotgun for more damage)

- The rework of the worldmap need you to be more active and gives you the feeling of having more control over the given situation: You can decide to a certain factor, what you're doing and how you're doing it. (more about that later). Also different kinds of Ressources (Info, Ressource, Scientist and Ingenieurs) leave room for your approach to save the world.

- New mechanics like Armor,Melee and weapon upgrades bring some fresh air to the battlefield. Especially armored opponents require more tactical work in fights and changes your Setup and Loadout a lot.

- The new Enemies are fun to play against. Especially the Snake and ADVENT Melee need you to adapt to the situation fast

- Starting in Concealment is an interesting way to let the players feel like hidden agressors and allows for better preparation of the whole sector. Works great!

- The Basemanagment seems very well thought through. There's new buildings which fit perfectly to the game and the old buildings got a great rework. The building part feels less grindy and more impactful on your gameplan.

reviewText:
To clarify recommendation, I'm on the fence.  If you're into Xcom.. Buy it.  If you're not. Don't.

As far as a follow on goes, it's good.  Good idea, quite a basic storyline, but it's fairly involving.

The missions after awhile become quite samey.  But they're fun to complete.
The big let down for me is enforced gameplay and timed missions.   I prefer open non linear games.  Xcom 1 was non linear, sure you have to take out aliens, do missions etc but it wasn't forced on you.

In Xcom2 You spend a few days gathering intel, then a few days picking up supplies(money) then you're given a mission, which you can't ignore doing so looses you the game. In fact you can't really ignore any of the missions or you'll either loose the game outright or you'll loose the county you've spent a week getting.

Then there's the avatar project, which even if you hold every country in the world, can still be completed by the aliens.  Your hand is forced throughout the game and during missions via the timer, forcing you to make moves you'd never make without the timer.  Forcing you to rush and loose essentially.

The game world is excellent, the ai in general is very good, sure there's issues with line of sight and some cosmetic glitches but overall the idea" of the game is superb.

It is just let down by poor balancing

reviewText:
It is mindboggling to me that I can run Witcher 3 on med-high settings on my 2-year old laptop but XCOM 2 crashes on a coinflip doing physics calculations when I blaster bomb a building apart. I love this game wholeheartedly and I want to play all day but the random crashing just became too much to handle. Please note I am not holding up Witcher 3 as a paragon of stability, just a very good looking cpu intensive game.

This is a heartfelt and emotional plea to all game devs about QA testing: If you're not making Crysis and very upfront about making Crysis, please QA test outside of the sterile office environment. Go on a 8mb wireless DSL connection with a bunch of mid-end computers using different chipset manufacturers. There's not a lot of point to testing stability in the office on a $2,000 machine using fiberoptic internet. I just want XCOM 2 in my life but I can't in good conscience recommend XCOM 2. Thumbs down for me.

for the tl;dr crowd, FIX YOUR GAME, JAKE!

Edit: I left my laptop on idle for quite some time during campaigns. I've played about 30-35 hrs of XCOM 2

reviewText:
If I'm expected to produce 100% of the money for a game on the spot, with no negotiation, wiggling, haggling, or reduction under any circumstances whatsoever, than you, game company, are expected to give me 100% of the dang game. Now.

Well, not necessarily 100. No launch will be totally perfect. But I definitely wish I'd heard about the absurd performance issues from, you know. Games media, reviews, people with pre-release copies. Unlike with other games, I figured a pre-order was a safe bet here, having watched like half a day of Beaglerush streaming it and thus knowing the gameplay will be awesome. But uh, performance.

Every review, negative and positive, on the entire store-front mentions this issue. And since the game was pre-ordered, I'm pretty sure the refund window for people bitten on this has already expired. Funny how that works, huh? Honestly, I'm just a tiny bit relieved it really is a global issue with everyone on every platform, and not just my computer being too far behind the times yet.

This review isn't about whether I love the new XCOM under Firaxis, because I do. This is 'should you buy this'. And if you weren't already big enough into it to put down the cash, then please don't buy this yet. Wait for them to fix it, if they decide to.

EDIT: I actually waited until the morning after going to sleep post-launch to make this review, just in case there was some emergency uber-patch. As, uh, far as I can tell, nnnope.

reviewText:
This game isn't XCOM at all, it's more like a strategy game race to get from Point A to Point B, I get there may be some missions were a timer is needed, but it is forced in nearly every single mission. If I have an ambush opportunity, I have time to fly across the United States to get there, why do I find I have 8 turns to complete the mission and extract my soldiers? 0 Point in Snipers at all, I lost mine as I could exctract them in time.

I wouldn't recommend at all, until at least some kind of Long War mod comes out, I'm a few hours in and already it feels like the game is forcing me to do this and that as quickly as possible, the campaign has a timer, so you can't even really spend time doing the missions that pop up, you have to throw yourself at every opportunity (even with full Rookie squads, as things like Codexes appear, and you are fighting two boss enemies, after clearing the map, with a basically dead team, wiping them out).

Furthermore, Overwatch in Concealment Sucks and is broken. I had a stun trooper, walk in range of all four squad members, all four in overwatch, hit my medic in the face, and then it was my turn? Not a single shot fired by the overwatch guys?!

It's a good game mechanically, but the forced nature of the story and every single mission makes me wish I had not of purchased it and waited to see if the modders can fix it.

To clarify recommendation, I'm on the fence.  If you're into Xcom.. Buy it.  If you're not. Don't.

As far as a follow on goes, it's good.  Good idea, quite a basic storyline, but it's fairly involving.

The missions after awhile become quite samey.  But they're fun to complete.
The big let down for me is enforced gameplay and timed missions.   I prefer open non linear games.  Xcom 1 was non linear, sure you have to take out aliens, do missions etc but it wasn't forced on you.

In Xcom2 You spend a few days gathering intel, then a few days picking up supplies(money) then you're given a mission, which you can't ignore doing so looses you the game. In fact you can't really ignore any of the missions or you'll either loose the game outright or you'll loose the county you've spent a week getting.

Then there's the avatar project, which even if you hold every country in the world, can still be completed by the aliens.  Your hand is forced throughout the game and during missions via the timer, forcing you to make moves you'd never make without the timer.  Forcing you to rush and loose essentially.

The game world is excellent, the ai in general is very good, sure there's issues with line of sight and some cosmetic glitches but overall the idea" of the game is superb.

reviewText:
Absolutely amazing game. Just completed the campaign and man it is so much harder than the previous game. If you love EU/EW you will love this sequel.

Although it launched with varied performance issues, and some... 'interesting' bugs, the performance is pretty easiliy tweaked and the bugs are not so much game breaking as they are... weird. Mostly visual delays during the alien turn that leave you pondering what is going on until the turn ends and animation catches up and normalness resumes.

Deeply rich campaign strategy and very very satisfying tactical combat. The turn counters add just enough pressure to make sure you're not quite comfortable while giving you the time for intelligent decisions and ultimately, victory. Even though about 75% of the missions had timers for me, the ones without the timer still kept me on my toes with the very difficult combat.

Literally improved everything we loved about EU/EW and added new features and combat mechanics.

Highly highly recommend this game to fans of the previous installment. Though the difficulty has gone up significantly! New players be warned! This is not a relaxing game but a stressful challenge to put your wits to the test! (brutally difficult but very winnable). And oh so satisfying when you obtain victory against overwhelming odds. Looking forward to many playthroughs.

STRATEGY GOTY.
