reviewText:
XCOM is back and aside from a few annoying details, it's better than ever.

Virtually every area of the game has seen an improvement in some way. The strategic layer, combat, classes, soldier customization, enemy AI, enemy variety, mission variety, maps, resource management, all improved. But optimization and overall polish has definitely taken a hit, and there are a few questionable decisions that hold it back from being perfect.

On the strategic layer back at the Avenger, managing your base's allocated space has seen a pretty drastic overhaul, and the new contact system replaces the satellites of previous games. In general, you have a lot more control over what missions you take and what you spend your time doing, instead of always passing the time by scanning for activity like in Enemy Unknown. Now as different scanning opportunities pop up with all different kinds of rewards, you can proioritize which place you'd like to take the Avenger to scan based on the rewards that each location gives out.

As far as managing your space goes, the new upgrade system is a welcome improvement over EU. Now you don't need to wait until late-game to get the most out of building generators, for instance. When you unlock the next level generator that increases output, you can just upgrade the generators you have. It's a system that punishes you for early building considerably less than EU did. In addition, each facility can now be staffed with engineers, which are a resource that you'll gather over the course of the game. Staffing facilities gives different bonuses depending on each facility, and you can switch up which facilities are staffed on the fly to focus on what you need at any given time.

Combat is much the same as EU and EW, with some subtle refinements and UI improvements here and there. Grenades and explosives are more powerful and more important now, as you'll often fight armored enemies who need to have that armor shredded by explosives before they become vulnerable. Verticality plays a larger role now as the new maps are built more with setting up for height advantages in mind. The procedural map system works brilliantly and honestly feels like these maps were handcrafted.

Each of the replacement classes for the classes from EU is a step up from the last game, and each one has two distinct paths of skills that almost make each side feel like their own class. The Ranger replaces EU's Assault class, and can be specced for stealth melee or a shotgun vanguard. Sharpshooter replaces the Sniper and be specced for pure sniper or as a gunslinger (a pistoleer that actually has distinct advantages over a sniper -- I once took shots at 8 aliens in one turn using the Faceoff skill that lets you take a free shot at every enemy in range). The Specialist replaces the Support and can be set up as either a field medic or a hacker, and comes with a drone that allows him to heal or hack remotely. The Grenadier replaces the Heavy and can be either a demolitionist focused on explosions or a heavy machine gunner that focuses on the usage of miniguns. And there's a fifth class this time around, the Psi Operative can be acquired earlier in the game than Psi troopers of EU, and is its own distinct class with tons of great abilities. My favorite is being able to permanently mind control one enemy per mission. And the best part of all of these classes is that you can mix and match skills from both sides of each class, so you have a lot of freedom in builds.

Soldier customization is great. You have a lot more control over how your soldiers looks, with customizable faces, names, nationalities, bios, props like shades, headbands, bandannas, headgear like hoods and helmets, full control over weapon and armor color, you can add patterns to weapon and armor (and might I add, weapons and armor can be customized separately), you can pick variants armor torsos, arms, and legs (except for the  middle tier of armor -- you can't change the torso there for some reason) and can even upload your characters to a global character pool so the people you've created will appear in future playthroughs. One big missing feature: If you save a character, you can't load that appearance/description onto a rookie, you just have to hope you bump into that soldier again randomly if you want to use him. To that end, I refrained from using the character pool and will just manually recreate my soldiers next time if I want to re-use those characters. But you can also create characters to be engineers, doctors, or bad guys if that's more up your alley. And finally this one is to Firaxis (thanks for reading, Jake): Give us some more helmets, please. Such a great selection in EU and EW and yet there's only a handful in XCOM 2, and they don't look so good.

Now for some negatives: The game is not optimized well. At all. Back at the Avenger it's  not uncommon for dips down to 10-20FPS, and I have a capable rig playing on reasonable settings. I had better performance on missions after the initial ten-second stuttering as the map first loads, but many people have terrible performance all around. Here's hoping Firaxis addresses this in a future patch and manages to make this game more playable for more folks. It's unacceptable that a game in 2016 that was delayed and made exclusive for the PC runs this poorly, especially when the visuals, while ultimately good, are nothing crazy. There are also frequent hitches like the game hanging in between turns, actions taking longer than they should to start/stop playing, UI and sound bugging out. It's hard to understand why the game shipped like this when Firaxis generally knocks optimization and overall polish out of the park.

Mission timers. Oh boy. Mission timers are a divisive topic within the community. Some people love them, some people say they ruin the game, some people don't care much either way. I played on normal (veteran"

reviewText:
Hefty amounts of bugs.
Like in the first XCOM, you can shoot and be shot by enemies you have no real line of sight to or from, making any planning obsolete because you don't know whats going to happen. One of my guys got shot from outside the building he was taking cover in - right through the wall.
Ever seen a soldier smash in a laser-grid window, shattering glas everywhere? You will see that a lot in XCOM 2.
Displayed information for actions is occasionally incorrect or doesn't contain any info at all (like missing damage/percentage numbers). Occasionally Explosives that clearly outline the enemey units as affected, don't to jack to them.
The action cam repeatedly shows a black screen with red bars - so you won't even directly see what the ADVENT soldier right in front of you is doing. And when you can see something, the soldiers usually hold the guns to each others heads or walk though obstacles to shoot at the enemy. Same stuff they did in Enemy Unknown.
Also, the mission occasionally lets stuff go boom next to your squad for no discernable reason, killing off your dudes without you ever having a chance to have prevented it.

It's now all bad though. On the plus side, you can customize soldiers and weapons and even augment most of them with mods. Loads of maps are randomized now, so you won't likely see the same levels multiple times. And you have concealment now. Which basically means you don't have to creep ahead one space at a time as enemies are now unware of you until you get the drop on them. But don't worry, after that first fight, you get right back on your knees and crawl at a snails pace again as Enemy Pods are the way to go in the sequel as well...
But you have turn limits on most missions now, so the game acitvely FORCES you to run into Pods head on as you wouldn't be able to complete the missions elsewise.
[To be fair: You can mod the turn limits to be higher or non-existant, but since that is a mod-induced feature it wouldn't feel right to say that this isn't complete bullsh*t.]

So, I am not a fan.
Barely an upgrade in terms of mechanics as far as I see it and I guess XCOM has Polio again. Several design decisions such as the turn limits are highly questionable and make me actually hate this game.
This is another AAA-Beta-Relase. XCOM 2 needs a hefty dose of polish, then we can maybe talk about it being a decent game.

Apart from that there is so much freaking RNG involved, you can as well play Monopoly or Ludo.
...Gods forgive me, I acutally recommended playing those two games...

If you wanna really give this one a try, go to your cardiologist first. See if he has any objections to high blood pressure and rage fits.
Because you can and will lose your favourite soldier due to a random crit of a guy that decided to go bonkers, activated by one of your squaddies taking cover behind a wall or even worse getting dragged over half the map by a Viper.

And don't come at me with learn how to tactics" or any other of this PCMR bs. If an outmaneuvered Muton evades all shots directed at it and then decides to ignore the Suppression directed at him and crit a heavy in full-cover in the face
recommended:
there sure is a lot I must have done wrong.
XCOM:EU was hard but fair. XCOM 2 is flat-out unfair in every aspect. And the way it is designed it acutally punishs tactical planning.

But if you love rolling the dice and lose all your stuff

reviewText:
Well..... I'm just not even sure what to say.  I loved XCOM Enemy Unknow, but this is rediculous.

An enemy in the open and flanked with a 90% chance to hit? MISS!
My squad in cover being fired at from across the map? CRITICAL HIT!

It got to the point where it was laugh out loud aweful.

I should have waited for it to go on sale, but I was so excited to play it that I just went ahead and bought it. Horrible decision.
Graphics: not really better.  To me they feel like something I would expect in an indy game. Glitchy and it didn't look, to me, like an improvement on EU.

Game Play: Not bad. The move counter gets annoying when you have to rush across the map to do something, but it wasn't so bad that I disliked it. It's turn based squad combat and I like that. I did like the new stealth aspect, but it kind of seems useless when the enemy gets to make a bunch of additional moves(see below).

AI: I really feel like the Advent soldier's either had an unfare advantage, or my squad was just the unlukiest group of soldiers ever.  First off, when you trigger the enemie's awareness of you, they get a free move for some reason.  So the ambush you spent many turns setting up gets ruined. Second, their aim is impeccable from any position. And finally, they come at you in such large groups, even in the beginning of the game, that the fact that it takes 4-5 of your squads shooting at 1 enemy to kill them makes it infuriating.

I think I'm done with the game for now.  I will take a look at it in a month or 2 after some updates have come out to see if it has gotten better.

3/10 would definitely not pay $60 for it again.

I did like the new stealth aspect, but it kind of seems useless when the enemy gets to make a bunch of additional moves(see below).

AI: I really feel like the Advent soldier's either had an unfare advantage, or my squad was just the unlukiest group of soldiers ever.  First off, when you trigger the enemie's awareness of you, they get a free move for some reason.  So the ambush you spent many turns setting up gets ruined. Second, their aim is impeccable from any position. And finally, they come at you in such large groups, even in the beginning of the game, that the fact that it takes 4-5 of your squads shooting at 1 enemy to kill them makes it infuriating.

I think I'm done with the game for now.  I will take a look at it in a month or 2 after some updates have come out to see if it has gotten better.

3/10 would definitely not pay $60 for it again.

reviewText:
i was really looking forward to the xcom sequel.  i even pre-ordered which i quit doing long ago; now i remember why.  the gaming press is in the bag for the game companies.  I looked through multiple pre-release reviews and there was basically no mention of bugs or what is at times, completly illogical enemy behavior.  for example the game interface works fine on my laptop, right untill i dock it and use my mouse.  now when i mouse over a button it dissapears before i can select it. that's annoying but i can work around it until the hot fix but what i can't get past is the often completly moronic responses of the advent troopers.

more than once they've advanced on my position to get a nominally better shot on one of my squad but expose themselves to another squadie.  several times i've had an advent trooper move from a firing position to a burning vechile, ensureing they die after taking thier shot from the explosion.  because they move with no hint of self preservation it's like you are fighting an OP zergling rush.

Even that wouldn't be so bad but your squaddies fail about 80% of thier will checks, often creating a cascade failure that is irrecoverable because you're (seemingly) always fighting against a timer.

I could probably even work past all of this but i get the stong feeling that failing at any one mission will start a larger failure cascade in the larger game and i don't think there is much of chance to recover once your (nominal) grip on the situation starts to slip.

I understand this is supposed to be harder experience and i even embrace the idea but if failure is such a constant  the game becomes a chore.  I've got 6 hours into the game, and i've yet to see the fouth promotion skill for any class because none of the squaddies stay alive long enough.   There is no point in spending time customizing a squaddie if they are going to die in the next mission or two.  the only reward for good tatics in this game is that you might not get completly boned by the crazy enemy behavior, but i wouldn't count on it.

The base control suffers from constanly haveing to stop one thing to go to another section to start a new research project, restart a scan that got stopped for the 3rd time, re-assign an egineer, move your ship, deal with a concil alert, and on and on and on.

I'm going to table the game until the patch comes out, hopefully fixing the interface and nerfing the will checks a bit.  If it becomes fun i'll write a new review but right now it's just a gigantic dissapointment.

reviewText:
This game runs very poorly on recommended/above recommended hardware, that alone leads me to in turn, not be able to recommend this title. (this will likely be fixed soon)

Also the turn timer is limiting, and gets very tiresome after about the third mission. It's not fun when the game forces you to make decisions which are sub optimal. Especially when those decisions lead you to get burned from placing your hope in one diceroll, which was a perfect example of a misplay in EU/EW.

The thing is I loved XCOM Enemy Unknown, I got enough enjoyment out of it to play for 200 hours. I don't consider myself very good at it, but I still tried and failed a few times until I became experienced enough with the game to complete Classic/Ironman. Obviously something kept me going to try again when I failed and I still had a good time even when I was playing poorly. This is not the case here.

Between the performance issues and the game telling me I can't have any enjoyment on a level for more than 8-12 turns, this game is more of an exercise in frustration than it is fun. This game tells you exactly how it wants you to play it, and that can't deviated from whatsoever. Why not just put me in a level with minimal restrictions and let me discover for myself what works and what doesn't?

If I could get a refund for this, I would.
I can't recommend a title which is so tedious and frustrating to play as this happens to be.
Honestly, it's a shame.

First thing you need to know, combat mechanics are pretty much copied from part 1. Same infuriating, pre-calculated RNG, same LoS issues. I'm not sure if there is flying armor in this one, but I bet it will be just as horrible as i remember it from EU.

reviewText:
TL;DR? = Unenjoyable, Every mission felt like a chore, stupidly flawed probability system, missions gradually become impossible to complete, game forces you to play how it wants you to play, timer to beat the game makes it virtually stressful and unrelaxing.

I personally enjoy turn based games with a strategic and tactical element implemented to make you feel like a commander of a fireteam. This game fits right in there but with major disappointing twists that have rendered it unejoyable and everything about it is forced onto you. In addition, one thing I HATE the most about this game is the element of probability, and not just that but the probabilities you get in terms of a successful hit are very unrealistic and just straight out annoying.

In the beginning of the main campaign, I was having fun. Missions were playable, but only easy if you knew how to position your fireteam and target the most lethal and threatening enemies first while taking care of your own team in order to suffer little to no losses or damages. I was mastering that pretty well. The enemies I faced were a suitable match to the soldiers and lack of equipment I had to begin with which was fair enough. Then came this AVATAR project. Now I understand Firaxis wanted something unique, but to implement some sort of timer required in order to beat the game well thats just thrown any form of relaxation and joy of the game straight out the window. Then enemies staretd to become harder, and I couldnt keep up with improving my team and equipment. The game forces you to use your veteran teams more often due to the sudden rise of difficulty. Leaving you with no chance of using any additional rookies to promote them and give them access to better equipment. The further into the game I got, the more stressful it became when you lost even one soldier (who was either a squaddie or Cpl) because that meant you needed to replace him/her, but that was vitually impossible because I have now reached to that part of the game where every mission I play now is extremely difficult for rookies. I then eneded up having to restart because I kept losing soldiers bit by bit after every mission. How I was losing them I will explain later.

Now the missions themselves I believed were forced onto the player. You're given a mission to do in which although you have an option to skip it, you will suffer a serious penalty if you do. Now you're probably asking, why would you want to skip it anyway? Well maybe because I was in the middle of picking up a supply drop and researching equipment to further improve my fireteam, and I know that if I don't finish those researches then I won't stand a chance in hell in doing any further missions. reviewText:
I thought long and hard about this, but I came to the same conclusion as everyone else.

XCOM2 is a very good, although unfinished game. It's funny to have to call it unfinished seeing how it is basically the exact same thing as XCOM1, running on the same engine, and fundamentally with the same gameplay, albeit with sensible balance improvements. What's new?

The base is now a spaceship that flies around the map. Instead of building satellites, you build radio towers to gain region bonuses. Regions can be destroyed by terror missions, but you can rebuild them.
Everything has a time limit. Even the map has a time limit. Each month the aliens get +1 victory progress or something like that. You have to take these points away by destroying alien factories. Almost every mission has a turn limit, so no camping.
Three monthly random events, only one of which can be stopped. Lowered income, aliens get poison bullets for a month, more alien reinforcements for a month, +1 alien victory progress etc.
Procedurally generated & fully destructible maps.
Proving Grounds (AKA foundry) projects are now random.
There's a building that lets you respec soldiers or train rookies as a specific class.
A significant increase in customization options
Weapon upgrades
Concealment
These are very welcome and well thought-out mechanics, but it's also where the praise runs out. XCOM2 has all the glitches XCOM1 had, and then some. The optimization is absolutely pathetic - this game has higher requirements than GTA5 and unplayable with any kind of anti-aliasing enabled. During the last mission there were so many enemies on screen that the game's engine kicked the bucket multiple times and gave epileptic textures requiring a reboot.
The action cam is an incredible drag as well. XCOM1 could handle rapid fire in one animation, but XCOM2 pauses the game twice. Or three, or four, or five times. This is ridiculous considering how many abilities let you shoot 3+ times per turn, and since it used to work on the same engine in 2012. It's basically like aircraft animations in Civ5.
The frequent loading screens approach 40 seconds in length, despite using an SSD drive. Also the stats and leaderboards don't work.
One thing to be particularly weary of is being able to destroy the floor underneath an enemy. It seems like a great idea, but it guarantees that enemy will be glitched out and freeze the game for 15 seconds each time it moves or shoots. It also guarantees a desync in multiplayer.

Speaking of which, most disappointing of all is by far the multiplayer. It comes with questionable limitations (only 2 types of each class as opposed to 5, cannot choose weapons, cannot choose armour, not even half of the utility items are available, no PCS, no deep pockets etc.) These are the gameplay aspects. Gameplay aspects, however, do not matter if you can't play the game.
Once again, in this third installment, the multiplayer an unplayable and completely broken mess.. It is beyond unstable. It is even worse than EW, which, in turn, was worse than EU. I have yet to finish a singe game without it collapsing under desyncs and glitches, and finally disconnecting. How hard can it be to do multiplayer in a turn-based game? Legacy XCOM had multiplayer over email for crying out loud. It's unacceptable to sell this game as having multiplayer".

But enough of that. I was going to give a negative review for as long as the extremely high price coincided with technical issues
date: but ultimately I chose acquiescence. It's a good game with tons of fantastic little flavours you won't notice
recommended: extensive moddability (!) and significantly improved balance (except for that one item). I'm sure that the modders will find a way to improve many completely of the broken aspects that the developers clearly didn't have time to finish.\n\nI'll admit that I was worried about XCOM2 being geared towards "a wider audience"

reviewText:
This game is freaking terrible!  If you were a fan of the last reboot, and are wondering about whether or not to get this game, read this review!

You start most missions in concealed mode, which allows you to creep around the maps and set up an ambush. In this mode, Overwatch no longer has an aim penalty, so you could set all of your soldiers but one on Overwatch, and have the last one attack, or run out in the open to trigger a 'pod'. (Group of enemies that are just stood there) Once triggered, they will most likely run for cover, and your soldiers will shoot them.

Concealed mode is an interesting addition, but during the timed missions, where you are given 8 turns to complete the objective, or you fail the mission, you cant really be messing around slowly setting up an ambush to deal with the enemies. In this way, the game comes accross as having multiple personality disorder. Because of the new abilities the aliens have, you have to be very careful, running away and looking for cover. But because of the round timers that the developers have, you have to be very fast, making sure to get there on time. The developers also saw fit to remove the ability to 'dash' to a door or objective and activate it in the same turn. That means that you have to move there, and use your second action point to activate the objective, or dash there, and activate it on the next turn. Nearly all of the 8 turn missions I have attempted have been failed with one soldier standing right next to them, ready to activate it! FOR GOODNESS SAKES! I failed 8 missions in the campain, and completed 4, (some of them tutorial missions) on the easy difficulty, even though I have played the other game on impossible.

The aliens themselves have also been given much more power. Sectoids can now mind control, and appear just as early in the game as the last one. In the last game, only Sectoid Commanders could mind control, and you didn't encounter them until much later, when the research your scientists had done allowed you to manufacture advanced armours and weapons that leveled the playing field. Not only that, but Sectoids can also now raise the dead. So if one of your soldiers is unlucky (Literally, since the game is based around pseudo-random hit chances more than ever before...) not only does it hurt because you can attack the enemy once less per turn, but also it hurts because they can attack you once more per turn!  Killing the offending Sectoid will kill all the zombies as well though, but unfortunatly, it is rare that you encounter a Sectoid all on it's own. It is often accompanied by a pair of 'stun' troopers. These aliens are also encountered early in the game, and can dash AND melee attack your troops in the same move! Not only that, but they have a high chance to stun your troops, robbing them of their next move. It is hard to run away from these troops AND reach the objectives in time. Not only that, but while you run away for more cover, which is the only strategy in these Xcom reboots (everything else is random, positioning is the only certainty (and suppresion /explosives )...) you will invariably trigger another pod of deadly aliens, which will surely slaughter your entire team in the next go.

What is also poorly explained, and completely ruined, is the geoscape. In the last game, you were given clear goals of what to do next, or what decisions you could afford to make. In this game, Everything is random. There are 11 continental perks, but there are only 6 continents. The game randomly picks your starting position, randomly picks 6 perks out of the 11 in the game, and randomly gives each continent one of those perks. I started in New India, in Asia.

In the last game, you had a scan button, which would advance time. In this game, there are Scan buttons located all over the map. These buttons are essentially like bars, that get filled up as you choose to scan at that location, instead of another. once you have scanned it empty, you get the reward from it, what ever that was. Now, instead of monthly funding, every month, the funds you would have got are put down on the map somewhere, and need to be scanned for three days. You also need to build communications centers in your base to be able to contact more regions, and the regions are contacted in linear order.
Research and base management works the same, with a list of upcomming events that get completed as you scan in the map. Manufacturing works similarly, but now once you have manufactured certain items (Like armour or weapons) You only need to manufacture one, and every troop can have one.

There are certain missions in the game which advance the 'Advent' bar until completed, which when full, ends the game.  These missions don't disapear after a day like the others, and can be attacked at anytime. But only if you have contact with the continent that it is located in. So if you dont have access to that mission, you will have to build a communications center. But if you don't have enough power, you will need to build a power plant. But if you don't have enough money to do that, you will need to scan around to get some. While scanning, there is a risk a pick two, or pick three mission will pop up. You can choose to ignore it if you want, but there are 2 or 3 negatives associated with each of those missions, such as all enemies will have armour for the next month, or your funding will be cut in half next month. You can only pick one of those missions, and the other two negatives will happen anyway. But it will be difficult to beat those missions, with the new timer mechanics, and unfair enemy powers. If you dont have enough time to wait for all the building either way, then you will lose the game.

There is no way to play the game like the last one in my opinion. Now, instead of being able to start a new playthrough and put on Ironman/Impossible, and follow through with a certain strategy you have been working on, the game does everything
randomly, making it so you go in blind everytime. The old rules still apply to a deggree, elevation is good, blow up their cover, run away if you can to a more secure location, focus fire etc etc.

But all of those rules go out of the window randomly. You rely on cover? Well what about if one of the humans running around on the map randomly turns into a giant monster, that can walk up to your soldier on a balcony, and swipe it's claws, and completely destroy the building your team is stood on, in one move? You always know you can run away from the aliens to secure a much better environmental advantage, like higher cover or a vantage point? Aww, well, too bad, you got a mission that expects you to kill 10 aliens and hack the box in 8 turns, with four rookies, and devastating consequences for failure.


There are some positives though:

They fixed the mouse lag, making for a much more enjoyable user experience. The game also runs well for me on my old rig, so I don't know why some users are reporting performance issues, but it may be a driver issue or something. The game looks pretty good as well. The game features well done randomly generated maps. The designs, the music, the sound are all great! One great moment I recall was a grenade knocking a soldier into a train, only to have a 'BANG' play, as his body hit the metal train! xD The game is also much more snappier than before, it's very responsive and less time-wastie to give orders and pan the camera. The game world and designs ooze atmosphere also.

The tactical randomness lets the game down imo. You shouldn't have to mod the game to give you one or two more turns, that's something the developers should have anticipated.

reviewText:
Will update this once I get home from work, review mostly written for old xcom players.

+ The combat has been improved a lot because of small things that makes the game have a much better pacing. As an example they've added the ability to actually see if you have a line of sight on the enemies so that you wont have to worry about it when moving around.

+ The new system in which you spawn invisible to the enemies makes the first part of every map more enjoyable because it means you're setting up ambushes instead of hoping for good rng with the pod openings.

+ I for one like the new base building system even if it at first glance might look dumbed down. It feels like you wont have to play a certain way IE follow a certain building line that was always the same no matter what.

+ So far the enemies have been fun and rewarding to face, and I'm eager to see what they will throw at me for the rest of the game.

* Some graphical glitches like weapons or enemies clipping trough walls, pretty much the same as the previous game. It doesn't affect game play unless you really care about graphics.

* Difficulty has been scaled down and it feels like if you would play on a difficulty level under commander(classic) it would probably be really easy compared to the previous game.

- The AI has a habit of some times running into really stupid positions. As an example I've had two occasions now where AI ran into cars that exploded the next round, instantly killing them. Not sure if intented but I doubt it.

- Terrible optimization makes the menu, cutscenes and base almost unplayable. I don't know if this is a common issue but my rig should easily be able to handle this on even the highest graphics. Luckily since it's a turn based game it doesn't affect game play that much.

Easily recommend the game for now!

reviewText:
The game initially showed promise, but I quickly came to realise that it's so tied up in the designers' decisions for showboating and 'what-would-be-awesomes' that it isn't actually any fun to play.

The core of the original XCOM game is there and they've added some really solid new features to it, such as the armour system and melee combat, but the bad decisions significantly outweigh the good. The amount of RNG (which on it's own is fine), combined with new status effects that essentially render your soldiers completely ineffective for a turn (and the sheer number the enemy can deploy them on you) can quickly render entire missions impossible to complete within the first turn of combat, potentially forcing you to reload the same mission over and over.

Animations in combat take forever and sometimes pause for a second or two afterwards for no clear reason, completely removing the sharp and snappy combat aesthetic they were aiming for and making battles take forever. The camera seems to snap all over the place for no good reason, even occassionally missing important enemy moves, and if I have to see that pointing animation one more time I don't know what I'll do.

The stealth system, while a nice addition, seems a bit ad-hoc and doesn't seem to explore its own potential fully. I'm not sure how I'd change it up but currently it just feels lacking.

The additions to the overworld gameplay are really fun and add a lot to the game, the more guerilla style warfare gives XCOM 2 a suitably refreshing style change from 1 and I think it's the overworld that's the strongest part of the game. However, that doesn't really translate to the battle gameplay.

Additionally, I'll be the first to admit my machine isn't top of the line (or even all that good anymore) but the amount of variation in the framerate, even with graphics settings dialled down from recommended only increase the frustration of trying to play this further.

In conclusion, a promising game sorely let down by some terrible design decisions for the battle system that would turn an otherwise fun game into a mess of frustration and disappointment. A real shame, as XCOM 1 is among my higher rated games.

reviewText:
Contrary to other gamers I did not experience crashes and severe FPS drops but I can hear my computer on a heavy workload as if it were some high-end FPS game. Seriously, this game desperately needs some optimisation.
And I get it: As a resistance you have to operate on a time limit but the constant turn timers force you into a certain play style. Gone are the days when you could position your soldiers for maximum effect. Snipers almost are a redundant class. Streamlining is one thing in a game. It is another matter entirely to artificially inject a sense of urgency with game play mechanics limiting your range of tactical choices. Thanks to some quick modders you can now set up longer timers or remove them entirely from the game which basically is a bloody cop out. The devs simply included too many of those timer missions early in the game which is rather unfortunate because that's when your squads are at their weakest compared to the alien opposition. Any mistake in keeping up concealment is punished mercilessly by this game. So you find yourself inching forward with the waypoint movement system. Even worse, this whole system of forcing you into quick movement tactics is counterproductive when you reach later stages of the game. The key story missions don't have timers and you'd be well advised to dust of your old EU skills of slowly advancing your front line.
So what's the bottom line? Well, XCom 2 is a good game at least in theory. The enemies are varied and each species presents their own specific challenge. The timers are bloody annoying but you can get used to them. The real problems come from the bugs in this game. When you see your squad go to hell in an ironman game because one of those snake creatures can pull your soldier through a door and two floors, then you feel your frustration level rising because you were not defeated by a bad move but by a bad game engine. Sure, with some experience you learn to expect certain bugs and work around them but a truely excellent game would not force me to reserve some head space in order to avoid problems which shouldn't be in the game to begin with.

pros:

- interesting and varied enemies
- a real tactical challenge
- a good UI
- a competent AI
- tons of customization options
- compared to XCom 1 a greater choice in missions
- steep learning curve as the game is brutally unforgiving (if you want a challenge)

cons:

- still some performance issues
- still some glitches especially with the detection and line-of-sight system
- the game forces you to adopt a certain playstyle in order to succeed (at least early in the game)
- melee enemies have unbelievable range
- steep learning curve as the game is brutally unforgiving (if you are new to the game)

Gameplay wise, XCOM 2 is a definite improvement over it's predecessor. A lot of the problems i had with XCOM:EU and EW are fixed here. The streamlined base building mechanics are also welcome over the confusing layouts in Enemy Unknown. The character customization is also very detailed, allowing you to create lookalikes of your friends as well as yourself. However, the technical problems are very much present. Various animation glitches, crashes, terrain disappearing, aliens taking too long to respond in a turn, framerate drops etc. If this wasn't a turn-based game, i would have stopped playing a long time ago. i ran this game on an Intel 3970x @ 3.9 Ghz, 2x GTX 970s, 16gigs of RAM and the game running off a high-speed SSD, and the performance was pretty much the same, irrespective of whether SLI was on or off. And by that i mean the game runs poorly regardless of whether sli is on/off.

In it's current state, i cannot recommend this game. My advice for a potential customer would be to wait until the problems have been ironed out before picking this up. Or maybe wait for a sale.

reviewText:
After playing this game for 40 hours I figured i'd share my thoughts on it with you.

Seing as it's been out a few days now, i figure most of you know the general story of this game, but just in case here is a short synopsis: It's 20 years after the events of XCOM. during that time, the aliens overthrew the human governments and founded their own. They are currently in control of everything. XCOM is njow little more than a  small group of freedomfighters, with very little to their name. The goal is to stop abductions, overthrow the aliens, and get the cake. Although not a very innovative story, it is certainly interesting enough to keep you hooked.

Firaxis have let the story show through in some of its game mechanics-in both good and bad ways.  You are constantly on a timer, meaning you have to prioritize production of gear, research and facilities well. You may alos find yourself abandoning areas of the world to help out another. Every choice feels important, and this really helps carry the story forward.

reviewText:
In XCOM 2 Earth forces have failed to stop the alien invasion of the first game and entered a pact with the invaders: most people now believe the aliens to have peaceful intentions and are happy to let them control most of their life. The XCOM project is still alive though and is trying to mount a resistance movement to find out the aliens' true agenda before overthrowing their government.
The game is both an overhaul and a refinement of its predecessor and stands out as the finest XCOM game in recent times despite a shaky release.

PROS:

-the overall graphics are pretty good with nice effects and animations

-good soundtrack

-while pretty cliched the plot flows well and there'd a decent amount of mistery behind the aliens' plans

-the new resistance-styled XCOM really has alot of character and charm

-still sports some top notch turn-based tactical combat made even better by added mission types and better level randomization

-the concealment mechanics are truly superb and provide good tactical depth

-new soldier classes are excellent and great to use: said soldiers are also fully customizable in their looks, voice, stance etc

-moddable weapons are fun

-new alien types are quite interesting and can surprise you with some new abilities, their design and animations are also great

-good length, each campaign'd last you at least 20/30 hours

NEUTRAL:

-timed missions can be challenging or annoying, also depending on personal taste: still there's mods to make timers longer or remove them altogether

-some missions can feel a bit unfair in regards to the amount of enemies thrown at you

CONS:

-uneven performance

-long loading times

-some line of sight bugs (like through closed steel doors) can be annoying and ruin your tactics

-camera can be problematic at times

-still has several bugs (a few crashes, audio desync in cutscenes, envirnment destroying itself for no reason etc...)

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=629612335

Going from a worldwide funded organization to a small resistance movement is quite a change and while I wasn't fully convinced at first I must say it works perfectly: you'll feel like a guerrilla squad operating behind enemy lines, facing overwhelming odds and slowly turning into a truly badass spec ops squad as time goes by and promotions mount up.

The new mechanics Firaxis introduced provide an overall better game experience both in the field- with concealment letting you decide when and how to start going guns blazing, soldier skills providing many ways to get the upper hand over the aliens and synergizing well with each other, etc- and in the geoscape view- with mutually excluding missions prodiving different bonuses and drawbacks, POIs to explore, the Avenger to rebuild and so on. There's just so much to do, most of it is fun and well-designed and the game's brand of challenging, deep combat is simply as outstanding as it is engaging.

There's a few dents into this great game sadly and most of them are due to a shaky release. There's some line of sight bugs where you can be discovered through solid walls and closed doors,a few AI hitches, shaky framerate, some jarring problems with audio in cutscenes getting messed up and the game can sometimes simply crash to desktop. Even after a patch things havn't improved too much so here's hoping Firaxis gets their act together and finally polish everything up.

Even with all its blemishes XCOM 2 is simply an impressive entry in the franchise and a must buy for both long-time fans and newcomers: it's that good and it's only going to get better through patches, mods and DLCs.

reviewText:
There's a difference between challenging and frustrating. XCOM 2 simply isn't fun to play anymore at the later stage of the game. The game is very unforgiving, and brutal which is fine. However, it also doesn't balance the risk/reward of the game well. Often we are forced to risk the lives of our soldiers for minimal gain, and if we fail, we lose much more than we can recover. This makes the game into a long and hard grind, and more often then not after a few hours of playing I stop because the game just makes me tired and frustrated at it.

Frustating Issues:

Constant Interuptions - The game makes us scan every thing for days to get anything done, and yet it constantly throws interuptions and urgent missions and all sorts of stuff at you whenever you try to get anything done. It forces the player's progress to slow to a crawl.

Always Outnumbered, Always Outgunned - The difficulty curve spikes insanely quickly after the first few missions, forcing us to always have to field high ranking soldiers if we want to have a chance at succeeding. Yet it makes it difficult to train Rookies, which in turn leaves us without a capable fighting force if we happen to lose our higher ranking troops. And we WILL lose them eventually.

Timers - The game has too many missions with timers on them to play without the Disable Timers mod. Timers forces us to be reckless if we do not want to fail the mission, which in turn causes us to lose soldiers, which are expensive to replace.

Overpowered Enemies Are Too Common - It's completely fine to have strong boss enemies. They make the gameplay fun and makes you feel rewarding when you manage to score a kill on them. One good example would be the first encouter with the Avatar. If done right, you could have your whole team fight the Avatar alone, and it made for some interesting and intense gameplay. However, one bad example would be the Sectopod. The first time meeting it was cool, but later on, the game simply spams the Sectopods and force you to fight one in almost every single mission, and they are often backed up by other units. By having these things be so common, it no longer a novelty to fight them. Instead it becomes a huge annoyance. Furthermore, some enemies are completely overpowered. Not only does the Sectopod have a insane amount of health, it gets to attack twice per turn AND overwatch after that. That is simply not fun. That's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

Sure, this game might appeal to the veteran hardcore XCOM fans out there, but as someone who just wants to enjoy the game, perhaps it'd be better if they left some of those things for the higher difficulties and made the lower difficulties easier. For now, it feels like the developers did not put any effort into balancing the game, and instead thought How much can we frustrate and ♥♥♥♥ off our players so that they hate the game from now on?" and designed the game based on that."

reviewText:
Great game with many improvements over the previous XCOM: Enemy Unknown.

I'll start by saying I did not experience any of the bugs or performance issues experienced by other players. I purchased on launch and my experience has been very smooth. I have a mid to high-end computer and the game runs flawlessly. I did experience some crashing but it happens infrequently. Users with low-end PCs may have issues until the game is better optimized.

The biggest change that players seem to be complaining about is the timer. The whole campaign is basically on a timer and you have limited time to research, make contacts and hunt down supplies as there are constant alien interruptions. You would think the aliens would have the courtesy to leave me alone for 11 days while I research the plasma rifle that is going to triple their losses in battle. How dare they try to prevent me from destroying their race. All kidding aside, I enjoyed this mechanic as it forces you to make the most of the time you have available and doesn't allow you to rush through the research and create early super soldiers. There are many ways offered to halt and reverse the progress the aliens make essentially giving you more time for your own activities.

The only real flaw (and it is a major one, in my opinion) of the game is the RNG, or more specifically the in-game indicators of RNG are completely inaccurate and frankly, make no sense. I seem to hit more often with 43% chance than I do with 91% chance. The terrain also effects hit chance in a really weird way and the whole cover system seems to be broken.

Overall I'm 18 hours in and having a blast. I'll freely admit I've re-run some missions that have gone poorly for me in order to minimize the loss of a favored soldier, but half the fun in my opinion is seeing what happens differently during a mission by taking various actions.

It was questionable as to whether or not they could make a game that is superior to the original.  The first game was really good and its expansion gave you more to do with the original game.  Without a doubt this game is... more of the same thing.  Which isn't necessarily bad.  It's different which allows you to play differently, but for the most part it's the same thing.

Many of the enemies have had stats adjusted and have been reskinned, but for the most part all of the enemies are the same.  Some enemies can burrow now.  They've added stuns as a mechanic in the game.  They've removed some moves from some units and given some new ones to new ones.  The enemy unit composition although feels different, is roughly the same.

Instead of having to worry about managing countries and slowly losing monetary support from countries you're instead building up a resistence network and can only lose support if you lose a defense mission for that area.  To keep you entertained there are 'pick ups' on the map that you can pick up over time while waiting for enemy attacks or waiting to progress down the rabbit hole of the game's storyline.

I think if you've played XCOM before this game is worth picking up.  If you haven't played XCOM before you might want to just pick up XCOM instead and perhaps pick up this one after you're done with the first.

reviewText:
I gotta admit, I was playing on a very low end laptop playing at around 10-15 fps so I won't really touch on performance and what not. For those who are not familiar with the Xcom franchise, it is a series of turn-based tactical games that is well known for its unforgiving difficulty. The Xcom games made from Firaxis are made as a reboot to the series after when everyone thought the franchise was seemingly dead and was made for people who are both new and old to the franchise with of course easier difficulty levels added in to keep newer player from getting discouraged from joining Xcom while the higher difficulties are of course there for the veterans, although I've never played the originals myself.

So what does Xcom 2 add in from Enemy Unknown? Here's a short list to get an idea:
-new enemy types, with ADVENT troops being the sucessor to the EXALT forces in Enemy Within and a few new aliens and the old aliens learning a few more tricks up their sleaves
-base defence, for when the aliens are able to attack you're mobile command center
-semi-procedural level generation
-new and improved class abilities
-the ability to save your customized soldiers in a separate list so you can play with them throughout multiple games
-weapon customization as a separate upgrade system instead of taking up a utility slot along with visual upgrades (like taking a scope replacing gadgets like medkits and grenades)
-Steam Workshop Support

Some negatives to consider:
-PC requirements are pretty high so double check to see if you meet the requirements
-$60 USD as opposed to Enemy Unknown for $30 USD, unless you buy the Enemy Within expansion for $30 USD without a sale
-people have said something about the AI doing stupid things every now and again, but I wouldn't really know for sure because I'm bad at this game
-some visual glitches with soldiers and aliens alike doing some pretty weird things from time to time
-don't even bother with the multiplayer

Honestly, I feel too lazy to even say anymore since there are way better reviews than this one and there really isn't any reason to repeat what people have already said for about 10,000 times. Would I recommend Xcom 2? For someone who's fairly new to the Xcom franchise, I enjoyed my time with it immensely so what reason do I have to say no other than the negatives I mentioned above along with easy access to mods via the Steam Workshop extending the games' lifespan.

reviewText:
Very good game overall and the tactical battle is better than the first game. The base building and map is ok but depends on player's taste. You will get attached to your soldiers and you will most definitely enjoy this game. Also, you might break a keyboard or two as the game is challenging and sometimes even feels cheating.

3. Major performance issues although graphics don't look that demanding.

reviewText: XCOM: EU/EW was a great game and XCOM 2 is even better. There are all around improvements from pacing to gears, and the new story line is a lot more intriguing than the last one. Hell, even most of the system changes they made felt like an improvement. Strategy side of the game is as solid and fun as always, while character creation remains to be a time sink. And thanks to a great modding scene, XCOM 2 will have a rather long life span.\nThe game has some technical issues, mostly glitches and weird animations, and some annoying systems such as frequent timed missions, but those are nothing that mods cannot fix.\nOverall, XCOM 2 is a fantastic game that i can easily recommend to any strategy lover and to those who like some challenge and dont get easily frustrated.

reviewText:
Sweet Fustration: The Game

Sigh. I really wanted to enjoy  XCom 2.
After numerous tweaks and mods to elminate some of the more bothersome elements of this game; too many timers, nonsensical hit rates, constant interuptions from tasks, I still cannot finish a campaign before the game breaks and wrecks my PC with the RSOD.

Honestly there is no excuse for a AAA game being this unstable. It is near Bethesda level of glitches and bugginess, but the hard crashes are beyond fustrating.

As it stands, I can't reccomend XCOM 2 at this time. It's still an 8/10 game, but for gods sake don't spend $60 on this until this is fixed. I'll glady change my reccomendation once the issues are fixed, but for now, hold off. This game is hard enough without these problems.

That's NOT XCOM baby.""

reviewText:
If you liked EU you will probably like this, it's a general improvement in most categories. The game is also a little more tense, the addition of time sensitive missions makes every mission with it as exciting as a terror mission. It forces you to adapt to situations and think on your feet more than you would in EU/EW. You can't spend every mission blue moving and overwatch spamming anymore, it forces you to go out of your comfort zone and get really good at the game.

Graphics look nice, but the cinematic camera can get a little wonky at times. You can turn that off in the options menu if it bugs you. Game lags a bit when loading missions even on meaty rigs, and right now MSAA will cut frames pretty hard. There are a few bugs here and there, so far nothing game breaking, mostly visual.

It's probably one of the best games I've played in the last few years.

Well after the whole weekend on X-Com 2 i have experienced many of the tweeks to the game, loving the fact you can add more weapon attachments like laser sights, extended mags etc. very extensive custom look options, the general progress through the game is much improved from the first, more enemy variants and yes it could do with an optimization patch though my aging i-5 is coping ok with some of the fluff turned off.

Me personally im only finding frame rate drops on the squad up screen and base building bit, missions run fine with a few bugs i.e some of the soldier skills dont seem to work properly on the odd occasion, its apparent the game needs patching, it seems to be the trend with most releases these days. If theres one thing ive learnt in my 25 years of PC gaming, its keep your rig optimized though this is no excuse for poor programming. Im enjoying the game experience so far but i am a hardcore fan of the series and dont mind the timed missions as i revel the challenge.

Great game with a few creases that need ironing out, i tend to buy games now on pre order if there under 20 quid or wait till sales or GOTY editions as like many im not paying top dollar anymore cause you never know what your getting these days

reviewText:
Game as a software: This program does not perform well. I have a good gaming laptop but still frame drops constantly. The application sometimes crashes. I have encountered auto-saves that the game cannot load.

Game in general:
I wish the one calling the shots regarding what to put in the game have played the previous xcoms. The old xcom have more content, more things you can do, more research, more vehicles, more facilities.
•	What happened to the archangel suit?
•	No more mec trooper
•	Missing the laser weapons
•	Not enough depth to the normal weapon you use in the beginning
•	No more bases across continents
•	No more interceptors
•	No more base defense (inside the base, where aliens can kill your engineers and scientists)
I mean if you want to change some stuff at least replace it with something better. I feel this is a trim down version. And still if the plan is to really trim it down at least make the game kick-♥♥♥ in the sense that it is sleek. But the game as it is far from being sleek. Why do I have to see that useless hologram of the globe every time I want to move my base? And by the way, you keep showing us that but what we can interact with is a map…. So lame…

Talking about moving the xcom base. We could assume that the ship would be a big ♥♥♥ ship but how come throughout the game it was only intercepted once, with no damage I tell you! What happened to the big ♥♥♥ ship the aliens have? Only saucers flying around. And even if you fly pass them they would not attack the freaking flying xcom base.

I can still say a lot of negative things about this game but to summarize. There is nothing in the game that was impressive. It’s a trim down version of its predecessor. No effort to impress the players. If they say they worked on the graphics, well they currently suck with that frame rate drops. Nothing new, nothing exciting, nothing!

I hope they earn a lot from this version so that they could do another one better. Come on guys, if you have to go back to the original game, please do so, there is a wealth of content there, you just need to use that as the base of your content and then improve some. (I still can’t forget that one time I sent an agent via motor bike to an alien site and “Rambo”ed the hell out of the aliens).

I miss throwing those light stick to see the aliens… hayz…. Then *just thought of this now* you could have a research for night vision goggles so we don’t have to throw light stick so we can save mother earth while killing the aliens right?! I mean this game is supposed to be human vs aliens but this version doesn’t show enough human tech (if somebody will say because this version is in the future and alien tech is more advance then I would ask if we discarded our technology for alien tech then why does the resistance need to research alien tech again?).

Anyway I digress, this is my first review here in steam and it is for a game that I love and played since the 90s and I am saying I feel there could be way more than what was given in this version. A very big room for improvement.

Will I buy the next version of the game? hell yes :) but i might not pre-purchase anymore. I thought with the enemy within version being good this would be better but alas it is not, so next time I would not be as excited.

reviewText: I waited until the first performance patch" was released (it didn't help) to write this review.  I haven't tried any of the mods.\n\ntl;dr version: So many great ideas
date:
but the execution and performance issues make XCOM2 unplayable.

Good:
- The aliens are incredibly interesting.  Most enemies are basically improvements from EU/EW.  Sectoids and Mutons receive massive upgrades from EU/EW
recommended:
and there are several new enemies that make you really rack your brain on how you are going to combat them.
- New twists on some buildings.  The proving ground is fun.  It's mostly a random grab bag of weapons and armor.  The advanced warfare center gives you some pleasant surprises every now and then.
- Overwatch AI is improved.  No longer will 5 dudes on overwatch shoot at the dead alien the 1st guy killed.  All successful overwatch shots are useful.
- Everything looks pretty good.  The animation is much less cartooney than EU/EW.
- Dodge/Graze mechanic.  Pretty cool when it's in your favor
hoursPlayed:
but heart-breaking when it burns you.
- Enemy reinforcements.  They will really screw up your game plan and make you recalculate.  Much improved over the drop-a-thin-man-in-there-and-put-him-on-overwatch paradigm from EU/EW.
- Weapon upgrades add another level to squad make-up.
- Psi-warriors are a unique class.  They are bad ♥♥♥...  and probably even overpowered.  No longer just necessary to "take one for the team" in the final cinematic.

Neutral:
- Stealth ambushes were a good idea.  Triggering enemies with several squad members in overwatch commences a Boondock Saints-esque cascade of bullets.  However

reviewText:
Whilst released in a poorly optimized state, XCOM 2 is an enormous improvement over XCOM: Enemy Within/Unknown, this game has been an extroadinary amount of fun and it is definitely one of my personal favourites.

If you liked the previous XCOM game, you will no doubt like the improvements they have made here.

It's a shame they released the game in a what feels like non-ready state, and I have no idea how long they will continue to support it. But when you make the comparison with Bethesda games, and especially with its extroadinary support for modding, it is hard to imagine it will not be fixed - one way or another.

Could have easily been a 10/10 if only the developers spent the extra time on the polish. Some visual bugs can be neglected - if only they weren't as game breaking. My expectations have been surpassed, and if not by the devs, I suspect the modding community will release unofficial patches.

reviewText:
Timed missions, poor UI, icon clearing.  Tis just not fun unless your on the ground!

It's not a bad game but I'm really struggling to want to play anything other than the ground missions.

The ground missions are great (well, apart from doing timed missions constantly) and aspects of it have been improved from the first game.  The new alien designs seem quite cool and the random maps are great as well.  There were a few parts of the game I enjoy until.....

- I am not in a ground mission.  They've put in a lot more complexity in the base/map part of the game but I find it confusing and uninteresting on the whole.
- The ground mission is another timed mission.  I cans ee why they have done it and it does add a bit more bite to the missions.  Save scumming is the new overwatch now!
- I had to use a mouse and keyboard as there is no controller support (Steampad doesn't count!).  You can play it well enough with the mouse and keyboard on the ground missions but the UI for the base/map section is difficult to navigate with them.  It looks like it would be easier to navigate with a controller but you can't use one!
- Easy is very easy, normal is very difficult.  I have played old X-Com and new X-Com and found the recommended difficulty far too hard at times.  When I changed it down to easy the aliens were suddenly made out of butter and it wasn't a challenge.
- I had to listen to the voice acting far too often.  Some of it is ok, all of it grates eventually because you can't do anything in this game without someone having something to say about it.
- I had to look at my rag tag bunch of misfits standing with attitude".  I'm not big into customisation but even I was tempted to use it when I saw the poor models you get as standard.  I'm also not a fan of the posing (but I understand this is more personal preference on my part.)
- I had to sit through the beginning and end animations again.  You do quite a few ground missions and I got fed up of the animations that I had to 'Esc' through constantly to get past them.

It's just not my cup of tea to be honest.  The choices they've made have taken a lot of the fun out of it for me and on top of that they have made some decisions that I just don't understand (like taking controller support out of a game which had previously amazed everyone with how well it worked with a controller.)  Shame as I was looking forward to this!

EDITTED TO ADD (as I've now finished it
date: no spoilers)\n- The ground game really is good fun.  If I didn't dislike the other stuff so much it might have been a recommend (and while it's great
recommended:
it's not that much of a change from the first one.  It's tweaked very well though.)
- The story is a bit tonally strange (can't decide if it wants to be a serious game or not) and didn't really like any of the characters.  It's also a bit light until the end.
- Can't really say too much about the end  as I don't won't to spoil it but....
The final mission is jarring as characters appear that you have either not seen
hoursPlayed: or barely seen throughout the game so far.  The end is a bit of an anti climax (X-Com 1 has a better ending!)"

reviewText:
Game as a software: This program does not perform well. I have a good gaming laptop but still frame drops constantly. The application sometimes crashes. I have encountered auto-saves that the game cannot load.

Game in general:
I wish the one calling the shots regarding what to put in the game have played the previous xcoms. The old xcom have more content, more things you can do, more research, more vehicles, more facilities.
•	What happened to the archangel suit?
•	No more mec trooper
•	Missing the laser weapons
•	Not enough depth to the normal weapon you use in the beginning
•	No more bases across continents
•	No more interceptors
•	No more base defense (inside the base, where aliens can kill your engineers and scientists)
I mean if you want to change some stuff at least replace it with something better. I feel this is a trim down version. And still if the plan is to really trim it down at least make the game kick-♥♥♥ in the sense that it is sleek. But the game as it is far from being sleek. Why do I have to see that useless hologram of the globe every time I want to move my base? And by the way, you keep showing us that but what we can interact with is a map…. So lame…

Talking about moving the xcom base. We could assume that the ship would be a big ♥♥♥ ship but how come throughout the game it was only intercepted once, with no damage I tell you! What happened to the big ♥♥♥ ship the aliens have? Only saucers flying around. And even if you fly pass them they would not attack the freaking flying xcom base.

I can still say a lot of negative things about this game but to summarize. There is nothing in the game that was impressive. It’s a trim down version of its predecessor. No effort to impress the players. If they say they worked on the graphics, well they currently suck with that frame rate drops. Nothing new, nothing exciting, nothing!

I hope they earn a lot from this version so that they could do another one better. Come on guys, if you have to go back to the original game, please do so, there is a wealth of content there, you just need to use that as the base of your content and then improve some. (I still can’t forget that one time I sent an agent via motor bike to an alien site and “Rambo”ed the hell out of the aliens).

I miss throwing those light stick to see the aliens… hayz…. Then *just thought of this now* you could have a research for night vision goggles so we don’t have to throw light stick so we can save mother earth while killing the aliens right?! I mean this game is supposed to be human vs aliens but this version doesn’t show enough human tech (if somebody will say because this version is in the future and alien tech is more advance then I would ask if we discarded our technology for alien tech then why does the resistance need to research alien tech again?).

Anyway I digress, this is my first review here in steam and it is for a game that I love and played since the 90s and I am saying I feel there could be way more than what was given in this version. A very big room for improvement.

Will I buy the next version of the game? hell yes :) but i might not pre-purchase anymore. I thought with the enemy within version being good this would be better but alas it is not, so next time I would not be as excited.

reviewText:
Timed missions, poor UI, icon clearing.  Tis just not fun unless your on the ground!

It's not a bad game but I'm really struggling to want to play anything other than the ground missions.

The ground missions are great (well, apart from doing timed missions constantly) and aspects of it have been improved from the first game.  The new alien designs seem quite cool and the random maps are great as well.  There were a few parts of the game I enjoy until.....

- I am not in a ground mission.  They've put in a lot more complexity in the base/map part of the game but I find it confusing and uninteresting on the whole.
- The ground mission is another timed mission.  I cans ee why they have done it and it does add a bit more bite to the missions.  Save scumming is the new overwatch now!
- I had to use a mouse and keyboard as there is no controller support (Steampad doesn't count!).  You can play it well enough with the mouse and keyboard on the ground missions but the UI for the base/map section is difficult to navigate with them.  It looks like it would be easier to navigate with a controller but you can't use one!
- Easy is very easy, normal is very difficult.  I have played old X-Com and new X-Com and found the recommended difficulty far too hard at times.  When I changed it down to easy the aliens were suddenly made out of butter and it wasn't a challenge.
- I had to listen to the voice acting far too often.  Some of it is ok, all of it grates eventually because you can't do anything in this game without someone having something to say about it.
- I had to look at my rag tag bunch of misfits standing with attitude".  I'm not big into customisation but even I was tempted to use it when I saw the poor models you get as standard.  I'm also not a fan of the posing (but I understand this is more personal preference on my part.)
- I had to sit through the beginning and end animations again.  You do quite a few ground missions and I got fed up of the animations that I had to 'Esc' through constantly to get past them.

It's just not my cup of tea to be honest.  The choices they've made have taken a lot of the fun out of it for me and on top of that they have made some decisions that I just don't understand (like taking controller support out of a game which had previously amazed everyone with how well it worked with a controller.)  Shame as I was looking forward to this!

EDITTED TO ADD (as I've now finished it
date: no spoilers)\n- The ground game really is good fun.  If I didn't dislike the other stuff so much it might have been a recommend (and while it's great
recommended:
it's not that much of a change from the first one.  It's tweaked very well though.)
- The story is a bit tonally strange (can't decide if it wants to be a serious game or not) and didn't really like any of the characters.  It's also a bit light until the end.
- Can't really say too much about the end  as I don't won't to spoil it but....
The final mission is jarring as characters appear that you have either not seen
hoursPlayed: or barely seen throughout the game so far.  The end is a bit of an anti climax (X-Com 1 has a better ending!)"

reviewText:
There are enough reviews our there on the performance of the game and how dodgy it can be.  There are reviews detracting the pace of the game and the forced time limits in the missions.  For those users who complain about the time limits of the missions think on this.  You are the resistance, you are deep in enemy territory and they have the advantage.  The game does a great job on pushing that on to the player.  You get the strong feel of being the underdog more so then in the pervious titles.  That being said this is where I start to have a problem with the game and the developers and the course this game took.

What do I mean by this well lets start with the fact the game is 20 years later.  The resistance has been fighting for years against Advent and the aliens.  So why in the name of all that is holy am I still starting the game off with your typical rifles?  WHY has nothing in the pervious war carried over?  In what universe would a 20 year resistance that had some advanced weapons at the end of the last game AND genetic modifications be reduced to the starting point of X-Com EW.

Does anyone else feel this is just a slap to the player?  Where is the intense story?  I spent 20 minutes just trying to find out exactly what happened at the end of the last game and I have gotten nothing that actually makes any sense.  Advent took over the aliens attacked and took over.  Really so what the heck happened to X-Coms war against the aliens and the launch on their home planet?  Why are we stuck with nothing at the start? No Psionics no Gauss no nothing we are basically naked against a enemy that has evolved in 20 years and X-Com has not evolved?  I can not believe this as realistic.

The game so far is good but I am feeling let down by this game.  Lets be honest X-Com the LW makes X-Com better than this.  As far as games go I give this a 7/10 for graphics and feel but I have to give it a thumbs down still.

*Additional Note here that has me a little annoyed as a modder, programmer, and a gamer.  Upon reviewing the game files at length I noticed within the game code alot of notes and options laid out for development of the game.  Why are these not live, why are they sitting there unpolished?  Simple because the developers and company in general don't give a dang about the players.  They want others to finish the work for them like Long War Studios.  IF anyone cares to look carefully they will see long war published the mods in December of 2015 for this game.  So not only do they get the first jump on putting mods out there they have have had the game files for over a month, have completed some in game tweeks the dev team should have done and are well ahead of any modder who now looks to tackle an advanced mod for this game.  Way to go on the developers and publishers of this game.  As a customer and fan of this series you have lost my bussiness.  Simply because of the tactics played with this one game, and if this is the writing on the wall for the future of gaming well gaming will no longer be a secondary pastime but not a pasttime at all.

reviewText:
PLEASE NOTE: Although I do give this game the thumbs-up, I would recommend waiting until the performance issues are fixed. I haven't experienced these problems, but quite a few others have, so I would be careful with this purchase if I were you.

I've been a fan of the XCOM games for a few years now. I'm not one of those veteran players that have been playing since Terror of the Deep or whatever, but I had a blast with Enemy Unknown, so I knew I was going to get this game. After playing this game enough to have a solidified opinion, I think it's easy to say that this game is a huge improvement over EU.

Graphics
The graphics aren't actually that bad for a strategy game. The characters themselves look great, and environments look pretty. If you have the action camera on, then you photographers out there should get ready to take some nice screenshots.

Gameplay
If I were to explain the overall gameplay in one word, that word would be improvement. The new classes (the Specialist, Gunner, and Ranger) are great replacements for the previous ones, and make the game far more interesting and teams much more diverse. My personal favorite seems to be the Specialist, because how can you NOT find using a drone to take control of your robot adversaries awesome? However, this is where one of the problems with the game seems to come in: there are some pretty rough balance issues here. Okay, first of all, I get that the game is supposed to be hard. I'm not talking about the enemies (besides the Viper and Codex) being over/underpowered, I'm talking about the XCOM soldiers themselves. The Specialist's drone is kind of underpowered when it comes to hacking the aforementioned robots, because the chance of actually hacking it is pretty low. The Psi-Soldiers are really OP, if you haven't heard that already. The Ranger's sword, although awesome, seems very situational. But, to make up for things like this, you have the new enemies. I don't want to spoil them all, but there's a few really creative ones that I'm a huge fan of. The pacing to the game has gotten some mixed reception, primarily because the timers can be really unfair" in some cases
