reviewText:
A bug from the patch 2 weeks ago introduced a memory leak. It hasn't been patched since. I haven't been able to play the game.

As of the most recent update, the game is now playable. I've even noticed an increase in performance! Wow! Still not optimal, but it doesn't really dip into single frames as often, and crashes are way less frequent. Others are reporting more performance issues though. YMMV.

Game is pretty damn fun. XCOM 2 is more streamlined than Enemy Unknown: Stripped down base management, removal of aircraft, and there are no longer country-specific panic bars, but instead a single global one.

That's not to say that they haven't added in anything new. Some missions will start you off in a stealth-based concealment status. Instead of groups of enemies gaining a turn as soon as you spot them, they'll only trigger once you enter their line of sight (which, once you spot them, will be displayed on the map when you move your mouse around. Unfortunately, this is currently bugged, and enemies may be able to spot you outside of the visible zone). I really like this concept, but generally the missions you start in this condition will have a lower turn counter. It makes sense for some missions, but it's a slap in the hand to give you this freedom and being unable to utilize it. On the bright side, there are some mods that change the way the timer works.

And mods for just about everything else, actually. XCOM 2 is miles ahead of Enemy Unknown when it comes to mod support. If you go on to the Steam workshop (or elsewhere, if you prefer), and you'll find new classes, cosmetics, weapons, enemies, gameplay tweaks, the works. Making this game so mod friendly may be the best change to XCOM 2. Firaxis definitely deserves some praise for their improvements. The only downside is that if you decide you no longer want a mod during a campaign, you won't be able to use that save. On the bright side, there's a mod that lets you bypass that! (though your save may have issues or make your game crash).

It's just such a damn shame how buggy this game is. There are situations like this where I feel like I should have a flank, but instead the game disagrees[i.imgur.com] and says the alien is in full cover. Here's one where I'm right beside this guy[i.imgur.com]. The inverse also seems to happen- flanks at absolutely incomprehensible angles. Happens to both me and the AI. Some bugs I feel guilty about is stuff like this. That target is behind 4 walls.[i.imgur.com] It's not usually that extreme, but it happens more often than you'd think.

My first playthrough was on Veteran. The global crisis meter was one bar away from being filled because I was pretty dumb with my build order (PROTIP build a Resistance comms facility early in your base). I was able to completely erase it in about a month's time, and they never remotely recovered from it. It was pretty much a win state for the final two months: I was just waiting for more tech to develop and only a handful of missions popped up. Very anti-climatic compared to how hectic the early months can be.

I really like this game. Should you get this game? Definitely. When the Game of the Year edition is released. The bugs are still present and they'll likely be focusing more effort on making DLC (because this is a 2K game, of there's a season pass). May as well get a cheaper, less buggy game at a later point in time with all the DLC included and better, refined mods from the community.

I'll change my recommendation to a yes when I can honestly tell others to pick the game up. Until then, stay away.

PS why the ♥♥♥♥ can Advent Officers move, use mark (increases enemy accuracy against one of your soldiers) and fire in the same ♥♥♥♥ing turn?

PPS bring two grenadiers, get them Heavy Ordnance, Volatile Mix, and Salvo. Develop them heavy armor. Give one gas and the other acid grenades. Blow up every single wall, floor, and ceiling.

reviewText:
XCOM2 is an evolution of XCOM EU ideas, refining classes and abilities as well as adding a lot of new stuff.

Nearly all abilities and items are usable in every mission, class builds are more versatile and fun, especially when boosted by the wide variety of items that are semi-blindly researched in Proving Grounds. To improve classes even more they have a random chance of getting the ability of another one when promoted thanks to Advanced Warfare Center - making some of your soldiers truly unique (and painful to lose).

Maps are randomly generated this time, armor system is refined (not a bonus to HP but lowering damage instead, can be bypassed/shredded by grenades, psi powers and some weapons), soldiers can stay out of combat for weeks when wounded and even become shaken, being more susceptible to panic and enemy mind control - so you have to take care of them more than before.

Weapons can be upgraded with gear bought from black market or dropped by aliens, soldier stats can be amplified by stims and various types of ammo and vests.

XCOM2 also saw the addition of melee combat and concealment system granting you the ability to sneak up and ambush aliens. Aliens themselves are much more varied now, with more unique skills. Since you can mind control organic enemies and take control of robotic ones through hacking - combat becomes quite interesting.

At the campaign level aliens have won and you are in charge of last remnants of XCOM organization fighting the occupation together with resistance. It's a race against time more so than before, with Doomsday clock ticking and you can only slow it down. This time there's truly never enough resources for everything so often you will find yourself literally running on fumes and will have to compromise.
As a result some missions are timed now, which can be tough at first but becomes a lot more managable as your force becomes more skilled and on par with alien technology. This however rids the game of the infamous overwatch cheating that made the game easy in XCOM EU.

And with all that said - there's a LOT more to see in this game that is impossible to mention here.

reviewText:
-- True Story ---

The Avenger had been making its way back to the HQ for resupply and rest for the troops. The resistance had been flying over Russia for some time, the land below frozen and dusted with a white powder. It was quite a sight, but knowing my luck, life was about to give me a closer look. At about 14:00 hours our ship was ambushed. A UFO had been tailing us for some time and just launched an attack against us. Fearing the worst, everyone held on as two cannons shot at our engines. To our surprise, we weren't blown to bits, but all the power on the ship was dead... And we were descending.

Falling from the sky, our ship plummeted to earth, engines stuttering. Without a moments notice, our Engineers reactivated our power through our emergancy battery. Our engines came to life and did all they could to keep us from crashing. Surprisingly, we landed without a scratch... Though I wish I could say this was the end of it. Our escape was halted by a nearby jammer that was deployed by the UFO. It halted our systems and left us vaulnerable.

Reports of enemy dropships stormed our comms and we soon realized we had little time. We had to deactivate that jammer and get this bird airborn again before we were overrun. Our troops were instantly deployed into the frozen tundra to defend our bird, each one hunkered down and prepared for the first wave.

While most of our troops defended the entrace, a demolitions squad of 3 advanced to disable the jammer. CPT. James Grey" Mckenna

Quick Overview of Pros and Cons:

Pros:

* Really really fun - Matters because reason we buy and play
* Good solid graphics
* Great strategic play - Well thought out - Better than XCOM: EU/EW
* Lots of options makes for very diverse play
* Lots of maps - Really good maps/variety
* Extremely immersive gameplay - You feel like you are trying to save the human race/world
* Surprises, twists, and mystery - Great story telling so far
* A large range of different enemies to fight
* Mobile base and travel is well done and you have to make hard decisions

Cons:

reviewText:
GAMEPLAY:

Extraordinarily unbalanced. Short mission turn timers and overpowered enemies make success random at best.

I don't mind difficulty, but being at the mercy of RNG where I cant hit an enemy who single handedly mops the floor with me is not fun. I was successful at Enemy Unknown on harder difficulties but find this one frustrating on normal(veteran) and still very RNG dependant on easy. The world map is just as random, spawning critical missions left and right while you are scanning to do a different one. The Avatar project bases spawn several contact points away, requiring a time costly facility be build to even get there.

I'm sure some like the extreme difficulty, as XCOM has been notorious for it.

STABILITY:

The game is not stable causing very poor frame rates despite far surpassing the recommended specs. On lowest settings I still cannot get to 60FPS consistently.

Load times are excruciatingly long between missions. AI in missions can sometimes just sit there while the engine is catching up. Some psi attacks from the enemy take 20-30 seconds between cast and application.

reviewText:
Note: This review originally did not recommend the game, based on several incomprehensible design choices made by Firaxis. The use of mods has changed my recommendation from very tenuously negative to very tenuously positive. The change from a red to a blue icon may seem dramatic, but in reality it's a very small change that just happened to push the game back into the Recommended zone for me.

I am very appreciative of the feedback, both disagreeing and agreeing, that was put forth in a respectful and reasonable manner, but I do feel obliged to say that none of it convinced me to change my opinion. The decision to very, very cautiously recommend the game was made independently and based solely on more playtime.

Only a fool never revises his opinions.

This review assumes play on Normal difficulty.


The Short of It:

As a lover of the X-COM series, I've had a very hard time getting to enjoy this game, and the fact that I had to use mods to do so still leaves a bad taste in my mouth. XCOM 2 has a lot of great points going for it, but in some ways, Firaxis sabotaged many players' enjoyment of the game, and this is why I can only very, very caustiously recommend the game, and only to players who know full well what they are getting into.


The Long of It:

XCOM 2 is set years after the XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Enemy Within, and in the time that has passed, the aliens have established a seemingly peaceful (if slightly patronizing) relationship with humanity, creating a global government known as ADVENT. Humanity seems to prosper under the guidance of its alien benefactors, but all is not as it seems, and a hidden Resistance movement, founded from the remains of the old XCOM Project, is determined to expose the aliens for what they really are.

In the vein of its predecessor, XCOM 2 is a turn-based tactical strategy game, where your small squad exchanges fire with a superiour alien force, and only careful guidance from their Commander can help them survive. Once again, the odds are overwhelmingly in the enemy's favour, except this time, the aliens don't give you any breathing room, not even in the beginning.

When you're not commanding your squad, you're constructing your base and researching new technologies, since apparently all the technological advances of the XCOM Project are... misplaced? Forgotten? I don't know. You simply give orders, and the crew of the Avenger, your new mobile base, starts work on the project you've requested, usually taking a set amount of days to complete the effort.


The Right of It:

XCOM 2 improves the most - and really, only - glaring problem Enemy Unknown had, which was its extreme reactivity. The aliens always had the initiative, and the player had to chase after events. XCOM 2 fixes this to some degree, allowing you to decide when to strike at alien objectives. You'll still have to respond to missions (and bothersomely often), but you can be a lot more proactive now.

The game looks gorgeous, and plays smoothly when not bugging out. Tactical options are once again legion, and the base and world building aspect is fun if somewhat streamlined. Concealment mode is a nice addition, although hampered by a serious flaw, see below.

Classes were well rebalanced. Snipers got slightly nerfed, going from omnipotent to 'merely' powerful, Supports are now much more useful and even necessary, Heavies are much more fun and versatile to use. Assaults still kill the crap out of everything.

Lastly, it has a lot of the qualities that made XCOM: Enemy Unknown so good, and those should  never be understated. XCOM 2 could have been even better than its stellar predecessor, if not for...


The Wrong of It:

Some utterly incomprehensible desicions by Firaxis lie at the base of my ambivalent review of this game, most of which end up making the game actively hampering its own gameplay, especially in the early game.

Firstly, and most importantly, making a turn-based strategy game and then making every single action and movement dependent on a timer is a very questionable decision. I agree, Overwatch Creeping was a lame strategy and had to be discouraged, but stringent timers that require beelining for objectives are a draconic measure. Many “seriously players” absolutely love the timers, and great for them, but they tend to forget that the timer is the same on Rookie as it is on Legend.

A throttling timer is great for Legend difficulty, but on Normal, I want a tough challenge, but I also want to have some leeway, to be able to make one or two mistakes without being instantly brutalized, and to be able to maneuver instead of madly dashing for the objective and evac zone. The timer itself is a good thing, but scaling it to the difficulty would have solved so many problems.

Even when you're not doing missions, you're constantly racing against the clock. Completion on the game-over Avatar Project goes punishingly quick, even on Normal, and you'll find yourself constantly chasing after main objectives to avoid getting strangled by yet another timer. Playing a strategy game on Normal shouldn't involve a feeling of constantly having a muton poking a pitchfork in your back to go faster! Faster dammit! Again, great for hardcore players who want to get gut-punched, but not for people who want a challenge without needing to min-max and learn stats by heart.

To exacerbate this problem, some enemies will make your careful positioning irrelevant by teleporting to a flanking position and then getting a free turn to put a soldier in the hospital – or make that the morgue. Faceless enemies are also highly unfair in the early game, revealing themselves whenever they like and then getting a free turn for an automatic hit. Stun Lancers will throw all caution to the wind and dash through withering overwatch fire just to get a hit in. It can be very frustrating in the early game without skills or equipment to counter it, especially with the draconic hospital times of 15 days or more. Sometimes it feels like “computer decides you take 6 points of damage,” and that's a shame.

Also important for a new player, the enemies have been bumped up compared to Enemy Unknown, and the early game can be a brutal meatgrinder. Enemies hit often and hard, even with full cover. Sectoids, encountered from the start, now have 8 health and can Mind Control, Mind Whip and Reanimate right off the bat. There's no occasion to warm up or even get to learn the ropes, you're dropped right onto Hamburger Hill and will have to endure serious punishment before you can start fighting back. Expect to burn through recruits quick in the beginning. A character so much as stubs his toe will spend over fifteen days in the hospital, so it'll be very hard to get any promotions in at first.

Lastly, the game is very poorly tested and this despite its pushed-back release date. Bugs are legion and immensely frustrating, some having serious gameplay consequences including soldier deaths.  The game also does not bother to explain its mechanics, just stacking objectives onto your cart with no explanation as to how or why you should achieve them. And I think only Firaxis know why they removed all the great Second Wave options.


The Last of It

I wish I could gush about this game, I really do, but I find the decision to put stringent timers on all difficulties to seriously chip the paint, making players feel bullwhipped. As it stands, I can only carefully recommend this game, and respectfully advise all non-hardcore players to use mods to make the timer less brutal on standard difficulties. With the timer's grip lessened, the game becomes more enjoyable to many people.

Yes, “you can use mods”, but that's no excuse. Many developers these days have an attitude of “the community will fix it” and it's a bad attitude to have, and not one players shoul defend.

reviewText:
Hello.

Xcom 2 is fun, there is no denying it and that is probably the only reason why it has achieved so many positive reviews. What the reviews all seem to ignore are the incredible number of bugs and general instability of the game. Please find below my systems specs, a list of bugs which i have encountered and the relative frequency at which they fudge up my experience.

Windows 10
Gtx Titan x SC edition
i7 3770k @ 4.3ghz
16gb ddr 3
1tb samsung evo ssd
960gb sandisk ssd

1. Game crashing to the point that my pc either restarts itself or I have to hard restart. The game crashes 90% of the time i play it, this is not an exaggeration.
2. Very poor performance - the fps are all over the place, the game is way more demanding than it should be - relative to how it looks and the amount of action taking place at any given point.
3. My soldiers or the enemy shooting each other through solid cover and other line of sight obscuring objects.
4. Action cam showing bullets actually hitting the enemy and then registering as a miss.
5. Sound bug where only the music remains and all other effects are not played or are very muted.
6. Stuck animations, i.e. the constricted animation not ending after constriction has been released.

When Batman AK and BF4 launched they both released in better shape than this game and were torn to pieces by the media and gamers alike, somehow it feels like Firaxis have gotten away with it and I have no idea why. It is incredibly disrespectful to your fanbase to expect payment for such a poor quality release; goodwill doesnt come easy and it feels like Firaxis need a reality check.

Bottom line - avoid hours of frustration and dont buy it until they stop alpha testing their game and fix it.

reviewText:
X-Com 2 what can I say?

The first X-Com I thought was a unique game of it's kind. No real, Turn based strategy game could really compare to the theme of it.

The second one though, everything is so much better.

- New Graphics
- Overhauled management system
- Much more in depth customisation
- Improved Base Management
- Improved Combat
- Much more satisfying gameplay
- New abilities/gameplay mechanics
- Much more challenging A.I and threat system
- Really threatening enemies

- The list could go on and it will when I decide to spend time writing this but for now after playing from release until the following morning I can say I am eager to continue my campaign.

Great game, great series, great developers and modding community too!

reviewText:
Took me 2 days to complete and when I exited the game after that, it was 4:20AM 10/10

It made me groan, It made me dissapointed, it made me sad, It made me cry, It made me stress the ♥♥♥♥ out. It made me leave the room, and most importantly, it left me satisfied.  Its like sex.

But seriously, this game is wonderful. Other than it being a pain in the ♥♥♥ at times, It's really a great game that I'll probably do a lot more of on harder difficulties. My first run was on normal and I allowed saves, so, of course every time someone died, I decided to be a wimp and reload. Even then, it felt really good.

This was my first XCOM game that I actually played, by the time I had EU, I was already playing this, so that's that.

The modding community is also great, Bob Ross confirmed for best sniper 2016. Halo armor, MGS Armor, a lot of stuff.

Multiplayer feels really quirky, but it was fun, based off of my one game in it.

Steam controller is also really great on this, if you happen to have that.

Even if this game leaves your life in shambles, this game has a wonderful conclusion that feels rewarding when you reach it, even if you aren't a fan of turn-based-strategy games, I'd still recommend this to anyone.

10/10

reviewText:
I really didn't like this game. There's a lot of new things, and some stream lining elements that make some things outside of combat better. But at the heart is the tactical combat gameplay, and that's really gone another direction from the previous XCOM. I personally do not enjoy the timed mission element on every single mission. I know other people do and that's fine. While this change is different compared to the first XCOM, it becomes a pain when every mission is timed. You have to throw caution to the wind to complete the objective, and the game punishes you for that. And if you fail, then game punishes you just as severly in a different way.

There's no slow and steady in this game, that tactic is gone. It's now balls to the wall rushing into bad cover and getting nailed. But don't forget to flank! Oh wait, you now can miss quite easily while flanking. Get used to missing even with good shots. I don't think there is even much point to flanking, as you easily get out flanked when flanking. So the risk vs reward isn't there at all. But it seems the AI doesn't have any issue hitting your troops and they will hammer you even when you're in full cover.

This game is quite different to the first XCOM, and I honestly don't like XCOM 2 at all. I'm going back to the original which had the right amount of risk vs reward to it.

reviewText:
Though it still retains some of Enemy Unknown's flaws, XCOM 2 is an improvement on its predecessor in almost every way.

+ The tactical turn-based combat is as good as ever.
+ Sometimes brutal difficulty keeps you on the edge of your seat even more so than the previous game.
+ New enemies with new abilities create a threat that's more far diverse than before.
+ semi-randomized maps means you won't be visiting the same battlefields over and over.
+ Tuned-up graphics, animations and character customization make battles look great.

- Planning movement across multiple vertical levels is still awkward and sometimes confusing.
- AA options seem poorly optimised, cranking them up can give a huge performance hit.
- Camera issues sometimes prevent you from seeing what's going on.

reviewText:
I feel that writing a review before finishing a game is wrong, but in this case I will make an exception.  I am currently running this game with the following specs:
EVGA GTX  980
RAM 16gb
CPU i5 4670k
WIN 7 premium 64 bit
Mechanical HDD
I am currently playing with everything maxed at 2560X1440, and I honestly don't see any performance issues that are game breaking in any way. I have been reading so many negative comments from people that are experiencing low or inconsistent FPS. Turn off what ever you are using to record the FPS, and stop concentrating on these numbers. This is the biggest way to ruin a game for you. It hurts even more when you have a banging game machine. I used to obsess about FPS, and would beat myself over the head trying to run a game to meet a steady 60 FPS. I had to stop. I realized I was spending too much time worried about FPS, and not enough time actually playing the game.
This game is awesome, and is such a huge improvement over EU, and EW.  There are so many personal stories waiting to be told within this game. I played for only 3 hours, and already experienced some awesome moments, I can't wait to dig deeper.
Firaxis hasn't wronged us. They haven't come to our homes, and kicked our dogs. They just released a game. If you feel ripped off, get a refund. Meanwhile, I'll be mu♥♥♥♥in' save-spamming, and killing sectoids. Peace.

reviewText:
XCom Long War is just more fun in every way.


Thnigs that suck in XCom2:

Melee.  I can't even imagine what they were thinking with building a whole class on swords.  And then the melee enemies are just brainless.  They run towards you, hit you with a stun baton that somwhow does the same damage as a railgun, and are just left standing out in the middle of the field.  You auto-hit-auto-crit them and that's it.  Melee only works if they were to get in the same square as you so guns couldn't be used.  Like, you know, every minis game ever made?  That would be cool.  (Like the snake, but without the ability for me to shoot the snake off.)

Explosions.  XCom 1 was super hard because you couldn't rely on explosives.  Destroying the Weapon Fragments was too much of a penalty.  But here it is open season.  Every Grenadier can have a grenade launcher and three plasma grenades.  They automatically destroy just about any terrain.  Including entire houses.  So carpet bomb, shoot the stragglers in the open, laugh at people who use the sword class.  Take 5 grenadiers and a sniper.  There will be no terrain left.

Research.  I can't pick the kind of grenade I research?  Seriously?  How does that even make sense?  You don't accidentally make a gas grenade while designing a flame grenade.  And if you do, apparently the mistake isn't repeatable because you get a different grenade next time.  And getting HazMat instead of Stasis armor just makes me cry.  (Prevent 2 damage from one type of enemy vs just heal 8.)

Startup.  In Long War, you start with six doods and they have multiple inventory slots you can customize with all kinds of Earth-standard accessories.  In 2, you have four and you have to loot an elite alien soldier if you want a WEAPON STOCK.

Mind control. Omg, mind control.  Sectoids with mind control are in the very first fight here.  Besides the fact that anyone who has taken a game design class or has a soul knows that mind control is something you just don't do in a game, it happens in the first fight.  On easy.  And in the final boss fight, you have a 7 man squad, and they have 3 guys with mind control who teleport off screen if you shoot them.  Even worse than 1's boss fight, which is amazing.

World map.  Why is there even a world map any more?  You don't set up radar stations to detect UFOs to shoot down.  You just click on a mission icon and click on Wait here 7 days".

Line of sight.  If you have squidgy rules for what constitutes LOS
date:
don't move the camera down low to show me exactly how bad your math is.  Stay high and let me pretend that the guy did have a shot.  And the icon on enemy for "you can see them from the square you are mousing over" is hilarious when there is no way to get both on the screen at the same time because of camera angle and zoom cap.

Snake guys.  That tongue.  Seriously.  It takes precisely one tongue attack to realize what a bad idea being able to drag my dood through walls and windows and trees and rocks from 50 feet away.  A) Where does he keep that tongue normally?  2) Ten second brainstorm- an abductor alien type with a gun that shoots a short range teleport taser.  Bam.  Problem solved.  No dragging across the ground.

Base building.  The workshop is equivalent to one enginer.  The lab is worth one scientist.  Adjacency bonuses are gone so there is no planning.

Proving Ground.  How come some projects are pay once and your team gets unlimited copies and some projects only give you one?  And how come they don't tell you that before you click?

Chyssalids. The ultimate terror from the first game is just a gimpy stun-baton guy who hides under ground.  How do they know where to hide
recommended: come to think of it.  They can't burrow horizontally.  So it's just a gimick to get a free hand-to-hand attack because their melee is such a great system it should be showcased.\n\nEwoks.  Melee does the same damage to doods in power armor as a rail gun.  I'm sure it is a very nice stun baton

The combats better, clearer , more cunstimisation , more gear choices the skills have been ramped up , height bonus got doubled, supression imposes a wopping -50 now over double its previous value. add in armour and all the skills the enemy uses and you end up with a much richer deeper tactical combat.

The Geoscape is now a valid tactical level with real choices to make, sure there are time sensitive missions that need to be done as they pop up but between those your free to invest your time as you see fit, generating troops or resources to increase either your economy or to fight back, and a balance needs to be struck, be too aggressive and stall out , be too passive and the aliens can simply win.

The base building options are at the same time smaller but also a bit more impactful. you actually have choice rather than being a slave to the satelite nexus spam. whats your first priority? get a guerilla school and some of the old officer training unlocks such as squad size , xp bonus and more loot, go for an advanced warfare facility (how you heal fast) so your troopers are unlocking bonus skills as they level? or maybe you want to push and get a psionics lab out early and get some psychers on the field.

Timers! big bone of contention and there is a veritable hurricane of ♥♥♥♥ on the forums about it. myself i like them mostly , id like a round or two longer to do my guerilla ops and the defend teh civilian missions are a bit vulnerable to spawn rng. but with over 20 hours in i havent actually lost a mission to them, i have left a trooper behind just couldnt get everyone to da chopper in time.

they certainlymake sense thematically , you are an insurgency now after all , take to long and the legions of the enemy will descend on you and swamp you. and they certainly address the issue of overwatch crawling so many relied on. dp you like this design choice? well its personal opinion and im sure there will be ods to remove them if there isnt already, but myself i like thier addition.

its a much more agressive game , between the timers and the aliens actively winning the game infront of you and it might not be for everyone. but for me its a glorious breath of fresh air. the new faster pace really forces you to make the most of your troops and to push.

im a big fan of 4x and turn based strategy games and i really like this new cranked up xcom. a strong contender for game of the year for me , but i love the genre and have adored the franchise since the release of the original i played back on my amiga , your mileage may vary, if in doubt watch some lets plays and see

oh and dont skip the tutorial its full of story and feels!

Welcome back commander its good to see you

reviewText:
The developers of XCOM 2 were upset that early beta testers of their game found it to be too easy.  They responded to this problem by adding difficulty, not by restricting the number of turns available to finish a mission or by making the enemy AI better, but by upping the enemy HP and throwing more of them at you than is reasonable.

I'm on the first terrorizing mission of the game.  My squad size is four.  It's impossible at this point to have increased it to five because there haven't been enough missions to get someone to sargeant rank.  When I move forward for the first time on the map I uncover five enemies.  They each take a volley from my entire squad to take down.  The five enemies are: a sectoid, two commanders, and two stun lancers.  One of the civillians next to me is actually a shape shifter.  If I kill anyone other than the sectoid in the first round, it's immediately resurrected as a zombie.  The shape shifter gets to reveal itself and attack in the same turn regardless of whether or not I get close enough to it to make it transform.  There is literally no way for me to avoid having at least one stun lancer running through my party knocking people unconscious after the second round.

XCOM - you didn't make this game more challening by making it more unfair.  You made it infuriating to play by obviously overstacking the deck against me.  This ♥♥♥♥ isn't fun.

reviewText:
In 2012, an old strategy franchise returned from the dead and showed the gaming community just what real difficulty and real pain is. That game was XCOM: Enemy Unknown, rebooted from a series once known as X-COM and it went on to win not just the pleasure of old fans but gain new fans as well.

XCOM 2 is the sequel to Enemy Unknown. Storywise, everything that happened in Enemy Unknown was a fake. The Commander was really a prisoner to the alien invaders and Earth has been conquered and ruled by the aliens with a faction of apparent human symphatizers called ADVENT. As the Commander, you're freed at the beginning of the game and once again, it's up to you to lead the forces of Earth against the aliens, only this time you'll be the attacker.

From a gameplay perspective, XCOM 2 is mostly the same. You try your best to keep your soldiers in the best cover you can find and launch attacks on your enemies. What changes is that this time, you start out in Concealment mode. The enemy won't know where you are until you attack or get spotted by them, so this is where strategy comes in as you'll have to pick a perfect opportunity to ambush the enemy. Sounds simple? Well, it wouldn't be XCOM if it was simple now, wouldn't it? This time, certain missions also feature a turn timer which shows how many turns you can take before you fail the mission. With that in mind, you have to get to an objective as quickly as you can while also keeping an eye on the timer. While it may seem like a rush, the timer is mostly fair. You do have enough time to get to an objective, you just need to make the most of Concealment mode. Another new element to the game is the more destructible environment. Putting all of your soldiers on top of a building may not always be such a good idea.

And stopping you from reaching those objectives would be the aliens now bolstered by ranks of so-called human volunteers. Some aliens make a return like the Sectoid and Muton but even the ones that returned have completely evolved or have been upgraded. Sectoids are no longer cannon fodder, Floaters have been upgraded to the angelic-looking Archons and the dreaded Sectopods return in a slimmer yet more powerful design. One way or another, the aliens are going to ruin your day, each of them with their own unique way.

All is not lost however. Your soldiers may be outnumbered and outgunned, but they're no pushovers. The classes are both similar and different from Enemy Unknown. Snipers now known as Sharpshooters not only make use of Sniper rifles but can learn to use pistols like a gunslinger from the Old West. A new class called the Ranger employs a high-risk, high reward combat style to slash the enemy with swords in melee combat. With the destructible environments, the Grenadier basically becomes the most powerful and valuable class you can have in your squad as you can blow enemies off buildings or those hiding behind cars and other explosive objects. Most importantly, you also can blow up walls and obstacles so that you can reach a objective faster. Rest assured, you're going to have a lot of fun doing that.

While XCOM 2 doesn't disappoint in its gameplay, it does in it's optimization. You'd think that having it as a PC-exclusive would make it easier for Firaxis to release a more polished game but nope, that didn't happen. The game is buggy like hell, at least it's mostly visual bugs  but still it can ruin the experience a little bit, especially for the last mission. There's also other weird problems like the aliens' turn taking too long, sudden framerate drops and the like but most players didn't experience anything game-breaking. Hopefully, Firaxis fixes the game soon.

All in all, XCOM 2 is a fantastic game and is a textbook example of what devs should do when making a sequel (not the bugs though). If you're one for great turn-based combat and you can stand the pain of watching your men and women die horribly in combat, then you'll love XCOM 2. Just remember when you miss a 95% shot, that's XCOM, baby.

reviewText:
XCOM® 2 is a 3D-but-isometric-tactical-shoot-them-aliens-up game. The plot boils down to this: extraterrestrial beings have taken over the world and it's your job to take it back. You need to dissect aliens and research their technology in order to find out more about them and come up with ways of defeating them.

Positive:
The game plays extremely similar to XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Taking cover, shooting, researching, upgrading your base and many other things feel very similar. There are, however, new features that are all built upon that rock solid base that we, or I, know and love. My personal favourite and in my opinion biggest feature is a stealth mode. You can't Metal Gear Solid the game up by silently taking down enemies, but you can now avoid them, sneak around them to set up ambushes and create massive tactical advantages. The game also features a load of new enemies. Most old enemies from XCOM: Enemy Unknown have been genetically modified using human DNA, making for more powerful enemies than ever before, because YES, this game is HARD. I recommend people who aren't familiar with XCOM play XCOM: Enemy Unknown before picking this up.

Something XCOM: Enemy Unknown was, in my opinion, already good at got massively improved: character customization! The higher the level of your character, the more you can unlock and the more unique your characters will become. I am a massive fan of extensive character customization and I absolutely love playing around with the customizer in this game. It has a load of options and features something for everyone's taste: wacky, tactical or whatever's inbetween, it's in there somewhere.

Negative:
I don't have many problems with this game, except for it's framerate. I recommend you watch out with this if your PC has low specifications, because I run it at 30 to 40 FPS, even though this PC can easily handle GTA V on some of the highest settings and still run it at a smooth 60 FPS.


My verdict:
A solid 8.5/10

reviewText:
Welcome to X-COM 2! Good Guy Terrorist Edition!

In X-COM 2, you'll be freeing humanity from the clutches of our new alien overlords of 20 years! You play as the commander of the previous game, and with your track record of losing the planet to aliens, you were the first man they spent 2 decades to hire. God help us.

But they probably recognise it wasn't your fault, since even the best tactician in the world can't win a fight with sub-standard troops. Which brings us onto 'Rookies'. Rookies are the mystical genetic blend of a stormtrooper's one night stand with a red shirt. Rookies could aim to breathe, miss, and then panic at someone doing it correctly as they are clearly a threat to their existence. Having a squad of rookies is asking for trouble, one panicky little ♥♥♥♥ can start a tantrum spiral that would make Dwarf Fortress revel in glee.

But in all seriousness, X-COM 2 has been a solid improvement to EU/EW. Even with day 1 bugs it felt solid to play, has a lot of interesting lore and new mechanics, but retains the original X-COM charm of having troops miss stunned enemies at point blank range only to get mindraped by sectoids. Recommended!

reviewText:
I have never written a steam review before but feel compelled due to the wave of negativity I have noticed and due to my experience so far!

I have put around 14 hours into the game at the time of writing and am having an absolute blast, I love the game, XCOM EU/EW has been the game I have played the most over the last few years and I believe this game has impoved upon that in every way so far!

A lot of negativity I have seen is about performance, I obviously can't speak for everyone and I am not a 'hardcore' PC gamer by any means, I bought an Alienware X51 3ish years ago and have not upgraded it in any way and would not know where to start if I had to, my PC is between minimum and recommended specs, i5 processor, NVIDIA GTX 660, 8GB RAM and the game runs fine for me.  I should say I have never looked at FPS counters in games and would only complain if the game was stuttering and impeding my ability to play the game and it isn't, I have noticed some stuttering in the cut scenes and a few times the camera pauses for a few seconds too long but that's it so far - I should also say I have not touched the graphics options so far and am just playing on what the game recommended for my PC on launch so I could probably improve the performance more so if needed.

People have also complained about turn timers, I was unsure at first but really like them now, great feeling when you extract your squad with only 1 turn to go!  Makes the game more interesting for me - I used to camp and try to draw the enemy to me in the first game which artificually lengthened missions and did bore me occasionally, I cannot do that any more, at least on the majority of missions and I love it.  The timers also fit the 'guerrilla' theme of the game which I love.  I have noticed there are already mods available to remove and tweak the turn timers as well so this could help people who cannot learn to love the mechanic.

Also, the fact modding is intergrated through the steam workshop is brilliant as it makes it more accesilbe to people like me and will only go onto enhance the game and increase it's longevity - which will be good anyway as this games is made to be replayed!

Anyway, as I said, for me, I love the game and it is running fine on my PC. I would recommended you give this game a try and if bought via steam directly you can always get a refund if you cannot play!

reviewText:
I have some experience with older Command and Conquer games, Final Fantasy Tactics: Advance, and Fire Emblem, but this is the first and only XCOM game I'll ever play. I absolutely hate this game, and wish I hadn't thrown away $60 on such an unpolished mess.

My main problems with XCOM 2 are (in no order):
The game does a very poor job of informing the player about vital mechanics.
I hate all four characters: Tygan, Shen, the pilot, and Mass Effect's The Elusive Man after about 80 more years of heavy chainsmoking.
The game is way too difficult during the first third, especially for a first-time player.
Enemy abilities are never explained. Unless you know beforehand, you have to risk your pawns' very important lives just to know how to fight enemies you've canonically seen before in some form.
Attack range is never explicitly shown. FF Tactics: Advance managed to do this beautifully 13 years ago on the GBA.
To manually path around hazards, you have to waste a move rather than the game having a competent pathing system.
There are too many things happening at any time on the overworld. I have like 6 things to scan, 3 dark events going on, a resistance raid, Avatar Project targets, monthly reports, and research all overlapping each other.
The game never tells you that a sniper can't fire his rifle after moving.
For some reason, a soldier will be gravely wounded after taking only 4 damage out of 17 health, and I've healed it with a medkit.
Supplies are too scarce for the first third of the game. By the final third, I contantly had over 2000 that I couldn't spend on anything.
Unless you've already played through XCOM 2, you will not properly lay out the additional rooms you can add to your ship unless you spend even more time and supplies fixing it.
After you beat it, it plays some cutscenes, and that's it. No New Game + or anything.
Soldiers' voices will often glitch, and play in a language, sometimes even gender, other than what's selected.
It's often far too difficult to click on specific tiles when targeting abilities like melee attacks and grenades.
It seems like Vipers can grab you from literally across the map.
You can have your engineers build experimental" armor
hoursPlayed: and ammunition. This actually means that you throw away at least one elerium core and wait 7-30 days for a random item in that category that you may already have."

reviewText:
I'm loving it, it improves nicely on the first XCOM (not the original one, haven't played it).

The fact that many missions have some sort of time pressure will irritate some (c.f. some reviews. CLARIFICATION: you can take as long as you want to make your moves, the only limit is the number of turns you get.). Be aware that there's already mods that increase the turn limit or get rid of it completely, so if it's really not your thing, you can easily play the game differently. But I think the frequent time pressure is great and it improves the game. Here's why:

-having to manage time as a resource IS strategic, contrary to some opinions. While it does remove the option to take it absolutely slow and cautious, so far, I've found there's plenty of wiggle room and making a mad dash for the objective is NOT your only option.

-time pressure is thematically very coherent with the game's premise of being resistance fighters. Not having it would create ludo-narrative dissonance.

-what the turn limit basically does is force you to give up the most effective XCOM: EU play-style, which is take it super slow, only activate one bunch of enemies at a time, spam overwatch and reload after each encounter. Unless you didn't care about winning, XCOM forced you to play like that. There were no rewards for finishing early, afaik (there were some rewards for taking risks in the expansion, though). Favouring such a slow playstyle is a bit like wasting the player's time.

-time pressure lets you experience a different, thrilling playstyle the same way playing without saves (ironman mode, iirc) helps you enjoy the game in a different way that you probably wouldn't, with saves enabled. Unless you're super disciplined, you know you end up reloading when your favorite soldier dies. Same goes for taking yet another turn, reload- and overwatch-spamming.

MISC COOL STUFF:
-A memorial for your soldiers with the option to write them an epitaph. So far, my only casualty's reads: Whatshername will not be forgotten."

-Enemy Reinforcements: (not sure
date: if these also happened in XCOM: EU). It totally fits the scenario and it's very exciting to see a dropship come in and worry about what it might bring
recommended:
as well as very satisfying to set up an ambush for them and wipe them when their feet touch the ground.

FINAL THOUGHTS:
If you liked XCOM:EU
hoursPlayed: you'll love this one. Give it a try as it is

reviewText:
If you enjoy any kind of Turn-Based strategy games, or you've played Enemy Unknown. This is everything you expect and 100x more.
Difficulty is up to 10, but not to the point where you get frustrated, but to the the point where you feel so motivated to complete the mission.
The addition of time pressure to the game overall, as the Alien's secret weapon is in construction, time is of the essence, every second and every move you make in the World Map is crucial, don't waste time or you will feel the consequences.
The graphics themselves are wonderful, nothing to write home about, but a definite improvement.
The newly added character customisation also adds a whole new experience as you can create your own units or even escort units. The customistation is quite developed for a game like this.
Overwatch ability can also create some wonderful moments which can either make you full of pride, as you witness your units totally wreck the opponent or leave you out in the open for attacks.
But as always, games like these arent perfect. The whole chance to hit system still feels ♥♥♥♥ed, but not as bad as before. The whole 'you're next to a guy but you have 60% chance to hit' can be aggrevating. But for me atleast it didn't happen too often. Everyone's game experiences varies in how badly ♥♥♥♥ed they can get because of it.
The story is a unique one, normally we're defending earth, but now we are trying to take it back from the aliens. It's loosely attached to Enemy Unknown, so if you havent played that you can still play this without knowing what happened before.

reviewText:
XCOM Is probably the most engaging game I've played in recent years, and XCOM 2 does great justice to the franchise. Let me break it down to pretty bullet points for you, in case you need help deciding whether to purchase this.

PROS:
- Strong theme and backstory, quite a mysterious plot.
- Looks awesome, art direction is exquisite.
- Tense! Some battles can really get your heart pumping.
- Interesting mechanic for the strategy map.
- Deep and fun soldier customization.
- Diverse enemies and mission objectives add variety.
- Long campaign!

CONS:
- Bad dice rolls can be cruelly unfair. Part of the game, tho! It's XCOM!
- The first run (with the tutorial ON, that is) is too frantic for my taste. I like to be left alone.
- Has some performance issues. Firaxis appears to be working hard on fixing them.
- I've seen a few glitches and quirks. Bugs, that is.
- Rather pricey, considering the above.

CONCLUSION: 9/10, would name my gunner Silvester Stallone" again."

reviewText:
Xcom EU with Long War mod is one of the best games I own. You would have to go a long way to beat it and I have to say that Firaxis have gone so far past that mark that you will need the hubble telescope.

Its visually stunning and the gameplay still captures what is all good and great about Xcom games. I have played the first 4 or 5 missions and Im blown away. I have been looking forward to this game for months and im not dissapointed. Shame I have work in the morning and have to sleep with the 11pm launch and all.

Still a few first day bugs which im sure will be ironed out. These relate to cutscenes and mainly experianced with the launch of the skyranger for missions. It goes out of synch but this is a minor annoyance. The soldiers moving animations can also seem a little jumpy at times but not so much that i care so far

Soldier customisations are great and I spent an hour or so messing with my guys and girls some fun looks but also some really cool ones too. Combat is still as good as ever but one little niggle is the cutscene of the soldiers face everytime they shoot. In Xcom you only saw this on a kill so everytime seems excessive but the gun animation and sounds are good. Hacking for in mission power ups is a nice touch as is the soldier panic. When a soldier panics he can randomly run off and take a shot which actually finished a mission for me :) Would like to be able to select my own soldier classes on promotion though as that was great in LW but we will see how this goes.Research looks varied and interesting and I like I can pick up gear from drops of dead enemies rpg style.

All in all this was worth the wait and I would highly recommend it to anyone with a passing interest in turn based comabt mecahincs. Sigh I can see another 500+ hours of my life dissapearing 10/10

reviewText:
My playtime is miniscule right now but let me give my piece  on it anyway. The game itself first and foremost caters to the XCOM: Enemy Within fan, it not only refines the mechanics seen in the previous games but it added new ones as well. The classes are distinct from one another and gives you the player greater tactical choice in your gameplay. But by far the best new item added is the concealment option which pretty much means that your team is invisible to all enemies until they are either detected via patrol or more often than not via an ambush you have setup.

The story and atmosphere from what I have seen in sublime, the game pulls in no stops from telling you that you lost the previous war and that right now, XCOM are considered terrorists, this is a huge step up both thematically and mechanically as well since the aforementioned concealment mechanic makes so much sense.

The mods will also bring in so much life to this game, as of writing this, there are 3 main mods that can easily be added to the game via Steam Workshop.


If I have one gripe I would point to the performance, it's not gamebreaking but it is a hassle and it is obvious, I struggle to get a smooth 60FPS with many of the filters turned off, I run an I5 3570K with a GTX680, not the top of the line setup admittedly but it should have handled the game better than it did.

reviewText:
Pros
-60 Hour Campaign
-Many more alien types, creating more dynamic encounters.
-UI Cleaned up from Enemy Unknown, quality of life improvements (reload only costing one action now, etc).
-Far more soldier customization options, including weapon customization.
-Game mechanics fit the Guerrilla warfare theme, having to contact cells, stay on the move, tactical insertions.
-Improved story telling and cutscenes.
-Ironman mode returns (requires tutorial to be disabled).
-Graphically gorgeous settings and improved terrain.
-Game now notifies you if you are flanking or being flanked by an enemy.
-Smarter, more aggressive AI. They use their best abilities off cool down and flank hard and often.
-Multiplayer is back and cleaned up/improved.
-Sharing custom characters (can appear randomly through your play through, even as VIPs).
-Weapon customization allows some counters, such as free reloads, increased crit or aim chance, and chance to kill outright.
-Experimental weapon research allowing for random weapon unlocks, including flamethrowers.
-More armor types.
-Armor is now indicated in-game and indicates it's damage reduction, or if it gets shredded.
-Classes redesigned but incredibly balanced with their talent choices, both trees are viable playstyles for all.
-Permadeath
-New event: Base defense, giving you access to ALL your soldiers over time while you defend the Avenger.
-Can EVAC from any mission at anytime, but must deploy and reach your EVAC zone with each soldier.
-Injured soldiers can be EVAC'd if you can't stablize them.
-Line of Sight Indicator now helps tell you in advance if a move gives your soldier line of sight on what targets.
-Concealment and Ambushes, incredibly powerful starts.
-Potentional for PURE stealth missions (incredibly fun).
-Buying Armor or new Weapons no longer require multiple purchases and are instead turned into default equipment.
-High replayability.
-Vast Modding scene.
-Vipers <3

Neutral
-Can lose your 60 hour campaign at anytime (as in the Aliens can win).
-Aliens don't wait around for you to tech up, deploying new aliens very often.
-5x more missions than Enemy Unknown, you will get a ton of random side missions, only a few you can ignore.
-Old mission types are back; UFO Landing Sites, Terror Missions, VIP missions, etc.
-Terror Missions now require that you to save a minimum of 6 civilians out of 13-14, fixing the previous version's mistake.
-Many missions now have turn limits (for objectives), forcing more aggressive play and less Overwatch spam.
-Avatar Project: The Aliens final goal that can make progress incredibly fast if you wait around too long.
-Injured or dead soldiers can be carried to an EVAC zone to return their equipment/weapons.
-Weapon and equipment can be lost if the soldier carrying them dies and is not recovered.
-Can slaughter civilians outside of terror missions with no reprecusions.
-New Geoscape map takes a while to learn but is more streamlined.
-Avenger base building is more streamlined, no adjacant bonuses (just need 1 of everything).
-Can build PSI Operators much more early or rush for unlocking them.
-Many aliens are mini-bosses (Sectoids, Archons, etc) more dangerous mechanics (Mind Control by mission 1).
-Research for Science and Tech upgrades remains the same.
-Only 3 Weapon Types; Standard, Magnetic, Plasma.
-Soldiers can be lightly wounded, wounded, or gravely wounded, putting them out from 3-18 days or more (always occurs if any damage is taken, changed from Enemy Unknown).
-Soldiers can become Shaken (Will reduced to 0), requiring kills or safe missions completion to remove.
-Dark Events: A difficulty modifier where you chose 2 of the 3 debuffs that you want against you.

Cons
-Game difficulty can be overwhelming for new players, even on Rookie (the lowest).
-Central nags at you very often on what needs to be done, even with Beginner VO turned off.
-Missions occur very often, sometimes forcing you to stop scanning to finish something to go do them.
-Avatar Progress can sometimes bump up drastically at random, even after destroying a Black Site.
-Aim chances are lower all around and require heavy use of flanking to increase.
-Hitting or Missing is now PREDETERMINED before you take the shot, and only rerolls when you move (crit not affected).
-Early UFO missions are very overwhelming without more soldiers or equipment.
-Some Launch day performance issues, v-sync, AA, and AO need to be disabled entirely to get or maintain over 60 FPS.

Final Thoughts
-Game is stellar and totally worth the purchase, but might be even more valuable on sale with the small season pass (which adds more customization, more weapons and armor, a new class type, and more story missions). Launch day issues have been very minor at best, my frame rate only seemed to drop during loading screens until the mission was loaded then returned to normal 60+. The customizations, difficulty, alien types all add to the vast replayability to the game and there are different paths you can take early on to determine how you want to play, instead of building satelites. Modding adds even far more to the game, and devs have given the tools they used to make the game to modders to expand upon that (name a dev that does that).

reviewText:
9.5/10
I've just completed the game on Commander difficulty and immediately decided to do it again but on Ironman as I did do a little bit of save dancing in the most intense parts of the game and want to remove the temptation next time.

For anyone that loves a multi-faceted strategy game that delivers tough decisions at every layer then this game is for you.

Pros:
+Aliens are much more varied than before requiring new tactics, tough decisions and intense fights.

+Your non-standard gear is random. I only unlocked a few grenades and some vests on my first playthrough and they went on every mission. Can't wait to unlock new interesting items.

+You can play your own way. I finished the game without recruiting a single Psi Operative.

+Every non-story map is procedurally generated, I have yet to see any serious repetition as I start my 2nd playthrough.

+The new perk trees are interesting and fairly balanced, I did not at any point think I wanted to bring ALL of one class on a mission. Though I did exempt Psi-Ops just because I did not have time to build extraneous facilities.

+The strategy layer is much more complex than the original and the addition of strategy missions for gaining resources along with the task of building a resistance network, recruiting and assigning Engineers to Excavation, Construction or Maintenance, researching specific technologies and dealing with the Black Market makes it an entirely seperate and sophisticated game within a game.

+Character customization is now an incredibly powerful tool that will allow you to create many varied characters and through the game give some extra badass-ness to your best performing soldiers.

+The character pool system allows you to add your family and friends into the game, but still nestled inside the random generation of the game. I recently had one of my friends mind-controlled and shot another friend in the face whilst attempting to escort a 3rd friend to safety as a VIP. This also works with getting attached to a character in a previous game and saving them to the pool for later games as this super badass.

Cons:
- The game bugs out occasionally with the screen being blank or units dancing around the screen, once my screen was blocked by scenery whilst attempting to hack and couldn't see the UI.

- Nothing throughout the entire game prepares you for what you will face in the final missions, it was disconcerting when I first attempted them.

- The main story is a bit weak but the game never focuses on it for long.

reviewText:
Home Sweet Home

Given the alternatives, Earth is a pretty cool place to live. (although with pollution and global warming it sometimes seems we're doing our best to change that).

It's just as well Earth meets our needs so perfectly because we don't have the ability to travel anywhere else to set up camp anyway... at least not yet (unless you count the moon, but we haven't been back there in nearly 50 years, governments would rather spend their money sending planes to drop bombs on deserts than sending rockets into space to benefit all mankind.)


Real-Estate

One day, we will have the technological capability to travel to the stars, which will come in handy when the Earth becomes a less hospitable place to live.

It's inevitable, whether it's climate change, lack of resources or the death throes of the Sun itself, eventually, if we want to survive as a species, we're going to need  to get off this rock and find a new one.

The problem is, even if everything works out for us, if we survive long enough and develop the technology to travel on mass to the stars, we're still going to need to find another Earth-like planet with all the amenities (running water, central heating, oxygen, etc.) that we're accustomed to.

Whatever happens, however we ruin our planet, for the moment, we're all stuck here so we have to make the most of it..


Squatters Rights

Do you know why life evolved on earth?
It was because we have all of those lovely luxuries here already.

There's a chance that if we did manage to find another planet that can sustain oxygen sucking life like ourselves, that it is already doing just that, sustaining some alien oxygen suckers that are perfectly happy where they are and have no interest in moving out and letting us move in.


Aggressive Negotiations

Sure, we could ask nicely, but if they didn't want to share there's always another option.

We've been turning sandy deserts into glassy craters on Earth for a while now, why not just use our military might to clear a path for our forlorn colonists? Desperate times call for desperate measures. We can justify anything if we need it badly enough.

If the native nuisance is still trapped on their own evolutionary cradle and we have the capability to get there, we're probably going to be more technologically advanced than they are (we'll have bigger bombs) so it shouldn't be too much of a problem.


Envious Eyes

But what if the tables were turned?

We're still happy here on Earth, things are ticking over nicely, we've still got petrol for our cars, food for our bellies and oxygen for our lungs, then some alien eyes start to peer greedily at our planet.
We'd be unlikely to roll over and give it to them, no matter how big their bombs are.

It'd be a fight we'd likely lose (unless Jeff Goldblum and his trusty laptop are around to save us with a timely upload of a computer virus).
But assuming this technological war or the worlds fluke doesn't come to pass, we'd be screwed.

It'd take a long time to eradicate all of us though and a submissive populace might fit better with the aliens plans, besides, why make war when propaganda can enslave a people just as easily.


A New Hope

That's where XCOM 2 comes in.

It's been 20 years since the brief war" against the invaders was lost

reviewText:
Unlike XCOM1, where you had a fighting chance, to beat this game requires save scumming (or modding). While Bentley will insist you need to 'review your tactics' at the end of a failed mission, no amount of tactical play will stop the aliens from one shotting your troops through cover. This is complicated by a buggy UI that will indicate one thing, but then something else happens. Like getting hit with status effects (running through fire, acid, poison) and being spotted are not always indicated. Also, a genade's damage radius can be often misrepresented causing you to destroy a mission objective. I've had a hack objective get destroyed because I threw a grenade over it. Camera transarency glitches and other things that cause your troops to move to locations you did not intend further this issue.

The game seems to let you know from the very start that you should expect casualties. OK, Firaxis. If that's the case then why can't I get more troops? I start with 9, early in the game you can get recruits for free(I got 2). A few missions later (2 died to one-shot crits through cover, 1 died to burning that the game didn't tell me I would get when I moved, 1 got one-shot by an exploding car). Now I've got 7 total, with 4 wounded. Can't even field a full squad anymore and I'm only 5 missions into the game. The game is filled with design contradictions like this. Expect to lose troops, but don't have any good means of replacing them (50 supplies is a lot for a recruit, and more than you have to spare). Time the missions, but moving quickly almost always results in an unfavorable situation. Fail a mission? Now you get reduced income from the resistance in that area. Complete a mission? I hope it was worth the bodies you had to sacrifice. As you progress, the game just stacks the negative consequences against you repeatedly until you can just forget about even playing. Because now you don't have enough troops, don't have gooed enough weapons, and don't have troops leveled sufficiently.

Parts of the game are tedious and time wasters. Bentley will constanly tell you what's blatantly obvious. The camera will constantly hover over the objective when you get near it (even though it's marked from the beginning). It's just dumb how much time is wasted and how irritating it is to have to listen to and watch pointless stuff when you just want to take your turn.

I have also found that the game forces you to play a certain way. In XCOM1, you spammed satellites. Now, you have to spam communications upgrades. If you don't, you will end up unable to get to mission areas and losing. Also, certain classes are much better than others. I would put specialist as the weakest in combat (but they can provide nice bonuses). Snipers are versatile if you go the pistol route, but otherwise can slow you down. Grenadiers are epic and can do some great AOE. Try dropping an acid grenade on a flare before reinforcements arrive and watch the aliens stand in place for 3 rounds as they don't want to get the debuff for moving through those tiles. Rangers seem to do the highest single target damage and can be essential to take down high hp targets. I've heard that snipers can do really well with high ground.

Yes it seems to be poorly optimized (disable bloom, SSAO and AA helps). I have yet to crash, though. I can live with some minor graphical glitches and a some performance slowdowns for reaction shots. The camera can act up as well, but that's just another annoyance. The thing that is frustrating is the incosistent manner in which some tactical notifications are given. The detection while stealthed for example, can incorrectly show a spot as being safe to move to (even though you can see the alien that spots you before you make the move). The notification icons for burning, poison can decide not to show up. I've had aliens be invisible on the map, even though troops can target them (also more irritating than game-breaking).

Bottom Line: wait for some mods to come out that fix game balance a bit (I like the one where you get to start with 1 engineer and 1 scientist), wait for a bug fix patch, and then get it on sale.

reviewText: XCOM 2 is an excellent follow-up to XCOM : Ennemy Unknown and XCOM : Ennemy Within. The game is tense and heavy while also giving you a realm of possibilities when it comes to killing aliens. This time around, your soldiers are on the offensive, and as such, the way you start a mission and set-up an initial ambush on your ennemies can change the odds of a mission. Fortunately or not, things do not always go as planned and the RNG makes for an entertaining but sometimes frustrating game. Ennemies are varied and all troublesome in their own, special way, but your soldiers also feel more resourceful and powerful then ever. The relatively easy to procure Psi Operative Class is so versatile and potentially devastating that you'll always want to have one in your squad. The game can be a little rough around the edges and the mission timers can be a big source of stress, but with the possibility to mod the game to suit your style of gameplay, this point is almost moot. With a few updates from Firaxis and an ongoing mod support, this game could easily be remembered as a classic of PC gaming in the years to come.

XCOM returns, and it is back with a resounding bang. I won't give away any plot details, but X2 offers a deeper look into the various supporting characters (not your soldiers) than its predecessor; while  maintaining the general overall feel of Enemy Unknown/Within. reviewText:
This game is fantastic. It is a very challenging turn based tactical game presented from an isometric point of view on the battlefield combine with a global resource management and territory gaining element against a global doom ticker. You have to try and take the world back from an occupying force one territory at a time, and amass resources to improve your base, research better technologies for your soldiers. One a tactical mission scale, you command a squad of 4 - 6 soldiers (you can mod this to be more) who consist of different classes, earn exp and rank up. There are multiple skills for each class to choose from, and a lot of items to equip them with.

If you're familiar Enemy Unknown/Enemy Within, then this game keeps all the good stuff about that game, and adds stuff to make it even better.

A lot of people are complaining about performance issues. The game is indeed not fully optimized, but will probably be patched soon enough. In general, I meet the system requirements, and even play on mac OS X. I have no issues so far.

A lot of the negative reviews seem to be due to people whinging about the turn timers. Please allow me to give you some context; The developers intentionally put this in to discourage a cowardly and tedious meta that was adopted by many players in the first game. In XCOM, you get to perform 2 actions per turn; you can move a certain distance twice, move and shoot, or move and use a skill. However, if you use your action to shoot, your turn ends (there are ways to change this by ranking soldiers of a certain class). There is a universal skill that all classes have called overwatch; it ends your turn and prepares your squad to shoot at any enemy that paths in sight during their turn.

Due to XCOM being somewhat challenging, many people decided to move half a turn, and overwatch every single turn across every map (maps in XCOM are rather large) because they didn't want their soldiers to die. The devs decided to upend this, and added turn timers to the second game.

HOWEVER, the turn timers are very lenient, you get plenty of turns to reach your objective safely (through your squad being concealed) and to complete it, kill enemies and evac the map with 2 or 3 turns to spare. There are also mods that allow you to tweak these (as XCOM 2 has complete mod support). The people whining about the turn timers are probably the people that I described above. Instead of actually altering the turn timers to be longer, or using the steam workshop mods that disable them completely, they just give a great game a negative review.

What do you feel is more tactical? Option A: Moving with stealth, setting up ambushes for enemy patrols, taking them out efficiently from a roof, blowing up the side of a building to reach your objective quick then evacing after a successful mission, or Option B: tediously moving half a turn and overwatching every turn against an enemy that isn't even actively looking for you in the first place? Yeah, I thought so. Anyone saying the timers remove the tactical layer of this game was never very good to begin with. Also, it doesnt make snipers useless. Fully upgraded snipers can take out multiple squads in a single turn if used correctly. Furthermore, on many missions, the turn timers deactivate after you complete the objective, leaving you with plenty of time to mop up remaining aliens for loot and exp. Many missions dont even have timers (campaign critical story mission, and alien retaliation missions.)

If your pc meets the minimum requirements for this game, and you are interested in this type of game then please try it out. If you dont like the timers, you can easily mod them. This game is incredibly challenging, and has many mechanics to learn, but once you master them, the game becomes very enjoyable and manageable. It also has infinite replay value (and is moddable to be even more infintely replayable)

Just don't listen to the whiners who are moaning because the devs decided that they didnt want people who wanted to cheese the game to be able to do so. Also, the people leaving bad reviews because they found the game too hard are a vocal minority who don't like learning too many things, or having open ended choice based game play that doesnt involve move to the arrow, now shoot that one guy, now move to the next arrow. Head over the XCOM subreddit to see how many people are having so much fun playing this. Other people don't seem to understand how probability works and that 90% is not the same as 100%. There is still a 10% chance to miss, but the majority of the time you will roll the 90%.

Yes the game is challenging and hard, but gives you every tool and opportunity to win.

Make up your own mind and don't listen to impatient self-entitled man children with the attention span of a gold fish.

reviewText:
XCOM 2 succeeds because it fixes the one large flaw with its predecessor: pacing.

Oh, things are still tactical and patience is still important. But in Enemy Unknown, experienced players quickly learned that the safest way to play was at a slow, glacial pace, spamming the overwatch ability (reactionary fire on the enemy's turn) every turn as your squad crept inch by inch across the map, combing it with a net of deadly crossfire. While satisfying, there were few rewards for risk and no sense of urgency at all. The tactical flow was prone to stagnation. The expanion, Enemy Within, took steps towards improvement by introducing Meld, a timed resource that would expire within a handful of turns. Yet even with this incentive, the problem remained.

By now, you've probably heard that XCOM 2 will, more often than not, impose turn limits on the player. This has been a source of much frustration and negative feedback -- just look around on this page for some examples -- yet this change is not only a positive one, it's the core of this game's DNA and vital to its success. You can still end every turn with your troops safely tucked in cover and all prepared to fire (and there are times where this is still a logical strategy), but the clock is ticking and it's going to take some measured risk to reap each mission's rewards. Hidden alien foes await in the fog of war standing between your starting point and your goal -- whether that's a VIP to rescue, an alien relay to destroy, or a UFO to raid -- which is tantalizingly close yet guarded enough to punish recklessness with severe consequences.

To complement the renewed sense of urgency, the soldier skillsets and capabilities have seen a significant overhaul. It's mostly familiar mechanically -- you're still taking cover and seeing percentages and screaming as you miss 85% shots -- but an increased focus on melee combat and destructive environments gives you more strategic capabilities that let you move forward towards your objective while maintaining a tactical approach. There's no longer any time to get bogged down in an entrenched skirmish, so the game provides a multitude of alternatives: you can use a grenade launcher to destroy your opponent's cover or rush his position with a deadly swordsman or hack his mechanized units and bring them under your control or...well, you get the idea. The destruction you'll inflict on the battlefield is both visually impressive -- buildings crumble, floors collapse, and yes, cars still explode -- and tactically crucial.

On the macro level, base-building is functionally similar but given a modern board game-esque overhaul that turns engineers from a simple resource into the pieces in a crucial worker placement mechanic. Do you assign your free engineer to speed up construction or to increase your power supply? Or send him off to clear out more room for a new building? Unfortunately, scientists don't receive the same attention and, consequently, feel somewhat pointless. The first scientist recruited increases your research speed by 50%, but diminishing rewards and a lack of usefulness means you'll find yourself continually opting for missions that reward engineers or supplies instead. The Geoscape has been given a similar gloss of board game paint -- no longer just a fancy hologram showing you where your next mission, the globe now gives you options to pursue additional resources or targets of opportunity. The layout is far from intuitive and the frequency of interruptions can approach frustration (a 5-day scan to make contact with a new resistance cell feels like an eternity) but it's nice to have options.

I could go on about everything else XCOM 2 does well -- the strong skill progression, the balanced classes that make a pistol-specced sharpshooter 100% viable, the smooth escalation of equipment that has just enough randomness to keep things intriguing -- but I want to end by touching again on the turn limitations. Rarely has a sequel taken such a large mechanical risk, one that completely upends the strategies its predecessor and turns the typical XCOM conventional wisdom on its head. And yes, it is absolutely punishing and demands strict execution and the occasional abandonment of your troops on the battlefield...but it's the most important change the game has made and gives XCOM 2 an injection of urgent life. Firaxis could have been safe and given us more of the same -- but as XCOM 2 will teach you, true rewards rarely come without risk.
